La señora está pidiendo un préstamo para invertir en el negocio de su esposo, que es de venta de artículos del hogar, principalmente plásticos y loza como vasos, vajillas, etc. Él vende a crédito y también al contado, entrega sus productos a domicilio, y viaja a Puerto Lopez y otros lugares para vender sus productos. Comprará un poco de todo con este préstamo para tener mercadería surtida para ofrecer a sus clientes. Como ya lleva 10 años con este negocio, tiene su clientela fija y la gente ya le conoce. 
Elvia dice que su meta para el futuro es agrandar el negocio de su esposo y poner un local para vender los productos.
texts.en:
Elvia is a member of the Mujeres Unidas Village Bank, a large group of women who meet every two weeks in the office of Espoir en Jipijapa, a small city on the Ecuadorian coast. She is a 40-year-old married mother of four children, of whom one is grown and three who are still young. For the past five years she has worked as a salesperson at her sister’s pharmacy. Before this she worked sewing with another woman.

She is requesting a loan to invest in her husband’s business selling housewares such as plastics, cups of china, dishes, etc. He sells these items on credit and also for cash, gets his products delivered to his house, and travels to Puerto Lopez and other places to sell them. He will buy a little bit of everything with this loan in order to have an assortment of merchandise to offer his customers. Since he’s worked for 10 years on this business he has a fixed clientele and people know him. Elvia says that her goal for the future is to expand her husband’s business and install a building to sell the products.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise, including plastics, cups, dishes, etc.

loans.name: Adriana Del Socorro

texts.es: Adriana del Socorro Millón Bárcenas tiene 56 años. Es madre soltera, tiene 6 hijos, pero ninguno está a su cargo. Su actividad económica es la venta de tortillas. Hace más de 13 años que se dedica a esta actividad. Todos los días en su humilde vivienda ofrece sus tortillas, por lo que en su mayoría los vecinos llegan a comprar sus productos. Son a un precio muy accesible y además sus clientes disfrutan de su elaboración. Ella dio inicio a su negocio por la necesidad de proveer a su hogar el pan de cada día y mantener a su familia. el financiamiento que solicita es para la compra de maíz y otros productos para la elaboración. Su mayor sueño es lograr que sus hijos finalicen sus estudios.
texts.en:
Adriana is 56 years old. She is a single mother of six children though none are still under her care. She has been selling tortillas for more than 13 years in her modest dwelling since most of her neighbors come and purchase her products. They are sold at a very affordable prices and moreover, her customers enjoy the way they are made. She started her business out of the necessity to provide her home and children with bread. The loan that she requests is to purchase corn and other supplies for the tortilla production. Her greatest dream is for her children to complete their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Laurie Paguio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to purchase corn and supplies to make tortillas

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is thirty-seven years old and married and she has 3 children who are all in school. She has been selling eggs for the past fifteen years. She obtains her supply of eggs from wholesalers and retails them to her customers, most of whom are food vendors. She wants to use her loan to buy crates of eggs to cater to the demands of her customers. She wants to use proceeds from her operation to build a stall where she can store her eggs. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy crates of eggs.

loans.name: Juana Gregoria

texts.es: Juana  Gregoria Álvarez tiene 47 años de edad con tres hijos todos ya  mayores. El negocio de Doña Juana consiste en brindar el servicio de  molino para masa para tortillas, pinolillo, pozol. El negocio lo inicio su marido pero debido a ciertas circunstancias de la vida falleció, entonces ella  comenzó a hacerse cargo del negocio y no fue nada fácil ya que tenía que conocer muy bien el mecanismo del molino, pero con la ayuda y el apoyo de sus hijos logran mantenerlo. A pesar de este tipo de dificultades no le impide sobresalir adelante con su familia y ganarse el pan de cada día de una manera muy humilde. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de ciertas herramientas que son necesarias para su molino. El sueno de Doña Juana es lograr que sus hijos coronen sus carreras a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Juana Gregoria Álvarez is 47 years old, with three children, all of whom are already grown. Doña Juana's business consists of offering milling services for corn to use with tortillas, pinolillo (a traditional Nicaraguan drink made with ground corn and cacao), and pozol (a similar traditional cornmeal drink). Her husband started the business, but owing to certain circumstances of his life, he passed away, at which point Doña Juana began to take over the business. This was no easy task, since it required detailed knowledge of how the milling machinery worked, but with the help and support of her children, she succeeded in maintaining the mill. In spite of the difficulties she faced, she could not be stopped from moving forward with her family, and she earned their daily bread by working hard at her humble task. The loan that she requests is for capital for her business, with which she will purchase various tools that are necessary in order to maintain her mill. Doña Juana's dream is to achieve enough success for her children to be able to pass that success on to their children.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital de trabajo para mantener su molino

loans.name: Marcela Ramona

texts.es: Marcela Ramona P. tiene 41 años de edad. Ella tiene un pequeño negocio que consiste en la crianza de cerdos. Es casada con 4 hijos a su cargo los niños estudian todavía gracias al esfuerzo de la Señora Marcela. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. Anteriormente el lugar donde ella laboraba no le proporcionaba los ingresos necesarios para ofrecerles a sus hijos el pan de cada día.  Por lo que con esta humilde actividad ha logrado salir adelante con sus hijos El mayor desafío que ha tenido es el accidente que uno de sus hijos por lo que ha tenido que gastar demasiado en medicamentos pero a pesar de todo ha sabido sobrellevar sus problemas. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de alimentos para cerdos y compra de cerdos.
texts.en:
Marcela is 41 years old. She has a small business that consists of raising pigs. She is married with 4 children in her care. They still study thanks to Marcela’s effort.

For more than 5 years she has been engaged in this business. Previously, the place where she worked did not give her the income necessary to offer bread to her children each day. That’s why, with this humble activity, she has succeeded in getting ahead with her children.

The greatest challenge she has had is the accident of one of her children. She has to spend too much for medicine, but in spite of everything she knows how to endure her problems. The reason for this financing is working capital for the purchase of pigs and feed for pigs.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en:
Cecilia is forty-five years old. She is married and has three children. One of  her children is in school, one will enter the university this year and her first child just graduated from the university. Cecilia and her family live in the greater Accra region of Ghana. 

Cecilia makes and sells batik and tye-dye fabrics. Batik and tie-dye are local textile designs in which raffia or waxes are used to prevent pigment (dyes) from getting to undesired areas. She buys raw materials, such as mercerized cotton, caustic soda, etc., from the city. She has been in the business for fifteen years. She hawks (sells door-to-door) in the community. Cecilia wants a loan to buy more raw materials so that she can produce on large scale, trek to more markets, and supply to other regions in Ghana, and even beyond.

loans.use: To buy raw materials.

loans.name: Lorgia Lourdes

texts.es: La Señora Lorgia Lourdes L. L. con la edad de 31 años de edad.es una mujer casada y vive con su hijo de 2 años de edad. El negocio de Doña Lourdes es una pulpería hace mas 10 años que se dedica a este negocio, empezó a vender golosinas a los niños que pasaban de la escuela por lo que ha luchado mucho para obtener este medio de vida. Actualmente realiza sus compras en los camiones que distribuyen los productos que ella compra. el sueno de la Señora Lourdes es hacer crecer su negocio e incrementar las ganancias para salir adelante ya que esta situación es muy difícil para ella a pesar del inconveniente que tiene como es  que una muchacha  le ayude pero  debido a sus pocos ingresos no se lo permite.
texts.en:
Señora Lorgia Lourdes L. L., at the age of 31-years-old, is a married woman and lives with her 2-year-old son. The business of Mrs Lourdes is a store that she has run for more than 10 years. She is dedicated to this business. She began to sell sweets to the children that passed from the school that she has fought a lot to obtain half of her life. At present she purchases from the trucks that distribute the products that she buys. The dream of Señora Lourdes is to grow her business and to increase her profits to do well since this situation is very difficult for her. She would like to hire a girl to help her, but her income is too small to allow it.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital for her candy sales business

loans.name: Dorotea Del Carmen

texts.es: Dorotea del Carmen Gómez tiene 60 años. Su negocio es la venta de furtas y verduras, tiene 4 hijos pero actualmente solo vive con una hija de 22 anos. Hace más de 32 anos que se dedica a este negocio.es una mujer emprendedora que tomo ese negocio, como el medio para salir adelante siendo madre soltera de 4 niños. Ella necesita el financiamiento para poder comprar mercadería  porque todos los días tiene que levantarse muy temprano en busca de sus productos, lo que más le  gusta de trabajo es ofrecerles a sus clientes las frutas más frescas y obtener la satisfacción de sus clientes. El mayor sueño es poder terminar  de reparar su vivienda ya que será lo único que dejara a sus  hijos y nietos.
texts.en:
Dorotea del Carmen Gómez is 60. She sells fruits and vegetables. She has four children, but she currently only lives with her 22 year old daughter. She has been is this business for over 32 years. She is an enterprising woman, who took this business as a means for a single mother of four children to get ahead. She needs the loan to be able to buy merchandise. Every day she has to get up very early to search for her products. What she likes most about her work is offering her customers the freshest fruit and obtaining customer satisfaction. Her biggest dream is to be able to finish repairs on her house. It is the only thing she can leave her children and grandchildren.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Ena Maria

texts.es: Ena María Ramírez P. es una madre soltera. Tiene 53 años. Ella es una mujer con un gran espíritu de alegría y es por medio de este espíritu que ha logrado mantener este negocio. Su actividad económica es una pulperia. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. En su negocio ella vende todo tipo de productos aunque algunas veces, no sea tan fácil de satisfacer a sus clientes, a pesar de esto ha logrado obtener lo suficientes clientes para su negocio. Este dinero será para la compra de golosinas, refrescos naturales, pan galletas entre otro.
texts.en:
Ena María Ramírez P. is a 53 year old single mother. She is a woman with a very happy spirit. It is through this spirit that she has been able to maintain her business. She has a mini market. She has had this business for over five years. She sells all kinds of products, even though, at times, it is not so easy to satisfy her customers. In spite of that, she has been able to get enough customers for her business. This money is to buy sweets, natural soft drink, bread, and crackers among other things.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Frida Bethsabell

texts.es:
FRIDA BETHSABELL PAUILINO R., de 39 años de edad, madre soltera, quien ha podido sacar adelante a sus hijos gracias a su esfuerzo y trabajo.

Dos de sus hijos aún viven con ella, son las personas que le dan fuerza y la animan a salir adelante y progresar para darles un buen ejemplo y un futuro mejor a sus hijos.

Ella desde hace varios años tiene un negocio de fuegos artificiales que prácticamente le toma todo el día y  el cual funciona en su casa, negocio que le ha permitido a parte de tener un ingreso para sustentar los gastos familiares, ha podido ahorrar y en enero de éste año pudo invertir en la compra de una combi el cual podrá hacer trabajar dando servicio de transporte.

El dinero que ha solicitado en ésta oportunidad es para  invertir una parte en instalar el sistema de gas a la combi, y el resto para invertirlo en la compra de materiales e insumos para su  negocio de fuegos artificiales.
texts.en:
Frida Bethsabell P. Rodríguez is a 39 year old single mother. Thanks to her effort and work she has been able to give her children a better future. Two of her children still live with her. They give her the strength and encouragement to keep going and make progress. She does this to give them a good example and to give her children a better future. For several years she has had a fireworks business. This takes her almost all day. The business is in her house, and it has allowed her to have income to pay for the family expenses. She has been able to save. In January of this year she was able to buy a “combi” (van), which she will be able to put to work providing public transportation. She will use part of the money she has asked for to install a gas system in the van. She will buy materials and supplies for her fireworks business with the rest of the money.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Invest in her businesses

loans.name: Rosa Maria

texts.es: Rosa María D. V. tiene 59 años es una madre soltera. Tiene 3 hijos a su cargo por lo que tiene 2 responsabilidades actuar como Padre y Madre a la misma vez. Su actividad económica es la venta y elaboración de nacatamales. Hace más de 30 años que se dedica a este negocio. Cuando ella inicio esta actividad fue por medio de su Mama ya que apreciaba la necesidad que Rosa pasaba con sus hijos, el mayor desafío que enfrento fue aprender a proporcionarle el toque de sabor, pero con el tiempo se fue perfeccionando. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de masa, maíz, algunos utensilios de cocina y condimentos para la elaboración de sus nacatamales. En un futuro a Rosa le gustaría proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Rosa María D. V., 59, is a single mother. She has three dependent children. She has two responsibilities, to act as both mother and father at the same time. She makes and sells “nacatamales” (a traditional Central American dish similar to tamale). She has been doing this for over 30 years. Her mother got her started in this activity because she saw the needs that Rosa’s children had. The biggest difficulty she faced was leaning to master the seasoning. But, in time, she perfected her seasoning. The loan is for working capital to buy dough, corn, and some cooking utensils and condiments for making her nacatamales. In the future, Rosa would like to make some improvements on her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Francisca

texts.es: La Señora Francisca E. S. es Madre de 1 hijo. Ella tiene 54 años de edad. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es una pulpería. Hace más de 17 años que se dedica a este negocio, ella dio inicio a su negocio por medio de una amiga. Pero Francisca no tenía el suficiente capital para dedicarse a este negocio, pero ella no desistió de su idea y fue por una amiga que le brindo la facilidad de prestarle el dinero y comenzó con granos básicos y golosinas, la mayoría de sus vecinos les gusta comprar en su pulpería porque la atención de Francisca es la mejor. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas en general, granos básicos, pan, galletas, jugos y refrescos naturales. Su mayor sueño es su pequeño hijo logre ser un profesional y le brinde la ayuda necesaria.
texts.en:
Francisca is the mother of one son. She is 54 years old.

The business she is engaged in is a grocery store. She had been involved in this business for more than 17 years. She got into the business through a friend. She didn’t have enough capital to start, but she didn’t give up her idea, and a friend offered to loan her money, and she began with basic grains and sweets. Most of her neighbors like to buy at her grocery store because the attentiveness from Francisca is the best.

The reason for this financing is working capital for the purchase of sweets, basic grains, crackers, juices, and natural beverages. Her biggest dream is that her little son succeeds in being a professional and that she can offer him the necessary help.

Translated from Spanish by Richard Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Maria De Los Angeles

texts.es: María de los Ángeles Martínez es una mujer casada tiene 4 hijos  a su cargo. La actividad económica a la que se dedica es venta de abarrotería. Hace más de 10 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ya que con mucho esfuerzo ha logrado obtener esta actividad. María es  una mujer muy responsable y que disfruta de interactuar con sus clientes. Por lo que muchas veces sus vecinos recurren a ella para ciertos consejos. El dinero que solicita será destinado para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas, granos básicos, pan, jugos y refrescos naturales. En un futuro ella desea proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda ya que esto será para sus hijos y que el día de mañana no tengan necesidad de un techo digno donde vivir.
texts.en:
María de los Ángeles Martínez is married with 4 children in her care. She dedicates herself to the sale of groceries. She has devoted herself to this business for more than 10 years. She has maintained this activity with great effort. María is a very responsible woman and enjoys interacting with her customers. Thus, many times her neigbors come to her for certain advice. The loan she is requesting will be used for working capital to purchase candy, basic grains, bread, juice and natural soft drinks. In the future, María wants to make improvements to her home to benefit her children, and so that in the future they will not want for a dignified home.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.es: Rosa Argentina P. Chávez tiene la edad de 50 años. Es una mujer casada. Tiene 3 hijos a su cargo que dependen de ella. Rosa tiene la actividad económica de es la elaboración de cepillos, pastes de baño. Ella solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo e invertir en la compra de hilo, esponja, retazos, cloro entre otras cosas. Rosa es una excelente cliente ya que siempre le ha gustado trabajar con Fundación León 2000. Es una mujer muy responsable porque en varias ocasiones siempre le ha gustado pagar con puntualidad. El sueño que siempre le gustaría cumplir es obtener su propia casa, para tener algo que sea realmente propio.
texts.en:
Rosa Argentina P. Chávez is 50 years old. She is married, and has 3 dependent children. Rosa's economic activity is the manufacture of bath brushes and scrubbers. Rosa is requesting this loan for working capital to invest in the purchase of thread, sponges, fragments and chlorine among other things. Rosa is an excellent client since she has always enjoyed working with Fundación León 2000. She is a responsible woman who has always made her payments on time. Her dream is to obtain her own home, in order to have something that is really her own.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Ampliación Villa El Polvorin Group

texts.es:
GUILLERMO M. A.; recién elegido Presidente de la ALCOM “Ampliación Villa El Polvorin” en reconocimiento a su entusiasmo y progreso, se integró a éste grupo hace aproximadamente un año.

El Sr. M. tiene 26 años de edad, es soltero pero convive con su pareja y tiene un hijo pequeño de 2 años 8 meses. Tienen un Taller de Metal, el cual ha ido creciendo poco a poco, desde que iniciaron con muy poco capital comprando matrices y maquinas con el dinero que ahorraban. 
Gracias a su esfuerzo y el apoyo de su pareja quien se dedica a las labores de la casa y el cuidado de su hijo, el negocio ha podido progresar y a la vez incursionar en el negocio de la venta de ropa, en Arequipa en un local de propiedad de su hermana y en Moquegua participando en diferentes ferias.

El dinero solicitado lo destinará en la compra de más ropa para la venta en provincias.

Ellos dedican todo su esfuerzo y trabajo a tiempo completo teniendo como su meta más próxima el terminar de construir su casa.
texts.en:
GUILLERMO M. A., recently elected President of ALCOM “Polvorin Village Extension” in recognition of his enthusiasm and progress, joined this group about a year ago. Sr. M. is 26 years old and single, but he lives with his girlfriend and their small child of 2 years 8 months. He has a Metal Shop, which has been growing little by little since he started buying matrices and machines with very little capital with the money he had saved. Thanks to his efforts and the support of his girlfriend, who devotes herself to the household chores and caring for their child, Sr. M. has been able to progress in his business. At the same time, he has been able to invest in a clothing sales business in Arequipa, in a site owned by his sister, and in Moquegua participating in various markets. The loan Sr. M. is requesting will be used to purchase more clothing for sale in the provinces. Sr. M. and his girlfriend devote all their effort and toward completing the task of constructing their home.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To invest in a new business

loans.name: Vidaldina

texts.es: Vildaldina R. Hernández tiene 3 hijos. Su edad es de 41 años. Su negocio dio inicio hace 15 años, porque empezó vendiendo ropa en su vivienda y además algunas veces transportaba en una canasta calcetines, ropa interior, camisetas y camisolas. Y posteriormente logro conseguir algo de dinero prestado, y así incrementar su inventario para ofrecer a sus clientes. Y así fue como poco a poco con interés y con mucho esfuerzo logro proporcionarle a su negocio una amplia variedad de productos. Es por esto que Vildaldina solicita este financiamiento para capital de trabajo para la compra de camisetas, pantalones, ropa interior, camisolas. Por lo que todos los esfuerzos que realiza son para proporcionarle a sus hijos una educación por medio de este digno trabajo.
texts.en:
Vildaldina R. Hernández is 41 years old and has 3 children. She started her business 15 years ago when she began selling clothing from her home. Sometimes she also transported undergarments, undershirts and camisoles in a basket. She has received one previous loan, with which she increased the inventory she was able to offer to her customers. In this way, little by little, with interest and much effort, Vildaldina was able to add a large variety of products to her business. For this reason, Vildaldina is asking for a loan for working capital to purchase shirts, pants, undergarments and camisoles. The goal of all her efforts is to provide her children with an education through her dignified work.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Griselda De Los Angeles

texts.es: Griselda S. tiene 42 años de edad es madre soltera tiene 2 hijos una de la edad 23 y 21 anos uno depende de ella está cursando su segundo año de la universidad.  El modo de sobrevivir es una pulpería en donde ofrece granos básicos, leche, pollos y lo que tenga que ver con productos en una pulpería. Hace dos anos inicio con capital propio ya que ella trabajaba en costa rica como domestica hasta que decidió regresar a Nicaragua a poner un Negocio. Su sueño es poder lograr expandirse tanto como pueda, para poder tener más  surtida su venta. Y ofrecer más productos. Su mayor deseo es quedarse con este negocio y obtener  prosperidad.
texts.en:
Griselda S. is 42 years old and the single mother of 2 children, ages 23 and 21. One still depends on her as she is in her second year at the university. Griselda makes her living with a small grocery store where she offers basic grains, milk, chickens and other products that are to be found in a grocery store. Griselda started two years ago with her own capital, which she earned working as a maid in Costa Rica before she decided to return to Nicaragua to start a business. Her dream is to be able to expand as much as possible, to be able to stock more products for sale and offer more items. Her greatest wish is to stay in business and be prosperous.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: working capital

loans.name: Norlan Yuran

texts.es: El joven Nolan Yuran O. C. tiene 25 años de edad. El se dedica a la venta de ropa. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. A pesar de su corta edad es un joven muy emprendedor y trabajador. El capital con que inicio fue con muy poco dinero, y decide recorrer muchos lugares para ofrecer sus productos. Pero Nolan enfrento dificultades porque no tuvo la oportunidad de estudiar, además el vive con su Mama y  se enfermo y es Nolan quien la cuidaba, por lo que algunas veces tenía que cerrar su pulpería para atender su Mama.  El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de golosinas en general, pan, granos básicos, refrescos naturales y jugos.
texts.en:
Young Nolan Yuran O. C. is 25 years old. He sells clothing. More than five years ago he began this business. Despite his young age, he is a very dedicated and industrious worker. He started his business with very little capital, so he decided to visit various locations to offer his wares. But Nolan faced challenges because he did not have the opportunity to study. He lives with and takes care of his sick mother, which requires him to close his store sometimes so that he can care for his mother. The loan he is requesting is for business capital to purchase basic snacks, bread, basic grains, natural drinks and juices.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: Orlando

texts.es: Orlando V. R. tiene 50 años. Su actividad económica es mercadería en general. Hace más de 7 años que se dedica a este negocio Orlando se hace cargo de 2 hijas. Este negocio surge por la esposa de Orlando ya que no tenía un trabajo para generar a su familia los ingresos necesarios, y con la ayuda de de su esposa aprendió este negocio. Y así decide aportar cierta ayuda a su familia y aportar lo necesario para su familia. El motivo del financiamiento es para capital de trabajo para la compra de ropa para caballeros, ropa para niños, calzado y bolsos. Su mayor sueño es cumplir con la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Orlando V. R. is 50 years old. His work is in sales of general merchandise. More than 7 years since Orlando began this business he care for 2 daughters. This business moves forward because of Orlando's wife. He was without work to generate the family income they needed, and with the help of his wife he learned the business. As such he decided to provide some assistance to his family and give them what they need. The loan will be used as business capital to buy men's and children's clothing, shoes, and handbags. His dream is to meet the needs of his customers.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Jung, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Business capital

loans.name: Luisa Diliana

texts.es: Luisa Diliana M. tiene 37 años. Esta Señora es muy trabajadora, su espíritu de alegría es envidiable. Su actividad económica es una pulpería. Hace más de 5 años que se dedica a este negocio. Ella empieza vendiendo ciertos productos como golosinas en general, ya que ella es Madre y Padre para sus 2 hijos, y así proporcionarle lo necesario. Y decide ofrecer los productos de golosinas y refrescos naturales. El financiamiento que solicita es para capital de trabajo para la compra de pan, jugos, refrescos naturales, golosinas. Su mayor sueño es que sus hijos se preparen para que sean personas de bien.
texts.en:
Luisa Diliana M. is 37 years old. This Lady is very hard-working. Her spirit of happiness is enviable. Her economic activity is a store. She has been dedicated to this business for over 5 years. She began selling certain products such as sweets in general, since she is both mother and father for her 2 children, and in this way she could provide them with necessities. Then she decided to offer both sweets and natural refreshments. The financing that she requests is for working capital for the purchase of bread, juices, natural refreshments, and sweets. Her greatest dream is that her children are prepared to become good persons.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy bread, juices, natural refreshments and sweets for resale.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria moved with her husband to the United States from Venezuela five years ago.  Their adult son was already living in South Florida and had started a business.  He employed his father and the two of them took care of the household expenses and Maria’s bills.  

Despite their support, Maria wanted to contribute to the household finances and keep herself busy. She was always been good at sewing. Two years ago, little by little, she started to develop a small clientèle that used her services for clothing alterations. She was proud of her small business, but her sewing machine started to fail due to overuse.  

Maria learned about ACCION USA’s lending program and applied for a loan to buy two new sewing machines.  With this loan, Maria was able to invest in her business, and also establish a credit history. She paid her loan off perfectly and would now like a larger loan to make additional investments in her business.  

A local factory wants to contract for her services, which would proviD. her with consistent work. Another business owner, who currently imports bathing suits, wants Maria to hand-make the swimwear for them. In order to sign these contracts, Maria would need an embroidery machine and a digital sewing machine to create her own designs. She will also need to purchase more inventory to maintain a more sizeable stock. For example, now, if she doesn't have the right color zipper, she has to take the bus downtown, incurring a $4 round-trip fare and more than 2 hours of her time.  

Currently, Maria works in her quaint, one-bedroom apartment in Miami Beach. She hopes to be able to expand her business so she can rent a modest storefront where her customers can stop by and drop off items that need to be mended.  

She is a very friendly person who always has a smile on her face. She loves to visit with people and to get to know her regular customers. In her own space, she can welcome clients and, hopefully, hire a helper, too.

loans.use: An embroidery machine, digital sewing machine, inventory

loans.name: United For Progress Group

texts.es:
Señor Fernando G.  entusiasta y emprendedor tiene 27 años D. edad, conviviente, tiene 2 hijos que son el motivo D. su vida, Fernando es chofer D. transporte publico desD. hace 5 años. 
Trabaja con EDAPROSPO – Prosperidad  hace 8 meses actualmente asume el cargo D. presidente D. L. alcancía comunal “Unión por el Progreso” conformado por 10 socios, quienes realizan diversas actividades como: venta D. verduras, venta D. golosinas en forma ambulante y otros. 
Fernando y su esposa cuentan con una pequeña bodega “YULISSA” ubicada  en L. zona alta y agreste D. Huaycan, con L. cual desD. hace 8 años abastece  a sus clientes principalmente en los productos D. primera necesidad.
El  préstamo D. S/ 500.00 Nuevos Soles,  lo invertirá  en L. compra D.  mercadería como arroz, azúcar, leche y otros.
Fernando en el futuro anheL. hacer  crecer su bodega y también le gustaría comprarse un carro D. transporte público.
texts.en:
Señor Fernando G., enthusiastic and enterprising, is 27 years old, and has two children who are his reason for living. Fernando has been a taxi cab driver for 5 years. Fernando has worked with EDAPROSPO – Prosperity for 8 months. Currently, he is President of the community group "United for Progress", maD. up of 10 members who take part in various activities, such as the sale of vegetables and sweets door to door, and others. Fernando and his wife have a small bodega “YULISSA” located in the high and rural area of Huaycan. For 8 years they have provided their customers principally with staple needs. This loan of S/ 500.00 Nuevos Soles will be invested in the purchase of merchandise like corn, sugar, milk, etc. Fernando hopes to grow his bodega in the future, and would also like to purchase his own taxi cab.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice, sugar, milk, etc.

loans.name: Dolores

texts.es:
Dolores es una señora casada con 3 hijos, ella nació en Jaramijo provincia de Manabí un cantón a orillas de las aguas del pacífico, el esposo años atrás se dedicaba a la pesca en alta mar, pero con el tiempo decide cambiar de ocupación y en los actuales momentos él es chofer.
 Dolores comentó que cuando el esposo salía en su lancha a pescar  para ella era un gran sufrimiento ya que arriesgaba la vida, pero ahora esta un poco tranquila ya que así lo  tiene mas cerca y puede compartir con la familia.
Ella es una mujer muy luchadora le encanta trabajar dedicarse de lleno  a la ayuda del hogar, por ello le gustan los grandes desafíos y decide tomar un espacio en su propia casa para montar un pequeño negocio.

Desde el punto vista positivo, ella toma la decisión de invertir una pequeña cantidad de dinero en su propio negocio que consiste en la venta de repuestos y accesorios para motores  fuera de borda, y es que en el lugar donde ella vive la mayoría de las persona viven de la pesca, en su localidad son muy pocos los lugares donde pueden encontrar estos respuestas.

Emocionada comenta que desde hace 8 meses viene dedicada a esta ocupación y manifiesta que le esta yendo muy bien, de lo poco que ella gana lo invierte surtiendo su negocio con bujías, bombas de agua, arrancadores y mas.

Al preguntarle que le motivo para solicitar un préstamo, ella nos respondió…´´ aspiro con ese dinero ampliar mi negocio e invertir en comprar más repuestos Y poder hacer realidad el sueño de ver mis hijos realizados que estudien y se preparen ´´ acotó.
texts.en:
Dolores is a married woman with three children. She was born in the Jaramijo province of Manabí, a county on the banks of the Pacific Ocean. Years ago, Dolores' husband was a fisherman, but he later decided to change his occupation and currently is a driver.

Dolores told us that when her husband left on a fishing trip she suffered greatly knowing that he was risking his life, but now she is calmer because he works nearby and shares in their family life.

Dolores is a hard worker, and loves to devote herself completely to helping out at home, but she also enjoys great challenges and decided to use some space in her home to start a small business.

From a positive point of view, Dolores made the decision to invest a small amount of money into her own business, which consists of the sale of spare tires and after market automotive accessories. Since, in the place where Dolores lives, most people make their living from fishing, there are very few places where one can find these spare tires.

Dolores emotionally tells us that since she started this business 8 months ago, it has been going very well. The little money she has made so far, she has reinvested in her business, purchasing headlights, water pumps, starters and more.

When asked about her motives for requesting a loan, Dolores responded, " I hope that with this money I can increase my business and invest in more spare parts. I want to realize my dream to see my children study and be prepared."

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase spare tires, headlights, water pumps, starters

loans.name: Maria Agustina

texts.es:
La señora Agustina es socia del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte, un grupo de 21 mujeres que residen en el pueblo de Rocafuerte, aproximadamente media hora de la ciudad de Portoviejo. La ciudad es muy conocida por los dulces que vende. El grupo Rocafuerte es muy unido, y las señoras se llevan muy bien entre ellas. El día de nuestra entrevista con Sra. Agustina era el cumpleaños de una de las socias, por eso sirvieron unos bocaditos y cada socia aportó un poco de dinero para regalarla. 

Sra. Agustina tiene 46 años y vive en unión libre con su pareja, con quien tiene 2 hijas pequeñas de 8 y 5 años. Ella tiene un comedor estilo cafetín en su casa, un negocio que abrió hace unos meses atrás. Vende tortillas y pan de almidón todas las tardes entre las 2pm y las 7pm, además sirve almuerzos los días domingo. Antes criaba pollos, pero decidió cambiar de negocios y hasta ahora le está yendo muy bien, algunos días hasta se le agota todo lo que puede producir. Ella vive en un lugar bastante transitado cerca de un paradero de buses, y desde que sacó sus hornos a la calle empezaron a venir mayor clientela, atraída por los olores y lo que veía. Ella dice que aprendió a cocinar adivinando no más, nadie le enseño formalmente.

Sra. Agustina está pidiendo un crédito a la Fundación ESPOIR para comprar mesas y sillas para así incrementar a su negocio. También está pensando comprar otro horno para poder producir más, el cual le sale $140 al contado o $180 a plazos. 

Dice que tiene muchos sueños para el futuro, pero el mayor de ellos es hacer su propia casa (actualmente ella y su familia están viviendo en la casa de su suegra). Sus hijas ya están creciendo y ellas quieren una casa propia, ya le están hablando de comprar los muebles.
texts.en:
Señora Agustina is a client of the Community Bank Rocafuerte, a group of 21 women who live in the town of Rocafuerte, approximately half an hour from the city of Portoviejo. The city is well known for the sweets sold there. The Rocafuerte group is very united, and the women get along very well with each other. The day we interviewed Sra. Agustina it was the birthday of one of the members, so some snacks were served, and each woman chipped in some money for a gift.

Sra. Agustina is 46 years old and lives with her two small children (8 and 5 years) and their father. She has a cafe style dining room in her home, a business she opened two months ago. She sells cakes and starch bread each afternoon between 2pm and 7pm, in addition to serving lunch on Sundays. Agustina previously raised chickens,but decided to change businesses, and so far this has been going very well. Some days she sells everything she can produce. Agustina lives in a well-travelled area near a bus stop, and since she moved her ovens outside she has had many more customers, brought in by the smells and sights. She says she learned to cook by guessing, as no one every formally taught her.

Sra. Agustina is asking for a loan from the Fundación ESPOIR to buy tables and chairs to expand her business. She is also thinking of buying another oven in order to produce more, and this costs $140 cash or $180 in payments.

Sra. Agustina says that she has many dreams for the future, but the greatest is to have her own home (currently she and her family live in the home of her mother-in-law). Her children are growing, and they want their own home. They are already talking about buying the furniture.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Novesky, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase tables and chairs to increase business.

loans.name: Fidencia Del Pilar

texts.es:
La señora Pilar es socia del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte, un grupo de 21 mujeres que residen en el pueblo de Rocafuerte, aproximadamente media hora de la ciudad de Portoviejo. La ciudad es muy conocida por los dulces que vende. El grupo Rocafuerte es muy unido, y las señoras se llevan muy bien entre ellas. El día de nuestra entrevista con Sra. Pilar era el cumpleaños de una de las socias, por eso sirvieron unos bocaditos y cada socia aportó un poco de dinero para regalarla. 

Sra. Pilar tiene 56 años, es viuda, y tiene 5 hijos, todos ya son mayores con familias propias. Ella tiene 10 nietos, y dice que unos 4 más ya vienen en camino. Ella se dedica a la venta de queso, maní y longaniza desde su misma casa. Entrega sus productos a domicilios y también a instituciones; ya lleva 15 años con este negocio. El queso lo compra de su hijo, que vende queso al por mayor. Los precios cambian un poco de día a día, pero normalmente lo compra a $1.30 la libra y lo revende a $1.60 la libra. Vende entre 80 y 100 libras de queso cada semana. Dice que este negocio le ha servido bastante desde que murió su esposo, porque así tiene ingresos para pagar sus necesidades y los gastos del hogar (la luz, el teléfono, etc.).

Sra. Pilar está pidiendo un crédito a fundación Espoir para invertir poco a poco en la compra de quesos. Dice que tiene muchos sueños y proyectos para el futuro.
texts.en:
Pilar is a member of the Rocafuerte Community Bank. The group has 21 members who live in the town of Rocafuerte, which is approximately a half hour from the city of Portoviejo. The city is very well known for the sweets they sell. The Rocafuerte group is very united, and the women get along very well with each other. The day of our interview with Pilar was one of the member’s birthdays. They served snacks, and each member gave a small amount of money to give her as a gift. Pilar is a 56 year old widow. She has five grown children, and they have their own families. She has ten grandchildren, and four more are on the way. She sells cheese, peanuts, and spicy sausages from her home. She delivers her products to homes and also to institutions. She has had the business for 15 years. She buys the cheese from her son, who sells it wholesale. The prices change a little day to day, but she normally buys for $1.30 a pound. She sells it for $1.60 a pound. She sells between 80 and 100 pounds each week. This business has served her well since her husband died. She has income to pay for her necessities and for the household expenses (light, telephone, etc.). Pilar is asking the Fundación Espoir for a loan to spend little by little buying cheese. She has many dreams and projects for the future.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy cheese, peanuts, and spicy sausages to sell

loans.name: Petita Jacoba

texts.es:
Sra. Petita tiene 39 años, es casada, y tiene 3 hijos pequeños de 8 y 5 años más un bebé de 2 meses. Ella trabaja como comerciante, vendiendo artículos para el hogar a crédito de casa en casa. Por ejemplo, vende sábanas, plásticos, y cubrecamas. Lleva ya 10 años con este trabajo, su esposo ya trabajaba en eso cuando se conocieron, entonces ella decidió acompañarle con su trabajo. Ellos viajan dentro de la región de Manabí para hacer sus ventas, por lo general venden en lugares que quedan a una hora de Jipijapa como Portoviejo y Manta. Venden más que nada a gente conocida; sus clientes pagan cuotas semanales. 

Sra. Petita está pidiendo un crédito para poder comprar más mercadería surtida al por mayor. Dice que para el futuro le gustaría tener una buena situación económica y un carrito, pero lo ve algo difícil con la situación actual de la economía mundial. Han bajado sus ventas en este último tiempo. Ella está pensando en cambiar de negocio en algún momento en el futuro. Su esposo también es ebanista, entonces a ella le gustaría poner un negocio de carpintería. Piensa que este negocio sería más estable, y además le daría la oportunidad de estar más cerca de sus hijos (actualmente una prima les cuida cuando ella sale a vender). 

La señora es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes, el cual se reúne cada 2 semanas en Jipijapa, Manabí, cerca de la costa ecuatoriana. Es un grupo grande que ya tiene bastante tiempo trabajando con la fundación, las socias se llevan muy bien entre ellas. Sra. Petita lleva 3 años trabajando con su banco comunal, y dice que le gusta porque hay pocos lugares que dan dinero con la misma facilidad, sin pedir muchas garantías ni muchos papeles. Lo importante es ser responsable, dice ella.
texts.en:
Señora Petita is 39 years old. She is married, and has 3 small children, an 8-year-old, a 5-year-old, and a 2-month-old baby. She works as a salesperson, selling items for the home on credit from door to door. For example, she sells sheets, bedspreads and plastic bed covers. She has been doing this job for 10 years. Her husband already was in this line of work when they met, and she decided to accompany him on his job. They travel within the Manabí region to make their sales, generally selling in places that lie about one hour from Jipijapa, such as Portoviejo and Manta. Most of the time, they sell their items to familiar customers, and their customers pay them for the goods in weekly installments. Señora Petita is requesting a loan in order to be able to buy a variety of more merchandise at wholesale. She says that for the future she would like to have a good economic foundation and a little car, although she does see the difficulty of achieving success within the world's current economic situation. Her sales have dropped recently, and she is considering changing her business sometime in the near future. Her husband is also a cabinet-maker, and she would like run a carpentry business with him. She thinks that such a business would be more stable, and would give them the chance to remain closer to their children as well (a cousin watches over them when she and her husband go out to sell). Señora Petita is a member of the Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes, which meets every 2 weeks in Jipijapa, Manabí, near the Ecuadorian coast. Her bank is a large group that has worked many times with Fundación ESPOIR, and whose members support each other very well. Señora Petita has spent 3 years working with her communal bank, and says that she likes it because ther are few places that are able to provide her with money so easily, without demanding excessive guarantees or paperwork. The important thing, Señora Petita says, is to be responsible.

Translated from Spanish by Kevin Lenhart, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Comprar más mercadería surtida al por mayor

loans.name: Martha Del Pilar

texts.es:
Casada de 37años de edad, madre de tres niños ama de casa, una esposa abnegada comparte el trabajo con su esposo.
Ella y su esposo  dedican su tiempo desde muy temprano a las 3:00 am  ya están de pie en su panificadora situada en el centro de la ciudad de Jipijapa localizada en la provincia de Manabí.

Todos los días ellos desde su casa emprenden la tarea de hornear 400 panes entre sal y dulce, una vez que están saliditos del horno el esposo empieza su recorrido a las 5:00 am   entregando de casa en casa los pedidos de sus clientes, sin duda es una tarea que  requiere de mucha dedicación puesto que la meta de ellos es vender todos los panes que ese día han salido del horno, de lo contrario lo que quede sin vender lo comparten con la familia porque una de las reglas de estos panificadores es que al día siguiente que vuelve la jornada trabajo, la masa(harina) sea fresca ellos nunca han vendido panes del día anterior consideran que eso sería dañar su negocio, perderían clientela.

Martha considera que en estos cuatro años que tienen en el negocio han obtenido grandes satisfacciones dentro del hogar, ya que así han podido estar unidos en familia, también nos comentó que con su trabajo  han podido brindar el estudio a sus hijos, por ello lo que desea ahora es seguir implementando su panificadora e invertir el dinero del préstamo en materia prima como: manteca, harina, azúcar, entre otros productos necesarios.
texts.en:
Martha is married and is 37 years old. She is the mother of three children, is a housewife, and is a selfless wife, who works with her husband. She and her husband have a bakery located in the center of the city of Jipijapa in the province of Manabí, and they start working very early in the morning, at 3:00 am. Everyday, they start baking 400 loaves of salty and sweet bread. Once the bread is out of the oven at 5:00 am, her husband begins delivering bread to the houses of their clients to fill their orders. Without a doubt, this is work that requires a lot of dedication because their goal is to sell all of the bread that is produced that day. What is not sold during the day is shared with their family because one of the rules for these bakeries is that the next day, the flour must the fresh. They have never sold day-old bread, since doing this would harm their business. Martha thinks that in the four years that they have had this business, their family has gotten many benefits, because they have been able to work together as a family. She also said that with their work, they have been able to offer an education to their children. Now, she wants to continue implementing her bakery and invest the money from the loan on raw materials, such as butter, flour, and sugar, among other necessary products.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy butter, flour and sugar to make bread

loans.name: Astromelia Auxiliadora

texts.es:
La señora Astromelia es socia del Banco Comunal Rocafuerte, un grupo de 21 mujeres que residen en el pueblo de Rocafuerte, aproximadamente media hora de la ciudad de Portoviejo. La ciudad es muy conocida por los dulces que vende. El grupo Rocafuerte es muy unido, y las señoras se llevan muy bien entre ellas. El día de nuestra entrevista con Sra. Astromelia era el cumpleaños de una de las socias, por eso sirvieron unos bocaditos y cada socia aportó un poco de dinero para regalarla. 

Sra. Astromelia tiene 44 años, es casada, y tiene 4 hijos, de los cuales 2 son mayores de edad y 2 son menores (de 15 y 16 años). 3 de ellos viven con ella todavía. Ella y su esposo tienen un estudio de fotografía, llamado “Estudio Arely’s” por su hija, Arely. Su esposo también trabaja como profesor, entonces ella atiende el negocio durante la semana mientras él está en clases. Su hija también les ayuda con el negocio. Iniciaron el negocio porque el sueldo de su marido no les alcanzaba para pagar sus necesidades básicas, y a ella no le gustaba mucho al inicio, pero ahora sí le gusta, aunque dice que siempre llega muy cansada a la casa al fin del día. Trabajan todo tipo de eventos, como por ejemplo matrimonios y cumpleaños, normalmente 1-2 por semana, y trabajan tanto con cámaras digitales como de rollos. 

La señora está pidiendo un crédito a la Fundación ESPOIR para invertir en la compra de materiales para su negocio, como por ejemplo papel, químicos, álbumes y una cámara. Dice que su sueño para el futuro es jubilarse para poder descansar, también está pensando en poner algun negocio en la misma casa para no tener que salir más de la casa para trabajar. 

Ella ha sido socia de su banco comunal para años ya, es socia fundadora y el banquito en sí es bastante antiguo, el grupo ya tiene 32 ciclos trabajando juntos. “Me ayudan bastante,” dice de los préstamos. Solamente una vez hace 4 años tuvo un problema para pagar su crédito, aparte de eso ha sido muy puntual.
texts.en:
Mrs. Astromelio is a member of the Rocafuerte Community Bank and is in a group of 21 women who live in the town of Rocafuerte, which is approximately half an hour from the city of Portoviejo. The city is very well-known for the sweets that it sells. The group Rocafuerte is very united, and the women get along very well. The day of the interview with Mrs. Astromelia was the birthday of one of the members, so they served snacks and every member contributed some money to give a gift. Mrs. Astromelia is 44 years old, is married, and has 4 children, of whom 2 are adults and 2 are younger (15 and 16 years old). Three of her children still live with her. She and her husband have a photography studio, called “Arely’s Studio,” after their daughter Arely. Her husband also works as a teacher, so she takes care of the business during the week while he is in classes. Her daughter also helps them with the business. They started the business because her husband’s salary isn’t enough for them to meet their basic needs. At first, she didn’t like the business very much, but now she enjoys it, even though she says that she is very tired when she comes home at the end of the day. They work at all kinds of events, like weddings and birthdays. They normally work once or twice a week, and they work with both digital cameras and cameras with film. She is asking for a loan from Fundación ESPOIR to invest in the purchase of materials for her business, like paper, chemicals, albums and a camera. She says that her dream for the future is to retire so that she can rest. She is also thinking about having some business in her own house so that she doesn’t have to leave home to work. She has been a member of the community bank for years. She is a founding member, and the bank is very experienced. The group has already worked together for 32 cycles. She says that the loans help her a lot. Only once, four years ago, she had a problem of repaying her loan, and apart from this, she has been very punctual.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy paper, chemicals, albums and a camera for her business

loans.name: Baltazara

texts.es:
La señora Baltazara P. tiene 37 años, es casada, y tiene 4 hijos: su hijo menor tiene 1 año y su hijo mayor tiene 18. Ella cultiva frutas, verduras, y también legumbres como papas y cebollas en su terreno. Ahora mismo  está por cosechar papas. Lleva toda la vida trabajando en eso, porque es un negocio familiar; sus padres también se dedican al trabajo de campo. Ella vive con sus papás y trabaja la chacra con ellos,  su hermano, su esposo y su hija mayor. 

Está pidiendo un crédito  para invertir en la compra de semillas de legumbres para cosechar el próximo año. Su meta para el futuro es comprar su propia casa para que sus hijos puedan vivir allá y criar a sus propios hijos algún día. 

La señora es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes, el cual se reúne cada 2 semanas en Jipijapa, Manabí, cerca de la costa ecuatoriana. Es un grupo grande que ya tiene bastante tiempo trabajando con la fundación, y las socias se llevan muy bien entre ellas. Sra. Baltazara lleva 4 años con la fundación. Unas amigas le trajeron al inicio, y le gustó el trabajo en banco comunal, entonces se quedó.
texts.en:
Mrs. Baltazara P. is 37 years old, is married, and has 4 children. Her youngest child is 1 year old, and her oldest child is 18 years old. She grows fruit, vegetables and legumes, like potatoes and onions on her land. Now she is harvesting potatoes. She has spent her whole life working on this because this is the family business. Her parents also work on the farm. She lives with her parents and works on the farm with them, her brother, her husband, and her older daughter. She is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of legume seeds to harvest next year. Her goal for the future is to buy her own house so that her children can live there and so that she can take care of her children someday. She is a member of the New Horizons (Nuevos Horizontes) Community Bank, which meets every two weeks in Jipijapa, Manabí, near the Ecuadorian coast. It is a big group that has already spent a lot of time working with the foundation, and the members get along with each other very well. Mrs. Baltazara has spent four years with the foundation. Some friends brought her to the foundation at the beginning, and she liked working in the community bank, so she stayed.

Translated from Spanish by Avni Shah, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy legume seeds

loans.name: Nancy Narcisa

texts.es:
La señora Nancy tiene 52 años, es casada, y tiene 5 hijos mayores, ya con sus propias familias. Tiene 12 nietos: 10 niños y 2 niñas. Ella tiene varios negocios pequeños: trabaja como costurera, vende queso, y compra y vende ropa y artículos para el hogar (baldes, tinas, sábanas, etc.). Trabaja en Jipijapa y también en Guayaquil; es costurera para una fábrica de plásticos industriales en Guayaquil, y confecciona ropa para muñecas. Tiene la facilidad de hacer el trabajo de dónde quiera, entonces por lo general trabaja desde su casa en Jipijapa, donde tiene varias máquinas de coser y viaja a Guayaquil para entregar los trabajos. Ya lleva 18 años trabajando en eso, y dice que le encanta la costura. También hace trabajos para particulares, más que nada ternos y vestidos para mujeres. Las ventas de queso hace de la siguiente forma: compra unos 50-70 libras de queso a la vez a $1.30 la libra, después lo divide en paquetes de 1 libra y lo revende a $1.80. 

Está pidiendo un crédito  para comprar más mercadería, sobre todo artículos para el hogar, como sábanas por docenas. Vende su mercadería a crédito. Su meta para el futuro es comprarse un terreno en Guayaquil y hacerse una casita para poder quedarse allá. 

La señora es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes, el cual se reúne cada 2 semanas en Jipijapa, Manabí, cerca de la costa ecuatoriana. Es un grupo grande que ya tiene bastante tiempo trabajando con la fundación, las socias se llevan muy bien entre ellas. Sra. Nancy lleva 3 ciclos con el banco comunal; había sido socia antiguamente, y decidió reingresar porque le habían robado una máquina de coser y quiso comprarse otra. Le gustó haber vuelto al banco comunal, y piensa quedarse como socia por un buen tiempo. Nunca ha tenido problemas serios para pagar sus deudas; a veces se ha atrasado un poco pero siempre paga el 100% de su préstamo al fin del ciclo.
texts.en:
Nancy is 52 years old, she is married, and has 5 adult children who have their own families. She has 12 grandchildren: 10 boys and 2 girls. She has several small businesses: she works as a seamstress, sells cheese, and buys and sells clothing and household items (buckets, washtubs, sheets, etc.). She works in Jipijapa and also in Guayaquil; she works as a seamstress for a plastics factory in Guayaquil and makes clothes for dolls. She can do the work wherever she likes, so she generally works from her house in Jipijapa, where she has several sewing machines. She travels to Guayaquil to deliver her work. She has been doing this for 18 years and she says she loves to sew. She also does work by request, mostly suits and dresses for women. She sells cheese in the following way: she buys around 50 to 70 pounds of cheese at once, at $1.30 per pound, and then divides it into one-pound packages which she re-sells at $1.80. She is requesting a loan to buy more merchandise, especially household items such as sheets by the dozen. She sells her merchandise on credit. Her goal for the future is buy a piece of land in Guayaquil and build a house so she can live there. Nancy is a member of the “Nuevos Horizontes” (New Horizons) communal bank, which meets every 2 weeks in Jipijapa, Manabí, near the Ecuadorian coast. It is a big group because it has been working with the foundation for a long time. The members get along together very well. Nancy has been with the communal bank for three loan cycles; she had been a member previously, and she decided to participate again because someone stole one of her sewing machines and she wanted to buy another one. She is glad she came back to the communal bank and she plans to remain a member for a long time. She has never had serious problems in repaying her debts; a few times she has gotten a little behind, but she always pays 100% of her loan by the end of the loan cycle.

Translated from Spanish by Jennifer Day, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For the purchase of more merchandise, especially household items, such as sheets by the dozen.

loans.name: Flor Maria

texts.es:
La señora Flor Maria tiene 47 años, es casada, y tiene 3 hijos y 2 nietos. Dos de ellos ya son casados, mientras su hija es soltera todavía; su hija soltera y uno de sus hijos casados viven con ella. Su esposo trabaja como electricista de manera independiente. La señora es socia del Banco Comunal Nuevos Horizontes, el cual se reúne cada 2 semanas en Jipijapa, Manabí, cerca de la costa ecuatoriana. Es un grupo grande que ya tiene bastante tiempo trabajando con la fundación, las socias se llevan muy bien entre ellas. La sra. Flor Maria ya lleva 6 años como parte de su banco comunal, y dice que le gusta porque viene a las reuniones para conversar, y los préstamos le ayudan para financiar su pequeño negocio de crianza de pollos.

La Sra. Flor Maria tiene una pequeña tienda donde vende una variedad de productos como jugos, caramelos, camarones, pescado fileteado y pollo; los pollos son los mismos que ella cría en su casa. Su tienda queda a unas 4 cuadras de la iglesia en el mismo centro de Jipijapa, y ya tiene 3 o 4 años de antigüedad; lo puso después de que ya había criado a sus tres hijos. Empezó vendiendo pollos, y vio la posibilidad de expandir y empezar a vender otros productos también entonces aprovechó la oportunidad. Cuando eran pequeños, sus hijos le ayudaban a criar los pollos en la casa, “Son come-pollos,” dice ella, riendo. Los pollos que cría son gallinas criollas, es decir que se crían afuera (en este caso en su terraza) con alimentos naturales y sin hormonas. A pesar de que son de mejor calidad y son más sabrosas estas gallinas, la señora también vende la carne más barata, usualmente a 5 centavos menos que en otras tiendas. 

Está pidiendo un préstamo de  para la compra de pollos pequeños. Una caja de 100 pollos cuesta $60. También comprará los alimentos para sus pollos. 

Ella está por graduarse como ingeniera de alimentos, y está escribiendo su tesis sobre el uso de la harina de maíz para hacer tortillas para los tacos mexicanos. Está pensando en empezar a vender tacos desde su tienda como otra fuente de ingresos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Flor Maria is 47 years old, married, and has 3 children and 2 grandchildren. Two of her children are married while one of her daughters is still single; her single daughter and one of her married children live with her. Her husband works as an independent electrician.

She is a member of the village bank "New Horizons," which meets every 2 weeks in Jipijapa, Manabí, close to the Ecuadorian coast. It is a large group that has been working with the foundation for a long time and the members get along well with each other. Flor Maria has been a part of the village bank for 6 years and says that she enjoys it because she goes to the meetings to chat and to ask for loans to finance her small business raising chickens.

Flor Maria has a small store where she sells a variety of products like juice, sweets, shrimp, fish fillets and chicken that she raises in her house. Her shop is four blocks from the church in the heart of Jipijapa. The shop is 3 or 4 years old; she started it after she was done raising her three children. She started selling chickens and when she saw the possibility to expand and start selling other products she took the opportunity. When they were small her children helped her to raise chickens at their home; "They're chicken-eaters," she says, laughing. The chickens she raises are a variety known as "criolla" (Creole) and she raises them outside on her terrace with natural foods and without hormones. Although they are of the best quality and very flavorful, she also sells the meat at a cheaper price, usually 5 centavos lower than at other stores.

She is asking for a loan to buy chicks. A box of a hundred chicks costs $60. She will also buy food for her chickens.

She is graduating as a food engineer and is writing her thesis about the use of corn flour in making tortillas for Mexican tacos. She is thinking about starting to sell tacos from her store as another source of income.

Translated from Spanish by Cathy Coffman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying chicks and food for raising chickens

loans.name: Danilo

texts.en:
Danilo S., age 47, is a rice grower from Bunawan, Agusan Del Sur. He is the father of three children, and his only ambition is to have all his children graduate from college and improve their lives. He started farming when he was a small child. Now, he has a farm because his parents gave him one when he decided to marry his wife, Angelita S..

He would like to ask for a loan of 15,000 PHP so that he can buy the fertilizer, rice seed, and chemicals that he needs for his farm. He hopes that this will bring good profits in his farm business.

CEVI helps Danilo sustain his farm. In addition to loans, CEVI also provides training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase complete fertilizer, rice seed and chemicals

loans.name: Josie

texts.en:
Josie F. is 38 years old and the mother of two children ages eight and seven years old. Since she married her husband, Tito, her consciousness has been raised about her productive role, aside from her reproductive role. Their only income was what her husband earned as a mechanic, an income that was not enough to cover the family's daily expenses, especially higher education for the children.

Thus, she made a decision for herself and it was supported by her husband. She became a member of ASHI in 2007 to take a loan to start her own business -- a business that is very familiar to her and that she had grown up with -- a rice planting and production business. 

Many people in Josie's village own farmland through inheritance. However, for many reasons, these people do not to use the land for farming. Others have no farming expertise and would rather convert agricultural land to commercial purposes and build commercial buildings. Sometimes, people don't have enough money to finance ah agricultural business. 

Josie had a loan from ASHI to finance the business, but she doesn't have land of her own. To pursue her business, she rented land to plant rice. After receiving and repaying two loans from ASHI, Josie is now qualified for a larger loan amount. She plans to use the loans to enlarge her rice field until she can buy her own land.

loans.use: Buying rice seedlings, fertilizer, pesticide, and for labor fees.

loans.name: Annabelle

texts.en:
Annabelle O. is the wife of a fisherman. The two have three children ranging in age from eight to three years old. Anabelle is 32 years old and lives with her family in a distant village in the province of Antique surrounded by the sea and mountains. 

People in their village do not go to market very often, because they try to avoid spending too much on transportation. Instead, people put up mini variety stores that sell basic necessities to fellow villagers. Each one tries to offer convenience to each family in their village. 

Annabelle has her own business. She cooks and sells noodle soup. She also sells fish that her husband catches from the ocean. Since she started her business in 2006, she realized that food is the most salable product in their village. When she joined ASHI in 2007, she used the loan she received to finance the business she had started. Because she had demonstrated to ASHI her good performance in repayment, attendance and business, she qualifies for larger loans. Now she wants to buy her husband a fishing boat of his own to catch more fish so she can sell more fish. 

Annabelle wishes that, someday, she can purchase more fishing boats to have more fish to sell throughout the municipality, not just in their village. She wishes that she can give her children a good life, bring out her children of poverty, and send them to college.

loans.use: To buy the materials needed for a fishing boat .

loans.name: Leonarda

texts.en:
Leonarda C. is from the village of Waterfall, Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 49 years old. Leonarda is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Leonarda owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells ready-to-wear items, cellphone accesories, and electronic load in the local community. Leonarda has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2008, Leonarda joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonarda has successfully repaid a previous loan of 14000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional products to sell. Leonarda is requesting a new loan of 16000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be Leonarda's 5th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to sell

loans.name: Antonio

texts.en:
Antonio M., age 34, grows rice. When he is not busy on his farm, he works as a carpenter. He builds most of the concrete houses in Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. He also makes furniture. He has two children. He dream of providing a better life and future for them.

He would like to request a loan of PHP 6,000. He will use the loan to buy fertilizer, rice seed and chemicals. The loan will really go far in sustaining his livelihood.

He is actively involved in CEVI credit meetings. He has learned many things from bible reflections and sharing. He also received training and insurance coverage from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, rice seed and chemicals

loans.name: Pum

texts.en:
Pum Y., 35, is married. She has two school-aged children who are enrolled in a local primary school. She lives with husband in Kampong Cham Province. She is a farmer who typically makes around USD $1.90 per day. Her husband is a baker, making USD $16.60 per day. 

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year and inflation struggles have affected all Cambodians. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, Y. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor most. 

In light of the country's economic difficulties, Y. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of USD $1200 to purchase a bakery machine for her husband's business, because the bakery business is the primary source of income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a bakery machine

loans.name: Nut

texts.en:
Nut C., 28, is married and has 2 young children who are not yet enrolled in school. She lives with husband in Kampong Cham Province. She is a subsistence farmer who grows just enough rice for her family to eat. Her husband sells soy-milk and making $3.30 USD per day. 

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year, and inflation struggles have affected all Cambodians. These factors have resulted in a difficult economic year for much of the country, C. included. The country’s economic struggles always seem to affect the poor most. 

In light of the country’s economic difficulties, C. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $300 to purchase a trailer and an ice box so her husband can more easily transport the soy milk because his business is the primary source of income for her family.

loans.use: To buy a trailer and an ice box

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en:
Victoria G. is a 48-year-old farmer and mother of two children. She helps her husband till a 1-hectare (2.5-acre) farm that provides income for their household. She said that when she has savings, she will not need a loan to support her business.

She is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer, pesticides, rice seed and chemicals. She is very optimistic that she will be able to increase the average size of her harvest. 

CEVI helps her fulfill her dreams. Now she is involved in the CEVI cluster meetings. She learned about business from the credit plus education CEVI brings to the community. She also received training and insurance coverage in addition to  the loans that she borrowed.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer, pesticides, rice seed and chemicals

loans.name: Arlene

texts.en:
Arlene A., age 49, raises pigs. She also manages a small sari-sari (variety) store in her neighborhood. She runs multiple businesses to meet the growing expenses in their home. She is now cleaning the barn. She intends to buy new piglets and start a piggery.

After learning about CEVI services, she would like to apply for a loan of Php 6,000 to buy pig feed and 2 piglets. She hopes that someday she won't have to apply for a loan to expand her business and that someday she will be able to achieve all her dreams for her children.

CEVI aims to help small businesses grow. Like Arlene, CEVI is reaching out communities to start businesses for their own families.

loans.use: To buy pig feed and 2 piglets

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn J. is from the village of Waterfall Balingasag, Misamis Oriental. She is 46 years old. Evelyn is married and has 7 adult children. To make a living, Evelyn owns and operates a specialized retail store where she sells seafood products, including fish and shrimp, in the local community. Evelyn has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately 15000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Evelyn joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evelyn has successfully repaid a previous loan of 20000 PHP from HSPFI. Evelyn is requesting a new loan of 24000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be Evelyn's 9th loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Yokubboy

texts.en:
Y. Yokubboy is a potato farmer. As the head of the family, he is doing his best to increase his yield to support his family. At the same time, Yokubboy raises cattle with the help of his family. He is 42 years old and has 4 children. Yokubboy has managed the farm for 26 years. Because of his farm, he was able to feed his family and dreams of having all of his children graduate from school and college so that they can find better jobs for their future families. 

Yokubboy is asking a loan of $3000 USD to buy seeds and fertilizer for his farm. He will use the loan to increase his yield and support his family. With the part of the loan, he will also purchase cattle. Let’s support this hard-working and talented man so that he can obtain his goals! 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy seeds and fertilizer

loans.name: Chom

texts.en:
Chom C., age 54, is married and has 8 children. Seven of her children are students and another one is employed in the city. She lives with her husband in Kampong Cham Province. She is a subsistence farmer who produces just enough rice for her family to eat. Also, she manufactures dried salted fish for her repeat customers at the markets. This earns her an income of US $7 per day. Her husband is sick and stays at home. 

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, C. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, C. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US $400 to purchase more fish to manufacture into dried salted fish to sell because this business is the primary source of income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase more fish

loans.name: Chea

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Chea, 42, and her husband, Mr. Ny Khin, 49, live on an island of the Mekong River, about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.
