They married in 1984 and have seven children, five sons and two daughters. Two of their children are married and one lives outside the family home. Two of their sons are construction workers, one of their daughters weaves silk at home, and the others are still in school. 

S. was a weaver for twenty-three years. It is a skill she learned from her neighbor. She gave her loom to her daughter and started new business growing vegetables and crops. Mr. Ny Khen has been a fisherman for over twenty-five years. He fishes in the village and sells the fish to villagers.

S. is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase silk material for her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for her daughter’s weaving business.

loans.name: Marcelinda

texts.en:
Marcelinda J. is a 45-year old rice grower in Veruela, Agusan Del Sur. She has four children and a supportive husband who manages their farm. Her hopes and plans for the future is to have another area for rice. She also mentioned  the education of her children and providing them a bright future.

Marcelinda wants a loan to buy seedlings, complete fertilizers, herbicides, and insecticides. Because she was very worried about where is she going to look for money to finance her business, when she learned about the CEVI credit program, she never hesitated to apply for a small amount. which is really what she needs for her business operations.

Now she attends the CEVI cluster meetings which are managed by CEVI borrowers. They elect officers in their organizations. In their gathering, they learn about community business and savings, in addition to loans, training and the insurance coverage that they received.

loans.use: To buy seedlings, complete fertilizers, herbicides and insecticides

loans.name: Dos

texts.en:
Dos P., age 38, is a widow who lives with her 15-year-old child in Kampong Cham Province. Her child is a mechanic with an income of around US $8.33 per day. To make a living, she produces baskets. Cambodian hand-made crafts require hard work and time to produce best output for competitive prices in the market. Typically, she is able to earn an income of US $2 per day. 

In light of the country's economic difficulties, which result from the financial crisis, P. is seeking to increase her income. P. is asking for a loan of $1000 to invest in her child's business. She will give this money to her child to buy spare parts for his customer's cars. She believes that this will help raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase spare parts for cars

loans.name: Sot

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Sot, 46, is widow with one son. She lives along National Road Number One apporximetely 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital of Cambodia.

S. has been selling vegetables for eight years. She buys them from Korki market, about 3 kilometers from her house, and transports them to the Phnom Penh market to sell.

Her son, Mr. Youvoin Horng, is a fourth-year student at the University of Phnom Penh and he is nearly finished with his bachelor's degree. S. hopes to support her son as he continues his education, so she is a asking for her first loan of $500 to pay school fees for her son.

Youvoin also has part-time job working for a private company in Phnom Penh.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her son who attends the university.

loans.name: Bout

texts.en: Bout T., 54, is a widow who lives in the Kampong Cham province with her 27-year-old child, who is a grocery seller with an income of around $5 US per day. To make a living, she has been subsistence farming – producing rice that is just adequate for her family to eat. In light of her country's economic difficulties due to the financial crisis, T. is seeking to increase her income. T. is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase various kinds of groceries to expand her child's business. She believes that this will help raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries for a store

loans.name: Anunciation

texts.en:
Anunciation S. is a 52-year-old rice farm owner from Verueala, Agusan Del Sur. She has one child and is tilling a 3 hectare rice field. Before this, she and her husband were just renting a farm. Now, they are managing a larger rice field, which they use to feed and provide for the needs of their children.

Anunciation would like to ask for a loan of 6,000 PHP. She will use the loan to buy fertilizers, rice seeds and chemicals. She is very optimistic that, with her loan from CEVI, she will have a good return on her investment later on.

Anunciation shared her hopes and plans for the future. According to her, she dreams of buying farm equipment in the future, to be able to improve her farm and provide her family better quality living. "Some day, I won't have to borrow from CEVI to support my business," she adds.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers, rice seeds and chemicals

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Grocery purchase

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Morn, aged 34, and her husband, Mr. Piseth Ros, aged 41, have been married since 1993. They have four daughters, all of whom are in school. The family lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Morn and her husband have been selling vegetables since 2005. They purchase them from farmers in their village and resell them at the market located in Phnom Penh. Morn hopes to expand her business, so she is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase vegetables on contract for resale.

loans.use: To purchase vegetables on contract for resale.

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S., 36, is married and lives with her husband in Sa-ang approximately 40 minutes from the city. To make a living, she has been selling porridge since 2001 with an income around US $3 per day. Her husband is a butcher who typically is able to make an income of US $3 per day. In light of the country's economic difficulties because of the financial crisis, S. is seeking to increase her income. S. is asking for a loan of $1000 to purchase pigs for her husband's business, and with the remainder, she wants to purchase a new motorbike for her husband to transport his products to sell at the markets. She believes that this will help raise her standard of living.

loans.use: To purchase pigs and a motorbike.

loans.name: Horng

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Horng, 45, and her husband, Mr. Moeun Pich, 48, live in a small village along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1986 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. One of them is a construction worker, two assist their mother in her business of selling vegetables and the other three attend school.

S. has been selling vegetables for 18 years. She buys them from farmers in their village and a nearby village to resell at Derm Kor market located in Phnom Penh. Mr. Moeun Pich has been driving a motor remorque taxi (a trailer pulled by a motorbike) for 18 years as well. He carries people and goods from his village to Phnom Penh and back.
S. is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to improve the foundations of her house.

loans.use: To improve the foundations of her house.

loans.name: Nith

texts.en:
Nith D., 27, is married and currently lives with her husband in Sa-ang approximately 40 minutes from the city. She has been engaged in the business of selling vegetable since 2005 with an income of US$3 per day. Her husband is a construction worker, making US$2.50 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year and inflation struggles have affected all Cambodians. These factors have played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, D. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most.

In light of the country's economic difficulties, D. is seeking to increase her income and improve her business. She is asking for a loan of US$700 to purchase a trailer to easily transport more vegetables to sell at the market because she has noticed that this business is the primary source of income for her family.

loans.use: To purchase a trailer

loans.name: Hai

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Hai, 44, and her husband, Mr. Huot Hin, 41, have been married since 1992 and have one son and one daughter, both of whom attend school. The family lives along the Tonle Basac River, a tributary of the nearby Mekong, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.

K. and her husband have been farming for twenty-nine years. They grow cucumbers, green beans, and jasmine. The couple transports their produce to sell at the Prek Phnao market about 30 kilometers from their house.

K. is requesting her second loan of $1,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticides in order to continue her farming business and to buy more jasmine flower trees to grow.

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer and pesticides

loans.name: Rong

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Rong, age 31, (shown in the picture in her grocery shop), and her husband, Mr. Thol Thon, age 28, live in a small village along National Road Number One about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2002 and have two daughters, both of whom are in primary school.

S. has been selling groceries for six years. She buys them from Korky market and sells them at her house. Her husband has been driving a motor taxi for six years as well.

S. is applying for her first loan of $1,000 to repair her house and to buy more grocery items for resale.

loans.use: To repair her house and to buy additional grocery items to sell

loans.name: Las

texts.en:
Mrs. Y. Las, 41, and her husband, Mr. You Khem, 44, were married in 1993 and have six children: four sons and two daughters. Four of their children attend school. The family lives on an island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Y. and her husband are farmers. Besides farming, Mr. You Khem is a wooden house constructor as well. He works in his village and in nearby villages.

Y. is requesting a loan of $1,000 in order to purchase a motorized hand-tiller. She will use it to plow her own farm and rent it to other farmers to get extra income.

loans.use: To buy a motorized hand-tiller for plowing

loans.name: Lucena

texts.en: Lucena R. manages a small rice field which is 5 hectares (12.5 acres) in size in Veruela, Agusan del Sur. She has four children and a very supportive husband who looks after their needs. Aside from having a farm, she also sells different goods. She only sells those items that are needed by people everyday. Lucena would like to ask for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to buy three bags of ammonium sulfate fertilizer, rice seed, and other inputs. She is hoping that what she invests in her business will lead to good return of investment in the future. CEVI helps small businesses grow. It provides its clients with not just loans but with training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To buy three bags of ammonium sulfate fertilizer, rice seed, and other inputs

loans.name: Kou

texts.en:
Miss. C. Kou, age 24, is single. She lives with her parents along National Road Number Five about seventeen kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

C. has been a garment factory worker for ten years. She wants to buy cows to raise, but she doesn’t have any money. Thus, she is applying for a loan of $1,000 to make the purchase.

It will be better for her to have more income from selling cows when they grow big enough.

loans.use: To purchase cows to raise

loans.name: Judith

texts.en:
Judith is a member of the Ushirikiano borrower group in Kola, Mororgoro. She is 34 years old, married and mother of two children. Her children are ages 9 and 6.

Judith started her own café business selling food six years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 120,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Judith’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat, sugar to grow her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Judith hopes to save money, get more food for her family and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy rice, wheat and sugar

loans.name: Area Five Group

texts.en:
Sulum is a member of Area Five Group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 40 years old, married and the mother of two children.Her children are ages 15 and 9. She also cares for another seven dependents.

Suluma started her own clothing business, selling clothes for five years. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 600,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Suluma's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 in order to buy more clothes to sell. With the profits she gains from the use of this loan, Suluma hopes to save money and expand her business.

Tausi is another member of Area Five Group. She also requested an amount of 150,000 in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Van

texts.en:
Mrs. T. Van, age 57, and her husband, Mr. Ban Om, age 64, have been married since 1976 and have two daughters and two sons. Three of their children are married and live outside the family house; the other one weaves silk at home. The family lives in a small village across the Mekong River approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

T. learned to weave silk from her parents in 1966 and started her silk production in the same year. She sells her finished product to a middleman in the village, who then takes it to sell at Phnom Penh market. Her husband grows rice and food crops in the village. Besides farming, he is a chef as well. They are in their late 50’s and 60‘s but still strong enough to work.

T. is asking for a loan of $400 in order to purchase silk materials for continuing her business and she hopes to use a part of her loan to help repair her daughter’s house.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her business and to help repair her daughter’s house

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a member of Tujikomboe Group in Msamvu, Morogoro. She is 30 years old, married and the mother of one child. Her child is four years old.

Mary started her own clothing business selling clothes five years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Mary's second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested the amount of 250,000 in order to buy more clothes for selling. With the additional profit she gains from this loan, Mary hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes to sell

loans.name: Lilia

texts.en:
49-year old Lilia C. is a corn-grower. She has a farm which is 2.2 hectares (5.5 acres) in size. She has two children and she is working so hard to provide all the needs in their home. When her husband died, she learned to be strong for her family. She manages the farm so that she will have enough money to support the education of her children.

Now, Lilia is wondering if there’s a way that she could increase the size of her harvest. She thinks of buying the farm necessities so that the corn will grow healthier and bigger. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). She will use the loan to buy two sacks of ammonium sulfate fertilizer and a piglet to start a piggery. 

Lilia chose the services of CEVI because of its credit plus its education. Every time they have a cluster meeting, CEVI teaches women to become leaders by empowering them to preside during the gathering. CEVI also offers training and insurance coverage to all its clients.

loans.use: To buy two sacks of ammonium sulfate fertilizer and a piglet

loans.name: Edeltrudis

texts.en:
Edeltrudis is a member of the Juhudi borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is 50 years old, widowed, and mother of five children. Her children are ages 33, 31, 27, 25 and 22 years. 

Edeltrudis started her own business selling chicken seven years ago. She works 24 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Eldetrudis’ first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more chicken. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Eldeltrudis hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chicken

loans.name: Pov

texts.en: Mrs. C. Pov, age 26, is a widow (pictured here with her father). She has two children: a son and a daughter, which are both young. She lives with her parents on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. C. has been a ferment factory worker for one month. Because her father sells cows, she is asking for a loan of $400 in order to purchase a cow for her father to resale.

loans.use: To purchase a cow for her father to resale

loans.name: Salome

texts.en:
Salome is a member of the Maendeleo borrower group in Msamvu, Mororgoro. She is a 22-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of three children. Her children are aged 5, 3  and 1 years.

Salome started her own business five years ago selling clothes. She works six hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Salome’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to get more food for her family, do repairs, pay school fees, save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Ziada

texts.en:
Ziada is a member of the Makongoro borrower group in Msamvu, Morogoro. She is a 23-year-old married woman.
 
Ziada started her own business three years ago selling clothes. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 100,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Ziada’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 250,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Norn

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Norn, age 22, and her husband, Mr. Kimleng Brak, age 29, were married in 2004. They have two young children: one son and one daughter. The family lives on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

S. has been a nail artist (cutting and painting toenails and fingernails) for one year. She runs the business in her village by herself. Kimleng has been a chef for over ten years; he cooks for a restaurant. S. is applying for a loan of $500. She hopes to use the loan, along with her own money, to purchase neighboring property to expand her house property.

loans.use: To combine with her own money for the purchase of neighboring property to expand her house property

loans.name: Gilness

texts.en:
Gilness is a member of the Furaha borrower group in Msamvu, Morogoro. She is a 50-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of eight children. Her children are aged 33, 31, 29, 27, 25, 23, 20 and 15 years.
 
Three years ago Gilness started her own business selling clothes and charcoal. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 280,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Gilness’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal and clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Gilness hopes to save money, get more food for her family, pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal and clothes to sell

loans.name: Virgie

texts.en:
Virgie P. is a 38-year-old farmer and single mother with one child. She also raises chickens as a means of additional income. She owns a 6-hectare farm. She is worried because the farm has remained unplanted. She has decided to utilize the farm for growing vegetables, coconuts, and rice.

She would like to ask for a loan of 6,000 PHP to be able to get started in her plan. She will use the loan to purchase four bags of ammonium sulfate, as well as farm chemicals. She is a very optimistic woman and hopes very much for the possibility of success in her business.

Now, she is actively involved in the CEVI credit program. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase four bags of ammonium sulfate, as well as farm chemicals

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a member of the Uaminifu borrower group in Msamvu, Mororgoro. She is a 39-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of two children. Her children are aged 22 and 10 years. She also cares for four other dependents.

Five years ago Fatuma started her own business selling clothes. She works eight hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 210,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Fatuma’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 300,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Fatuma, hopes to save money, pay school fees and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Tol

texts.en:
Miss. S. Tol, age 31, is single. She lives with her mother and brothers and sister on an Island in the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh City. Her mother is 67 years old; however, she is still able to run own business selling dessert.

S. has been a silk weaver for over ten years. She sells her finished products to a middleman who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh market. 

S. is applying for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle for her sister for commuting to work.

loans.use: To buy a motorbike for her sister to drive to work

loans.name: Jamila

texts.en:
Jamila is a member of the Chapakazi borrower group in Msamvu, Mororgoro. She is a 34-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of two children. Her children are aged 13 and 7 years. She also cares for two other dependents.

Three years ago Jamila  started her own shop selling commodities like rice and sugar. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 500,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Jamila’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more wheat, rice and sugar. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more wheat, rice and sugar to sell

loans.name: Nasma

texts.en:
Nasma is a member of the Faraja borrower group in Msamvu, Mororgoro. She is a 26-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of one child. Her child is aged 5 years.

One year ago Nasma started her own business selling produce. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Nasma’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more produce. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to pay school fees, save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more produce to sell

loans.name: Un

texts.en:
Mrs. L. Un, 50, (pictured with her children) and her husband, Mr. Thorn Uk, 54, live in a small village across the the Mekong River and about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 1983 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. Four of their children are in school, and the youngest one is three years old.

L. has been a silk weaver for twenty-nine years, a skill she learned from her mother. She sells her finished products to the middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell in Phnom Penh. Her husband has been a house builder for nineteen years.

L. has borrowed money from Kiva through MAXIMA two times already and she used the loans to set up one more loom for her daughter to weave when she’s not in school. Now she is asking for another loan of $400 in order to purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials to continue her weaving business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a member of the Singolukele borrower group in Kola, Mororgoro. She is a 31-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of three children. Her children are aged 9, 5 and 2 years. She also cares for one other dependent.

Ten years ago Joyce started her own shop selling wheat, rice and sugar. She works fourteen hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Joyce’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat and sugar to sell. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat and sugar to sell

loans.name: Furaha Group

texts.en:
Hadija is a member of the Furaha borrower group in Msamvu, Mororgoro. She is a 39-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of three children. Her children are aged 22, 20 and 9 years. She also cares for one other dependent.

Ten years ago Hadija started her own business selling charcoal. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 180,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Hadija’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal to sell. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, she hopes to get more food for her family, save money and expand her business. 

Danieca, the other member of the Furaha borrower group, has also requested 400,000 Tsh in order to support her own clothing business.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is a member of the Omega borrower group in Kola, Morogoro. She is a 39-year-old woman, is married, and is the mother of five children. Her children are aged 22, 18, 12, 4 and 1 years.

Seven years ago, Beatrice started her own café business selling food. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 400,000 Tanzania Shillings.

This is Beatrice’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested 400,000 Tsh in order to buy rice, wheat and sugar. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Beatrice hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat and sugar

loans.name: Romeo

texts.en: 50-year-old Romeo C. is a peddler of dried fish in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato. He has four children and all he wishes to do is provide all their needs and provide a brighter future for his family. He was once a collector in a bus company. However, he was tired of doing it everyday so he decided to quit his job and manage a dried-fish business instead. Romeo would like to ask for loan of Php 14,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). He will use the loan to purchase more dried fish and chorizo (processed meat) for sale. His business is going so well, considering that he just started it in 2007. His income has gone far in paying for the school tuition and in buying groceries in their home. CEVI helps him have additional capital in his business. He receives loans, training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase more dried fish and chorizo (processed meat) to sell

loans.name: Vilma

texts.en: Vilma B. is already 60 years old. She is old but still strong enough to manage a business. She has seven children who are also married. She has been very particular as to the size of her harvest. That is why she encourages all her laborers to do everything to improve their yield. Vilma is a member of a CEVI cluster organization. She would like to ask for a loan to be able to buy sacks of fertilizer and chemicals. She is very optimistic that these things will help in having an abundant harvest on her farm. CEVI helps Vilma sustain her livelihood. She receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals for her farm

loans.name: Noe

texts.en:
Noe L. is a 44-year old farmer in Sto Nino, South Cotabato, Mindanao. He has one child and is doing his best to nurture him until he grows. In 1998, he started to farm. He has only one-hectare to till but this helps him to provide for the growing needs of his family.

He would like a loan of Php 8,000 to buy fertilizers and chemicals. Fertilizers and chemicals are vital in ensuring an abundant and quality harvest. He is hoping that his investments will have good returns in the future.

As he is managing his farm, he hopes and plans in the future to have a stable income so that he will no longer need to apply for a loan from CEVI.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Malika

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
       Малике 40 лет. Она замужем и мать 3-х детей. Она опытная портниха. Клиенты приходят к ней домой заказывать разные национальные платья. Она шьет платья на заказ, кроме того она со своими ученицами шьют национальные платья для реализации на рынках Панчшанбе и Якшанбе. Малика закупает ткань на рынках Сомон и Атуш. Там очень большой ассортимент тканей и низкая цена. В осенний сезон Малика планирует шить платья из теплой велюровой ткани. Для этого она должна закупить большую партию этой ткани и поэтому она запрашивает этот займ.
texts.en:
Malika is 40 years old. She is married and is a mother of 3 children. She is an experienced seamstress. Her customers come to her home to place orders for various traditional dresses. Malika makes dresses to-order and also makes traditional dresses with her apprentices for sale at the Panchshanbe and Yakshanbe markets. Malika buys the fabric at the Somon and Atush markets because they have a wide selection of fabrics and low prices there. During the autumn season, Malika plans to sew dresses from warm velour fabric. She needs to purchase a large stock of this fabric for this purpose, and this is why she is requesting a loan.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of velour fabric

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn D. is a 47 years old farmer in Sto. Nino, Cotabato. She has eight children and a very supportive husband who helps her manage their rice field. In 1983, they started to till land on a two-hectare farm. Aside from farming, they also have a sari-sari store. These are their sources of income.

She would like a loan of Php 15,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc.in order to purchase fertilizers and chemicals that are vital to ensure quality and healthy rice. She is very optimistic that she will be able to achieve more than the average of what is normally yielded in her rice farm.

CEVI helps small business grow and provides clients with not just loans but training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Muslum

texts.en:
Muslum, this 36-year-old man, is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan Fuzuli region, settled in Fizuli region, Araz-Zargar village. He is married and has four children.

Muslum has been in his pharmacy business for ten years. Now, he needs a loan of 2,000 AZN to buy medicines for improving his pharmacy business.

loans.use: To buy medicines for improving his pharmacy business

loans.name: Bella

texts.en:
Bella P., 49, is from the village of Bitibut, Sapang Dalaga, Misamis Occidental, where she is the married mother of six school-aged children. To earn a living, Bella makes and sells bibingka or rice cakes in the local community. Engaged in her business for over three years now, she earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Bella joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Having fully repaid a previous loan of 3000 PHP from GDMPC, she is now requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients to expand her product line. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients to expand product line

loans.name: Chem

texts.en:
Mr. K. Chem, 46, and his wife, Mrs. Phal Sok, 45, were married in 1983 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One of their children has full time employment and the other children study in the local school. The family lives in the small village of National Road Number Two, about 20 kilometers south of Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

K. has been growing rice and vegetables since he was married and started another business raising cows and chickens. Mrs. Phal Sok has been a garment factory worker for one year. The couple wants to repair their house to make it bigger and more comfortable, because their old house is small and broken in some parts. They don’t have enough money to repair it, so K. is requesting a loan of $800 to purchase wooden materials and zinc to make the repairs.

loans.use: To purchase wooden materials and zinc for house repair

loans.name: Muminadjon

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
      Муминаджон 32 лет. Замужем и мать 3-х детей. Её муж занимается скотоводством. Сама Муминаджон занимается пошивом женской национальной и европейской одежды. У Муминаджон много клиентов. Она очень красиво шьет и поэтому у нее много заказов. В основном, когда ей заказывают платья она подбирает ткань сама. Фурнитуру покупает тоже сама. У Муминаджон очень хороший вкус и многие клиенты полагаются на ее вкус. Она решила на осенний сезон закупить полушерстяной ткани для пошива европейской одежды и велюровой ткани для пошива национальной ткани. Для этого она просит займ и очень надеется, что займ поможет в развитии ее бизнеса.
texts.en:
Muminadjon is 32 years old. She is married and is a mother of 3 children. Her husband is involved in animal husbandry. Muminadjon is involved in sewing women's traditional and European-style clothing. Muminadjon has many customers. She sews very beautifully and, thus, has many orders. Usually, when she receives orders for dresses, she picks the fabric herself. She buys accessories on her own as well. Muminadjon has very good taste, and many clients rely on her taste. For the autumn season, she decided to purchase wool fabric for sewing European clothing and velour fabric for sewing traditional clothing. She is requesting a loan for this purpose and hopes that this loan will help with developing her business.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of wool and velour fabrics

loans.name: Choun

texts.en: Mrs. Choun S., age 29, and her husband, Mr. Vanny Pang, 25, live along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 2003 and have one son and one daughter.  Choun has been growing and selling flowers in her village for 15 years, while her husband has been a chef for three years. She is asking for a loan of $300 to purchase a motorbike to carry her flowers to sell.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to carry flowers to sell.

loans.name: Samira

texts.en: Samira (her husband is pictured) was born in 1986. She is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of the Azerbaijan Fuzuli region, now settled in Alkhanli village. This family has been in the cattle breeding business for five years. Now they need a loan of 2000 AZN to buy four calves to improve their cattle breeding business.

loans.use: To buy four calves

loans.name: Man

texts.en:
Mr. Man L., 34, and his wife, Mrs. Sithon Lun, 36, have been married since 2000 and have three children: one son and two daughters. One is in school while the other two are yet too young to attend. The famiL. lives in a small village on National Road Number Two about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

Mr. L. has been selling cows for four years, while his wife has been a teacher since 1990. He hopes to expand his business to better support his famiL., so he is requesting his first loan of $1,200 in order to purchase additional cows for resale.

loans.use: To purchase additional cows for resale.

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Mr. C. Chhum has been driving a motor taxi for three months. Mrs. Sopheak Cheav has been selling mangoes for six years. C. is applying for his first loan of $1,000 to help finance his wife's purchase of mangoes on contract. The loan will also be used to buy pesticides to protect the mangoes from insects.

Mr. C. Chhum, age 36, and his wife, Mrs. Sopheak Cheav, age 34, live along National Road Number One, approximately 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh City. They were married in 1995 and have three children: one son and two daughters. Two children attend school and the other one is still too young. The couple hopes to support their children's further education.

loans.use: To purchase mangoes on contract for resale

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline R., 40, is from the village of Curvada, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur, where she is married and has two school-aged children. To earn a living, Evangeline owns and operates a pedicab transportation business that provides service to the local community. Evangeline is just starting this business.

In 2009, Evangeline joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Evangeline is requesting a loan of 5000 PHP to purchase a second-hand pedicab. This will be the first loan taken out by Evangeline from GDMPC, and she plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About GDMPC: GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partners to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase a second-hand pedicab

loans.name: Oyimniso

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
Солибоева Ойимнисо-1949 года рождения. Семейная, имеет 5х детей.Женщина с высшим образованием и припадает в школе, но так как на зарплату не прокормить семью, она подрабатывает на базаре. Ей помогают её дети и муж- Иляшев Баходир.Зарабатывают нормально. На жизнь хватает и при том  они смогли отбрасывать лишние деньги на свои нужды. С нашей организацией Ойимнисо  сотрудничает более 3х лет.Несколько раз брала кредит и расширила свой ассортимент. На следующий кредит она планирует закупить оптом продукты питания.
texts.en:
Born in 1949, Oyimniso S. is married and has 5 children. She has higher education and teaches at a school. However, because her salary cannot support the family, she sells at a market. Her children and husband, Bahodir Ilyashev, help her. They earn well. They have enough to make a living and were able to set money aside for their own needs. Oyimniso has been cooperating with our organization for over 3 years. She obtained several loans and expanded her selection. Oyimniso plans to use her next loan to purchase food products wholesale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of food products

loans.name: Munira

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
      Мунире - 40 лет. Замужем и мать 3-х детей. Занимается продажей женской одежды и женского нижнего белья на рынке Атуш города Худжанда, контейнер № 30. Ей помогает дочь. Она закупает товар из города Бишкека Республики Киргизия. Ездит за товаром в не сезон 1 раз, в сезон 2 раза в месяц. Сейчас начался школьный сезон, и хотя у Муниры в ассортименте нет детской одежды, она хочет закупить школьную форму для девочек и мальчиков, чтобы увеличить ассортимент и прибыль. Для этого она запрашивает займ.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Munira is 40 years old. She is married and is a mother of three children. She sells women's clothing and undergarments on the Atush market in the town of Khujand, container number 30. Her daughter helps her. She buys the merchandise in the city of Bishkek, Republic of Kyrgyztan. She travels for the merchandise once during the slow season and twice a month during season. Now it's a school season and although Munira does not have children's clothing in her inventory she wants to buy school uniforms for girls and boys to increase the assortment and profit. She is asking for a loan for this purpose.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy school and autumn clothing

loans.name: Phoung

texts.en: Mrs. Phoung B., 31 (shown in the picture with her brother), and her husband, Mr. Thy Chring, 25, have been married since 2005 and have two young children. The family lives along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh.  Mrs. B. and her husband are farmers. They grow vegetables and flowers and sell the grown flowers to a middleman in the village where they live.  She is asking for her first loan of $700 to pay school fees for her brother, who attends Banking and Finance University.

loans.use: To pay school fees for her brother.

loans.name: Thorn

texts.en:
Mr. C. Thorn, 30 (shown in the picture in his shop), and his wife, Mrs. Chanthoeun Um, 29, have been married for over a year. They have a 2-month-old daughter. The family lives in a small village in a suburb of Phnom Penh.

C. has been a motorbike repairer for five years. He runs the business at his own shop next to his house. His wife has been a hairdresser for one year. The couple is able to receive a gross profit about $6.25 per day.

C. doesn’t have enough capital to purchase more motorcycle spare parts for his motorbike repairing business, so he is asking for his first loan of US$ 500 in order to make the purchases.

loans.use: To purchase more motorcycle spare parts for his motorbike repairing business

loans.name: Alisher

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
Эркабоев Алишер- молодой мужчина,30 лет-занимается бизнесом  более 10лет. Зарабатывает хорошие деньги, потому что у него оптовая продажа продуктов питаниями. У Алишера   быстрый товарооборот, так как он привозит оптом хороший товар, который пользуется спросом. Его жена Зебо поддерживает мужа и торгует за него пока он ездит за товаром или где-то задерживается. Наш Фонд поддерживает таких бизнесменов и готов  сотрудничать с ними в дальнейшем. Алишеру тоже нравится сотрудничить с нами, потому что работая с нашей организацией он приобрёл финансовую поддержку.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan

Alisher Erkaboev is a young man of 30 years, has been doing business for more than ten years. He makes good money because his business is wholesale of food stuffs. Alisher has a quick turnover as he brings in quality goods in wholesale which are in high demand. His wife Zebo supports her husband and does the sales when he goes out for the goods or when he gets help up. Our Fund supports such businessmen and is ready to be partners with them in the future. Alisher is also happy to be working with us because by working with our organization he received financial support.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food products

loans.name: Orifa

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
     Орифе 51 год. Разведенная и мать 2-х детей. Она развелась с мужем много лет назад, потому, что муж много пил и не приносил домой деньги. Орифа много работает чтобы прокормить и обучать своих детей, а также накопить денег на свадьбу сына. Сын Орифы тоже работает помогает матери. Орифа продает поп-корн и мороженное около рынков Джума-базар, Якшанбе-базар, а в остальные дни недели торгует около своего дома. Орифа хочет расширить свой бизнес и поставить аппарат для разлива холодных напитков.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Orifa is 51 years old. She is divorced and is a mother of two children. She has divorced her husband many years ago because her husband was a drunk and did not bring any money home. Orifa works a lot to be able to feed and give education to her children and also save money for her son's wedding. Orifa's son also works and helps his mother. Orifa sells popcorn and ice cream around Juma-bazar and Yakshanbe-bazar markets, and during the other days she sells near her house. Orifa wants to expand her business and install a machine for making cold drinks.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ice cream and popcorn

loans.name: Oung

texts.en:
Mrs. S., age 30 (pictured with her farther who is a widower), has been married since 2007 and has no children yet. She lives with her farther along National Road Number One about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

S. has been a garment factory worker for 9 years. Her husband is a construction worker. He doesn’t have his own transportation for commuting to work, so S. is applying for her first loan of US$ 700 to purchase a motorcycle for her husband to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for her husband to use to commute to work

loans.name: Zamira

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan. 
        Замире 28 лет. Замужем и мать 3-х детей. Замира вместе с мужем занимаются откормом и продажей крупно рогатого и мелко рогатого скота. Зимой они откармливают скот дома. Но летом, так как на пастбищах много горной травы, они пасут скот в горах. Муж Замиры пасет мелко рогатый скот в горах, а Замира откармливает крупно рогатый скот дома. Когда скот будет готов муж Замиры продает их на скотном рынке. Замира и ее муж просят займ для закупки крупно рогатого скота.
texts.en:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand” “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan.

Zamira is 28 years old. She is married and is a mother of three children. Zamira together with her husband feed and sell large and small cattle. In the winter they feed the cattle at home, but in the summer there's a lot of grass in the mountain range and they shepherd the cattle there. Zamira's husband shepherds small cattle in the mountains and Zamira feeds large cattle at home. When the cattle is ready her husband sells it on the livestock market. Zamira and her husband are asking for a loan to buy large cattle.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cattle

loans.name: Lorena

texts.en:
Lorena G. is from the village of Lower Bayao, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur. She is 33 years old. Lorena is married and has 4 school-aged children. To make a living, Lorena owns and operates a food market. The main source of income for the business comes from selling seafood products including fish and shrimp in the local community. Lorena has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 1,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Lorena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Lorena is requesting a loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional seafood to sell. This will be the first loan taken out by Lorena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional seafood to sell

location.town: Lower Bayao, Tukuran, Zamboanga Del Sur

loans.name: Sao

texts.en:
Mr. S. Sao, 53, and his wife, Mrs. Bora Soy, 51, got married in 1978. They have five children: three sons and two daughters. One of them is married and lives in a separate house; two sons are construction workers; one daughter is a garment factory worker and the other one is in school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number Two about 12 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

S. has been a mason since 1981. He does his work in his village and in nearby villages. His wife stays at home and takes care of the household. His children don’t have their own transportation; they spend a lot of money to take motor taxis. So, S. is asking for a loan of US$ 1,200 to purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for his children to drive to work.

loans.name: Gani

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Бердыев Гани -40летний мужчина,женат.Имеет 4х детей-двоих сыновей и 2их дочек.Его жена Бердыева Гульбахор работает медсестрой в районной поликлинике.Гани сам мастер по ремонту лекговых автомобилей,с детства увлекался машинами и вот стал мастером.В районе его услуга пользуется большим спросом, так как каждый второй или третий владеет собственным автомобилем.Гани ремонтирует все виды автомобилей и зарабатывает в среднем 50 сом. в день.Узнав про нашу организацию он решил обратиться за кредитом,чтобы закупить по оптовой цене запчасти.Он обучает своих сыновей своему делу и планирует в будущем открыть для них новую точку техобслуживания.
texts.en:
Gani B. is a 40-year-old man, who is married and has 4 children - two sons and two daughters. His wife, Gulbahor Berdyeva, works as a nurse at a district hospital. Gani is a master car mechanic. He loved cars since childhood and became a mechanic. His services are in high demand in the district because every second or third person has their own car. Gani repairs all types of cars and earns an average of 50 somoni per day. Having learnt about our organization, he decided to request a loan in order to buy spare parts wholesale. He teaches the business to his sons and plans to open a new auto repair shop for them in the future.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Wholesale purchase of spare parts

loans.name: Sary

texts.en:
Mr. T. Sary, 27 and his wife, Mrs. Aminas Mat, 24, have been married since 2007 and just have a little daughter. They live along National Road Number Six about twenty kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

T. and his wife sell cosmetics (perfume, powder, lipsticks), radios… etc. They buy their goods from Phnom market and transport them to sell in other districts, faraway from their house. His motorbike is old and breaks down, so T. is asking for his first loan of US$ 500 to purchase a motorbike to replace the old one and expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to replace the old one.

loans.name: Cheoun

texts.en:
Cheoun C., age 49, is married and has 6 children. Five of his children are students and another one is employed at a local garment factory. He lives with his wife (pictured) in Phnom Penh City. He and his wife work together in the grocery business. This earns them collectively an income of US$ 10 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, C. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, C. is seeking to increase his income and improve his business. He is asking for a loan of US$ 500 to purchase more various kinds of groceries to sell because this business is the primary source of income for his family.

loans.use: purchasing more groceries

loans.name: Tausi

texts.en:
Tausi is a member of Tunda borrower group.She is a 35-year-old woman,she is married and is a mother of three children. Her children are aged 15, 13 and 8 years.

 Tausi started her own business selling crops 3 years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earn a monthly profit of approximately 450,000 Tsh.
    
This is Tausi`s second loan from BRAC Taznania. She requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more crops for sale. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Tausi hopes to pay school fees, expand her business, and save money.

loans.use: To buy crops for sale

loans.name: Chhorn

texts.en:
Chhorn B., age 35, is married and has 2 children who are not yet old enough to have been enrolled in a school. He lives with his wife in Phnom Penh City. He and his wife work together in a sewing business at home to make a living. This earns them collectively an income of US $5 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, B. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, B. is seeking to increase his income and improve his business. He is asking for a loan of US$ 1000 to purchase more various kinds of fabrics to use to design good clothes to sell.

loans.use: fabric purchase

loans.name: Zahanati Group

texts.en:
Neema is a member of Zahanati borrower group. She is a 39-year-old women, she is widowed, and a mother of four children.Her children are aged 23, 18, 14 and 10 years. She also cares for another four dependents.

 Neema started her own food business selling vegetable and fruits 10 years ago. She works six hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tsh.

This is Neema’s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested the amount of 150,000Tsh in order to buy more products for sale. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Neema hopes to save money and expand her business.

Martha, Amina, Zuwena and Mwanaid are also members of the same borrower group. They also requested the loan from BRAC Tanzania in order to expand their own businesses.

loans.use: To buy more fruits and vegetable for sale

loans.name: Furaha Group

texts.en:
Asha is a member of Furaha borrower group. She is a 48-year-old woman,she is widowed, and she is a mother of two children.Her children are aged 20 and 16 years. She also cares for two other dependents.

 Asha started her own business selling charcoal 10 years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit approximately 150,000 Tanzania shillings.

This is Asha’s second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 350,000 Tsh in order to buy more charcoal for sale. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Asha hopes to save money and expand her business.

Situmai and Sikudhani are also members of the same borrower group. They also requested loans of 400,000 Tsh and 200,000 Tsh respectively.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Zainabu

texts.en:
Zainabu is a member of Area Five . She is a 26-year-old women, she is married, and  a  mother of two children .Her children aged 6 and 2 years.

Zainabu started her own clothing business  selling clothes for five years. She works twelve hour a day and earn a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tsh.

This is Zainabu`s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 150,000 in order to buy more clothes for sale. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zainabu hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Oung

texts.en:
Oung M., age 35, is married and has 2 children who are not old enough to have been enrolled in a school yet. He lives with his wife in Phnom Penh City. He is a skillful goldsmith, typically earning US$ 5 per day. His wife is employed in a garment factory with an income of US$ 3 per day.

The financial crisis has been difficult for business in Cambodia this past year. This factor has played into a difficult economic year for much of the country, M. included. The country's economic struggles always seem to affect the poor the most. In light of the country's economic difficulties, M. is seeking to increase his income and improve his business. He is asking for a loan of US$ 800 to purchase more platinum to design it into jewelry for his repeat and new customers.

loans.use: purchase platinum for making jewelry

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta C. is from the village of Pinansalan, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 45 years old. Julieta is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Julieta owns and operates a fishing business. The main source of income for the business comes from harvesting and selling wild-caught fish and seafoods to local community members. Julieta earns approximately 3,500 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Julieta joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Julieta has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Julieta is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used for repair and maintenance of her pumpboat. This will be the third loan taken out by Julieta from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as a reserve for future emergencies.

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: for repair and maintenance of pumpboat

loans.name: Tumaini Group

texts.en:
Tamasha is one of two members of the Tumaini borrower group of Msamvu in Morogoro. She is 35 years old and is married. She has four children, ages five, 10, 15, and 18.

Five years ago, Tamasha started her own cafe business, selling food. She works 12 hours a day and gains a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzanian shillings.

This is Tamasha's second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She has requested a loan in the amount of 250,000 in order to buy more rice, wheat, and sugar.

With the profit she expects to get from the use of this loan, Tamasha hopes to pay school fees, save money, and expand her business.

Grace is the member of this borrower group. Like Tamasha, she has requested a loan in the amount of 250,000 in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat, and sugar

Следующий кредит на хочет использовать на завоз школьного ассортимента детской одежды и обуви. Она привозит товар из оптового рынка города Истаравшан. Инобат ездит за товаром 2-3 раза в месяц. Инобат через 2-3 дня собирается опять в Истаравшан за школьным товаром.
texts.en:
Inobat is a woman, who has been a borrower for over one year. She uses each of her loans purposefully for business expansion. Her merchandise selection consists of children's clothing and shoes. Inobat wants to use her next loan to bring in school selection of children's clothing and shoes. She delivers her merchandise from a wholesale market in the city of Istaravshan. Inobat goes there 2-3 times per month. Inobat plans to go to Istaravshan in 2-3 days to purchase school merchandise.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of school merchandise

 Ginna started her own clothing business selling clothes 1 year ago. She works twelve hour a day and earn a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tsh.

This is Ginna`s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested the amount of 200,000 Tsh In order to buy more clothes for sale. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Ginna hopes to save money and expand her business

Melrose S. is from the village of Poblacion 4, Clarin, Misamis Occidental. He is 34 years old. Melrose is married and has one school-aged child. To make a living, Melrose owns and operates a business venture raising fish. The main source of income for the business comes from raising fish for sale. Melrose has been engaged in his business for over 10 years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month for these activities.

He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand his business.

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Benkadi 3  De (Benkadi B Tingolé) Group

texts.fr:
Les deux  membres du groupe BENKADI 3 de l’association BENKADI B sont toutes des femmes mariées qui ont une moyenne d’âge de 41,  5 enfants et  vivant (toutes les deux) dans des familles polygames à TINGOLE  un chef lieu de commune de la sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative de la république du Mali.
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un soutien financier pour la réalisation de leurs activités hivernales. Leurs activités sont axées sur la culture du sorgho et de l’arachide. Elles sont à leur cinquième prêt avec l’institution. Tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés à temps.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour  acheter, de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 4 hectares.
Après la récolte, une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue, sur place au village, dans le marché de Marka-Coungo et à Fana, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 25 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The two members of the group BENKADI 3 of the association BENKADI B are both married women with an average age of 41 years old and 5 children. Both are in polygamous marriages and live in Tingole, the head town of a region within the FANA prefecture, the second administrative region of the Mali republic. Both work with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order get financial support for their winter labors. Their primary work is the cultivation of sorgho and peanuts. This is their fifth loan through the institution, and all priors loans were fully repaid on time. This new loan will be used to buy fertilizer, pesticides, basic agriculture tools and to pay the hoeing and labor fees to cultivate 4 hectares. After the harvest, part of their crop is consumed by the members of the group and the rest is sold from their home, in the village, and at the Marka-Coungo and Fana markets to both male and female customers. They expect to make an average profit of 25 000 FCFA after the harvest and sale of their crops.

Translated from French by Chloe Mark Translator, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, pesticides, hoeing and basic tools

Sherali is a 49 year old man, he is married and has six children. Sherali has secondary education and now works in a collective farm as a shepherd. His salary is enough only for the minimal life expenses, and this is why for already many years Sherali has been in the animal husbandry business. During the season for cheap cattle he buy several tens of heads of cattle and after feeding them he sells them for a good price. Sherali wants to use the loan to buy several cows and a calf. Sherali knows a lot about pedigree calves.

Translated from Russian by Elena Fedorchuk, Kiva Volunteer
