In the future she wants to grow her business by building a bigger poultry house. This way she hopes to increase her income and be able to provide good education for her children.

About KADET

The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities. .

loans.use: To buy chicken feed and construction materials to construct a poultry house.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Señora Mary is seen here with two clients who are enjoying her delicious regional dishes. Mary runs a business where she sells cooked foods in front of her home in the evenings. She lives in an area called "Luz y Paz" (Light and Peace) in the city of Pucallpa.  

Mary is 36 years old and married with three children. Her children inspire her to keep working hard at her business.  Her husband works as a laborer at Pucallpa's port. (Pucallpa is located on the Ucayali, a wide brown river that flows past the city and eventually joins the Amazon to the north).  

Mary has worked with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for more than a year and belongs to a communal bank known as Las Romanticas. She used her very first loan of about $100 to invest in her business selling foods typical of the region. She plans to invest this new loan in the same manner. Mary is very pleased to be working with Manuela Ramos, as the organization not only provides loans, but also teaches borrowers strategies to grow and improve their businesses.  

Mary's goal is to improve the interior of her home so that she can make part of it into a restaurant. In this way, she will be able to serve her customers in a cleaner and more pleasant environment.

loans.use: To buy food and supplies for a catering/restaurant business

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr: Mariée et mère de 02 enfants, cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, elle a commencé ce commerce en 2008 et a gagné grâce à son dynamisme la confiance de beaucoup de clients. Cette croissance de sa clientèle l’oblige à accroître son stock de marchandises pour les satisfaire convenablement. Elle sollicite alors de WAGES un crédit pour acheter divers produits d’alimentation générale.
texts.en:
Married and the mother of 02 children, this woman generates revenue by selling groceries. She began this business in 2008 and thanks to her dynamism, has gained the trust of many clients. This growth in her clientele has compelled her to increase her stock to properly satisfy them. She is therefore requesting a loan from WAGES to purchase various grocery products.

Translated from French by Heather Nicholson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of grocery products

loans.name: Iyabo

texts.fr:
Cette femme a commencé en 2002 le commerce de pagnes, plus tard, elle a associé à cette activité le commerce de bijoux, de sacs de sortie dames et de chaussures. Elle est très connu dans son quartier et ceci à cause du dynamise dont elle fait preuve. Le stock dont elle dispose présentement ne lui permet pas de répondre à la demande de sa clientèle. Pour les satisfaire tous et convenablement elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 18 pagnes de qualité  « hi-target », une dizaine de bijoux, des sacs et des chaussures
Etant célibataire, c’est avec le revenu de ce commerce qu’elle subvient à ses propres charges et à celle de sa famille.
texts.en:
This woman began selling "pagnes" (brightly colored lengths of African print cloth) in 2002. Later she added on the sale of costume jewelry, ladies' handbags, and shoes. She is well known in her neighborhood because of her dynamic personality. Her present inventory does not allow her to meet the needs of her clientele. In order to satisfy everyone appropriately, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 18 lengths of high quality "pagne" fabric of the Hi-Target brand, ten or so pieces of costume jewelry, some handbags, and some shoes.

Since she is single, she supports herself and her family with the income from her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of handbags, "pagnes", costume jewelry, and shoes for resale

loans.name: Adzo

texts.fr:
Voulant  rehausser son stock de charbons de bois  parce que détruite en partie par la pluie, cette femme sollicite de WAGES son premier crédit pour acheter 20 sacs de charbons de bois. Elle fait aussi le commerce de céréales ainsi avec ce crédit elle pourra en profiter pour augmenter son stock de céréales  avec 5 sacs de maïs et 5 sacs d’haricots.
Elle est mariée et mère de 04 enfants.
texts.en:
Wishing to expand her stock of charcoal, because part of it was destroyed by the rain, this woman is asking WAGES for her first loan to buy 20 sacks of charcoal. She also sells cereals, so with this loan she can take advantage of the opportunity to expand her stock of cereals buy purchasing 5 sacks of maize and 5 sacks of dried beans.

She is married and the mother of 4 children.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of charcoal, maize, and dried beans for resale

loans.name: Mjimwema Group

texts.en:
Chrisentus Paulo, age 22, is single and lives with his sisters and their sons ages 16 and 12. He makes a living selling used clothes. He started this business in 2007, and works daily from 8 a.m. until 5 p.m., earning a monthly profit of around $113. Chrisentus has applied for his first loan from Tujijenge Tanzania, and hopes to use it to buy more used items to sell.
 \t
Chrisentus will share this loan with his loan group,  Mjimwema, which has 18 members. The members of the group will hold each other accountable for paying back their loans. In the picture, we see Chrisentus in the middle of the front row.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Olinda

texts.en:
Señora Olinda is seen in this photo with the small amount of merchandise she had left after a month of good sales.  Olinda makes a living selling shoes made in the northern part of Peru. She lives in the city of Pucallpa, and travels from time to time to the coastal city of Trujillo to purchase her footwear.

Olinda is married and has four adult children. Her husband works as a laborer at Pucallpa's port. (Pucallpa lies along the Ucayali, a wide brown river that flows past the city and eventually joins the Amazon to the north).

Olinda has worked with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about one year and belongs to a communal bank known as Las Guerreras (The Warriors). Olinda invested her first loan of about $100 in clothing she could sell.  This is how she began to develop as an independent businesswoman.  Olinda plans to invest this new loan in women's shoes.  She is grateful to Manuela Ramos for helping her develop her business, and is careful to request only loan amounts that she is confident she will be able to pay back on time.  Olinda is also happy to be receiving credit from Manuela Ramos, because the organization provides loans easily, quickly and with few complications, unlike many other banks.

Olinda's goal is to continue to grow her business. She eventually hopes to have a small store from which she can sell her line of women's shoes.

loans.use: to buy women's shoes to sell.

loans.name: Yedoukoua

texts.fr: Cette femme  est mariée et mère de 02 enfants, elle vit avec son époux et ses 02 enfants dans le quartier de gblinkomé à lomé. Elle exerce comme activité la vente de produits d'alimentation générale. Elle s’approvisionne à Lomé, pour attirer plus de clients,elle réduit  son prix de vente, ainsi elle réalise plus de profits. Voulant rehausser son stock elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter  3 sacs de riz, 5 cartons de savons,3 bidons d'huile rouge et divers produits d'alimentation générale.
texts.en:
This woman is married and the mother of 2 children. She lives with her husband and her two children in the Gblinkomé district in Lomé. Her business is selling groceries. She stocks up in Lomé. In order to attact more customers, she lowers her sales prices, and in that way she makes more profit. Wishing to expand her inventory, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 3 sacks of rice, 5 cartons of soap, 3 jerrycans of red (palm) oil, and various other grocery items.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing grocery inventory

loans.name: Kwamba Kafui

texts.fr: Cette femme exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce des objets plastiques, sa clientèle est en majorité féminine. Elle accueille ses clients avec beaucoup d’attention  ce qui fait que ses clients reviennent toujours acheter chez elle. Elle fait face en ce moment à une rupture de stock, pour s’approvisionner, elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 15 plats plastiques, 10 gobelets et divers objets plastiques.
texts.en:
This woman sells plasticware. Most of her clientele is made up of women. She waits on her customers attentively so her customers often come back to buy from her. She is presently out of stock and to replenish her inventory, she is asking WAGES for a loan to buy 15 plastic trays, 10 drinking cups and various other plastic items.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of objects made of plastic for resale

loans.name: Kwami

texts.fr: Ce monsieur exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de cartes de recharges  téléphoniques, il fait ce commerce de façon ambulante ce qui lui permet de toucher plus de clients et de vendre plus. Sa clientèle a grandit, pour les satisfaire convenablement il veut rehausser son stock avec 3 cartons de cartes de recharges TOGOCEL, 3 cartons de cartes MOOV et 2 cartons de cartes ILLICO
texts.en:
This gentleman sells phone cards. He sells them door-to-door which allows him to contact lots of customers and to make more sales. His clientele has grown and to satisfy them appropriately, he wants to add to his inventory by buying 3 cartons of TOGOCEL rechargeable phone cards, 3 cartons of MOOV cards, and 2 cartons of ILLICO cards.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of rechargeable phone cards for re-sale

loans.name: Kobada 3 De (Kobada Nokabougou) Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOBADA 3 sont des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 49 ans, 7 enfants et  vivent la plupart dans des familles polygames dans le village de NOKABOUGOU,  commune de Tingolé, sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont en  partenariat avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un appui financier pour exercer leurs activités hivernales qui sont entre autres la culture du sorgho de l’arachide et du haricot. Elles sont à leur cinquième expérience avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été remboursés correctement.
Ce  prêt sera utilisé pour acheter de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 21 hectares.
Une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue sur les marchés de Tingolé, Marka-Coungo et Fana, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group KOBADA 3 are married women who average 49 years of age and 7 children. These women live for the most part in polygamous families in the village of NOKABOUGOU, in the community of Tingolé, sub-prefecture of FANA, (2nd administrative region of Mali). They are in a partnership with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of obtaining financial support to carry out their winter-time work, which includes growing sorghum, peanuts, and beans. They are on their fifth experience with the institution. The past loans were correctly repaid. This new loan will be used to buy fertilizer, herbicide, and minor farm supplies and equipment and will cover the cost of weeding and labor for maintaining 21 hectares. A portion of their production is for their own consumption. The other portion is sold to customers composed of men and women at the marketplaces of Tingolé, Marka-Coungo, and Fana. The group members plan on realizing an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA after the planting campaign.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding, and minor farm supplies and equipment

loans.name: Amanda

texts.en:
Amanda is 32 years old, married and has two children.  She makes a living running a small grocery store out of her home. She and her family live in a neighborhood called El Arenal in the city of Pucallpa, where her husband earns a living as a baker.  

Amanda has worked with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for about two years, and belongs to a communal bank known as Nuevas Amigas (New Friends).  Amanda invested her very first loan of about $100 in her shop and plans to do the same with this new loan.  Amanda is very friendly to her customers and her business is growing slowly but surely.

Amanda is grateful to Manuela Ramos for the financial support and business education she receives. Manuela Ramos loan officers give educational sessions about how to grow and promote one's business, as well as other topics, at the monthly meetings of every communal bank.  Additionally, Amanda is pleased that Manuela Ramos requires little paperwork from its borrowers.  To receive a loan, all one need do is be recommended by another responsible borrower, have an ongoing business, and be punctual and responsible in making loan payments.

loans.use: Products for a small grocery shop/ general store

loans.name: Akossiwa Venunye

texts.fr:
Cette femme s’est lancée en 2001 dans le commerce de pagnes, elle exerce son commerce de  façon ambulante et à ce jour elle dispose d’une clientèle élevée et maîtrise son commerce. Son avantage est qu’elle exerce son commerce de façon ambulante ce qui lui permet  de toucher plus de clients et de connaître leurs préférences. Voulant reconstituer son stock elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter 20 pagnes de nouvelles qualités.
Elle  est mariée et mère d’un enfant
texts.en:
This woman began selling fabric as a street vendor in 2001, and today she sells her fabrics to a respectable clientele. She has an advantage as a street vendor, because this allows her to sell to more clients and to better understand their preferences. In order to refill her stock of fabric she is asking for a loan from WAGES that will allow her to buy 20 new fabrics. She is married and has one child.

Translated from French by Chloe Mark Translator, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fabric

loans.name: Kobada 4 De (Kobada Nokabougou) Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOBADA 4 sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 34 ans,  4 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames dans le village de NOKABOUGOU,  commune de Tingolé, sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont en  partenariat avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un appui financier pour exercer leurs activités hivernales. Leurs activités sont entre autres la culture du sorgho de l’arachide et du haricot. Elles sont à leur cinquième expérience avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été remboursés correctement.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 21 hectares.
Une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue sur les marchés de Tingolé, Marka-Coungo et Fana, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of the group KOBADA 4 are married women who average 34 years of age and 4 children.  The women living for the most part in polygamous families in the village of NOKABOUGOU, in the community of Tingolé, sub-prefecture of FANA, (2nd administrative region of Mali). They are in a partnership with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with the goal of obtaining financial support to carry out their winter-time work, which includes growing sorghum, peanuts, and beans.  They are on their fifth experience with the institution.  The past loans were correctly repaid. This new loan will be used to buy fertilizer, herbicide, and minor farm supplies and equipment and will cover the cost of weeding and labor for maintaining 21 hectares. A portion of their production is for their own consumption.  The other portion is sold to customers composed of men and women at the marketplaces of Tingolé, Marka-Coungo, and Fana. The group members plan on realizing an average profit of 40,000 francs CFA after the planting season.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Labor, fertilizer, herbicide, weeding, and minor supplies and equipment

loans.name: Emefa Yawa

texts.fr:
Cette dame habite dans le quartier d’adidogomé, elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants, son mari est un enseignant. Elle exerce comme activité génératrice de revenu le commerce de produits alimentaires. Son stock actuel a connu une baisse, elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des 04 sacs de farine de blé, 10 bidons d’huile, du sucre et divers produits alimentaires.
Avec son revenu elle contribue aux dépenses de la famille.
texts.en:
This lady lives in the Adidogomé district.  She is married and the mother of three.  Her husband is a teacher.  She earns revenues from commerce in food items.  Her inventory right now has experienced a drop.  She wants to stock up again and is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy 4 sacks of wheat flour, 10 drums of oil, some sugar, and other food items.  With her revenues, she helps to cover family expenses. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy foodstuff

loans.name: Kobada 5 De (Kobada Nokabougou) Group

texts.fr:
Les dix membres du groupe KOBADA 5  sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 43 ans, 5 enfants et vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames dans le village de NOKABOUGOU,  commune de Tingolé, sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont en  partenariat avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un appui financier pour exercer leurs activités hivernales. Leurs activités sont entre autres la culture du sorgho de l’arachide et du haricot. Elles sont à leur cinquième expérience avec l’institution, les prêts précédents ont été  tous remboursés correctement.
Ce prêt sera utilisé pour acheter de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 20 hectares.
Une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue sur les marchés de Tingolé, Marka-Coungo et Fana, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The ten members of group KOBADA 5 are married women who average 43 years of age and 5 children. They live in polygamous families in the village of NOKABOUGOU, in Tingole district within the FANA subprefecture, 2nd administrative region of Mali. They work in partnership with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso inorder to have financial support to carry out their rainy season businesses. Their businesses include among others, the cultivation of sorghum, peanuts and beans. They are on their 5th loan with the institution and all preceding loans had been correctly repaid. This loan will be used to buy fertilizers, herbicides, small agricultural equipment and to pay for the cost of weeding and plowing so as to maintain 20 hectares. A part of their produce is consumed in the family and the remaining is sold in the markets of Tingole, Marka-Coungo and Fana to a clientele composed of men and women. They intend to make an average profit of 40 000FCFA after the growing season.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plowing, fertilizers, herbicides, weeding and small equipment

loans.name: Kobada 6 De (Kobada Nokabougou) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit membres du groupe KOBADA 6  sont  des femmes mariées ayant une moyenne d’âge de 26 ans, 3 enfants et  vivant la plupart dans des familles polygames dans le village de NOKABOUGOU,  commune de Tingolé, sous préfecture de FANA, 2ème région administrative du Mali.
Elles sont en  partenariat avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso dans le but d’avoir un appui financier pour exercer leurs activités hivernales. Leurs activités sont entre autres la culture du sorgho de l’arachide et du haricot. Elles sont à leur cinquième expérience avec l’institution et tous les prêts précédents ont été remboursés correctement.
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter  de l’engrais, de l’herbicide, des petits matériels agricoles et payer les frais de sarclage et de labour pour entretenir 17 hectares.
Une partie de leur production est auto consommée et l’autre partie est vendue sur les marchés de Tingolé, Marka-Coungo et Fana, à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 40 000FCFA après la campagne.
texts.en:
The eight members of group KOBADA 6 are married women who average 26 years of age and 3 children. They live mostly in polygamous families in the village of NOKABOUGOU in Tingole district within the Fana subprefecture, 2nd administrative region of Mali. They work in partnerhip with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso in order to have financial support to carry out their rainy season businesses.Their businesses among others include the cultivation of sorghum, peanuts and beans. They are on their 5th loan with the institution and all preceding loans had been correctly repaid. This new loan will be used to buy fertilizers, herbicides, small agricultural equipment and to pay for the cost of weeding and plowing so as to maintain 17 hectares. A part of their produce is consumed in the family and the remaining is sold in the markets of Tingole, Marka-Coungo and Fana to a clientele composed of men and women. They intend to make an average profit of 40 000FCFA after the growing season.

Translated from French by Cletus Kuunifaa, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Plowing, fertilizers, herbicides, weeding and small equipment.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en: Anthonia is 41 years old, married and has four children. She makes a living selling hair extensions and cream, and is also a hair stylist. She has been in this business since 1993 in Lagos, where she lives. She is very happy and grateful to Kiva for its financial help in these hard times. Anthonia has applied for a loan to buy more hair extensions and cream to sell, and thanks Kiva participants for their support.

loans.use: To buy more hair extension and cream to sell to her customers

loans.name: Ismot

texts.en: Ismot sells baby items. She has been in this business for the past 3 years. Ismot lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is 40 years old and married with 4 children. Ismot is requesting a loan of N50,000 to purchase more baby items to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more baby items to sell

loans.name: Barakatou

texts.fr:
Madame Barakatou Sangaré est âgée de 40 ans, mariée  et mère de 5 enfants. Elle vit dans un foyer monogame avec son mari et leurs enfants à  Angoulême, un des quartiers de la ville de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Secrétaire de formation, après plusieurs années de recherches d’emploi salarié sans succès,  Barakatou  décida de s’installer à son propre en  commença le petit commerce  d’articles divers, des habits pour enfants, de l’encens, des chaussures, des pagnes wax, parfums  etc, à son domicile. Avec  une dizaine d’année d’expériences, aujourd’hui elle jouit d’une très grande réputation auprès des femmes, surtout pendant les périodes de mariage et à l’approche de la saison des pluies. 
Dans le but de satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante et d’augmenter le volume de son petit commerce, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 12 mois, après  2 prêts solidaires correctement remboursés.
Elle compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes wax et 20 paires de chaussures. Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises à Bamako et en Guinée Conakry. Ces produits sont vendus à domicile et en ambulant à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 54.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour la prise en charge de certaines dépenses familiales et rembourser les intérêts du prêt.
texts.en:
Mrs. Barakatou Sangaré, 40, is married and the mother of 5 children. She lives in a monogamous household with her husband and their children in Angoulême, a neighborhood of the town of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali).

Having trained as a secretary but having spent several years searching for work without success, Barakatou decided to set up her own business and began selling various items: clothing for children, incense, shoes, “pagnes” (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth), perfume, etc., out of her home. With around 10 years of experience, she presently is highly thought of by the women in her area, especially during periods of weddings and before the rainy season.

With the intention of satisfying the needs of her ever growing clientele and growing her little business, she came to Soro Yiriwaso. She has been working with us for 12 months and has correctly reimbursed 2 solidarity loans.

She intends to use this loan to buy 10 lengths of “pagne” and 20 pairs of shoes. She buys her merchandise in Bamako and in Guinea Conakry. The items are sold out of her home and on foot, to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 54,000 F CFA which will be used to cover certain family expenses and reimburse the interest on the loan.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: Angela produces and sells disinfectant, liquid soap and air freshener. She has been in this business since 1994. She is requesting a loan of N80,000 to purchase more disinfectant materials to enable her produce more to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more disinfectant materials to sell

loans.name: Oumou

texts.fr:
Madame Oumou Keita est âgée de 42 ans, mariée  et mère de 4 enfants. Elle vit chez son mari au quartier Bougoufié de Ségou dans une grande famille traditionnelle (4ème région administrative du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en  classe de 8ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour aider sa mère à faire les activités de petit commerce d’articles divers, habits, draps de lit, la fabrication des jus de fruits, condiments alimentaires  etc. Forte des années d’expériences passées auprès de sa mère, à son mariage, Oumou opta de perpétuer  la même activité de commerce de divers dont elle a une parfaite maîtrise. 
Le besoin de renforcer ses activités et d’augmenter ses bénéfices l’a amené à faire recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle elle collabore depuis 42 mois, après avoir correctement remboursés 5 prêts solidaires et un  prêt individuel.
 Elle compte utiliser ce nouveau prêt pour  acheter, 10 pièces de pagnes brodés et légers, 20 draps de lit, 10 douzaines de parfums, 1sac de sucre, 1/2 sac de gingembre, 1panier de feuilles d’oseille de Guinée et des essences pour le jus. Elle s’approvisionne au Burkina Faso pour les habits (tissus brodés et de légers) et les draps, sur place pour les produits et ingrédients des jus locaux. Elle vend ses articles à domicile et en ambulant dans les quartiers de la ville, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes, de femmes et aussi d’enfants.
 Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 60.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour augmenter son fonds de commerce et prendre en charge certaines dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est d’augmenter le volume de son activité et d’ouvrir une boutique de vente d’habits.
texts.en:
Mrs. Oumou Keita, 42, is married and the mother of 4 children. She lives with her husband in the Bougoufié district of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) in a big traditional family.

She left off her schooling in the basic school (8th grade in the Malian educational system) to help her mother sell various items: clothing, bed sheets, home-made fruit juices, condiments, etc. Having learned a great deal from working with her mother, Oumou decided to continue in this same business that she is very good at, after her marriage.

Needing to expand her businesses and increase her profit led her to turn to Soro Yiriwaso with whom she has been working for 42 months. She has correctly reimbursed 5 solidarity loans and one individual loan.

She intends to use this new loan to buy 10 lengths of lightweight, embroidered “pagne” (cloth traditionally used for clothing and head wraps in West Africa), 20 bed sheets, 10 dozen bottles of perfume, 1 sack of sugar, ½ sack of ginger, 1 basket of dried hibiscus flowers, and flavoring for juice. She buys her cloth and sheets in Burkino Faso and the ingredients for juice locally. She sells her goods out of her home and on foot in the neighborhoods, for cash and credit, to a clientele composed of men, women, and also children.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 60,000 F CFA which will be used to grow her business capital and cover certain family expenses.

Her ambition is to expand her business and to open a shop where she can sell garments.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary sells sarongs and microwave ovens in her shop. She has been in business for the past 4 years. She lives in Lagos State, Nigeria. Mary is 47 years old and married with 4 children. She is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more sarongs, bags and microwave ovens to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and bags to sell

loans.name: Soumba

texts.fr:
Madame  Soumba Koné est âgée de 59 ans, mère de 7 enfants, elle vit avec son mari, ses enfants et plusieurs autres ménages  au 1er quartier de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école, elle commença très tôt le commerce auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années passées à côté de cette dernière, elle bénéficia d’une solide expérience en matière de commerce. Elle opte,  sur initiative de son mari, pour la vente de fruits  depuis maintenant 11 ans. Elle maîtrise parfaitement  le créneau des fruits  et jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Pour augmenter son  fonds de commerce elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elle est en relation  depuis  54 mois. Après 7 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel, elle est à son 2ème prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter, 350 sacs de Zaban (fruits exotiques d’Afrique de l’ouest). Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages de Kalabougou et Dioro. Soumba Koné vend ses fruits au comptant, en détail et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50.000FCFA, qui lui permettra d’acheter des animaux domestiques et aider son mari dans la prise en charge des dépenses familiales. 
Son ambition est de  se construire une maison d’habitation.
texts.en:
Mrs. Soumba Koné, 59, is the mother of 7 children. She lives with her husband, children, and several other households in the First District of the town of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Never having been enrolled in school, she began to sell goods at a young age, helping her mother sell condiments. After several years of working with her mother, Mrs. Koné had gained a rich experience in sales. She chose to set up a business selling fruit, at her husband’s suggestion, 11 years ago. She is very knowledgeable in this niche market, has a considerable clientele, and is well-known.

To grow her working capital, she came to Soro Yiriwaso with whom she has been working for 54 months. After 7 solidarity loans and one individual loan, she is now on her second individual loan that she intends to use to buy 350 sacks of ‘Zaban’ (exotic fruit from West Africa). She buys her merchandise in the villages of Kalabougou et Dioro. Soumba Koné sells her fruit for cash, retail, and for credit to a clientele composed of men and women.

She expects to make a monthly profit of 50,000 F CFA which will allow her to buy some farm animals to raise and help her husband support the family.

Her ambition is to be able to build a house to live in.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of fruit for resale

loans.name: Marlene

texts.en:
Señora Marlene appears in this photo in her sewing workshop together with her 16-year-old granddaughter. Marlene's sewing workshop is located within her home. She is 57 years old and has five adult children. Her husband is a carpenter who works independently.

Marlene has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos through her communal bank, "Nuevas Amigas" (New Friends), since the communal bank's founding nine years ago. Marlene invested in the sale of candies with her very first loan of 300 soles (about $100). At that time she was also studying sewing, and has devoted herself to sewing as a full time business venture for the past seven years. Marlene plans to use this loan of 1500 soles to invest in materials for her business (including fabrics, thread, etc.). Marlene's goal is to eventually have her own boutI., complete with show windows and mannequins, where she can display her clothing.

Marlene is pleased to be working with Manuela Ramos and is grateful for the organization's financial support. Combining her own efforts with the help of loans from Manuela Ramos, she was able to purchase her sewing machine. Marlene continues to develop as a microentrepreneur.

loans.use: Materials for sewing (fabrics, thread, etc.)

loans.name: Diadiaratou

texts.fr:
Madame  Diadiaratou B. a 36 ans et vit dans une grande famille avec son époux et ses six enfants à Banconi, un des  quartiers périphériques de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Madame  Diadiaratou B.  après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès, s’est initiée à  l’activité d’achat et  de vente d’huile alimentaire il y a maintenant douze  ans. Elle mène cette activité à domicile et au marché de son quartier où elle dispose une grande table sur laquelle elle vend ses marchandises. Elle est beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant cinq ans. Après 2 prêts solidaires (prêt de groupe) dans une association des femmes de son quartier (Association Soro yiriwa de Banconi), elle est à son 5ème prêt individuel et tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 15 bidons d’huile alimentaire  dans les huileries de place avant de les revendre en détail, au comptant ou à crédit à une clientèle composée des femmes surtout. 
Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 80 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Diadiaratou B., 36, lives in a big family with her husband and her 6 children in Banconi, an outlying neighborhood of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mrs. Diadiaratou B., after having tried several businesses without success, began buying and selling food-grade oil 12 years ago. She conducts this business out of her home and in the neighborhood market, where she has a big table on which she sells her merchandise. She is much in demand with her clientele due to the quality of her products.

In order to satisfy this ever growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, 5 years ago. After 2 solidarity loans (group loans) with a women's association in her neighborhood, (Association Soro yiriwa of Banconi), she is on her 5th individual loan, and all the preceding loans have been correctly reimbursed.

With this loan she intends to buy 15 jerrycans of food-grade oil in the local oil factories to be resold retail, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed mainly of women. She expects to make a monthly profit of 80,000 F CFA with this loan. The profit will be used essentially to grow her working capital, contribute to family expenses, and pay the interest on her loan, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of cooking oil for re-sale

loans.name: Damarys Group

texts.es:
El centro focal Villa Adela esta ubicado en la ciudad de El Alto, a este pertenece la asociación “Damarys”, con la ayuda de su asistente de créditos trabajan de forma responsable y puntual.
El grupo esta formado por doce integrantes y trabajan junto a la familia de Pro Mujer hace tres años.
Diversos son los negocios que tienen este grupo, por lo general comercializan productos varios  de acuerdo a la temporada, ahora por ejemplo  venden ropa de invierno y también artículos tradicionales por las fiestas patrias. Ahora desean comprar mayor cantidad de mercadería, tienen la seguridad de obtener mejores ganancias y por lo tanto mayores ingresos para el bien de sus familias.
texts.en:
The "Damarys" Association belongs to The Villa Adela Center, which is located in the city of El Alto. Damarys collaborates in a responsible and punctual fashion with the loan assistant of the latter organization. The association is made up of a dozen members who have worked together in Pro Mujer for 3 years. This group has a variety of businesses, but in general they make a variety of products in accordance with the season. Now, for example, they sell winter clothing as well as traditional items for the national holidays. They would like to buy a larger quantity of merchandise that they will use to increase profits, and therefore income, to provide for the well-being of their families.

Translated from Spanish by Cyrus Maher, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: COMPRA DE MERCADERIA

loans.name: Famory

texts.fr:
Monsieur Famory T. est un célibataire de 27 ans qui vit dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à wayerma I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Monsieur  T. après avoir mené plusieurs activités sans succès notamment la vente de carburants, s’est initié au commerce de vente d’articles divers (eau minérale, boisson, déodorant, cartes de recharge de téléphone Malitel / Orange, du lipton  etc.)  à Wayerma I Sikasso. Il mène cette activité il y a environ trois  ans. Il est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce premier prêt, il compte acheter, 10 paquets de boisson NBB, 30 cartons d’eau minérale, 2 cartons de déodorants et 200 cartes de recharge Malitel/Orange auprès de commerçants grossistes sur place et des représentants des deux réseaux de télécommunication avant de les revendre en gros et en détail à une clientèle composée généralement des toutes couches sociales de la ville.
Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 240 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Famory T. is a bachelor of 27 who lives in a big extended traditional family in Wayerma I, one of the working class neighborhoods in the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Mr. T., after having worked at several businesses without success, notably selling fuel, began selling various items (mineral water, drinks, deodorant, telephone charge cards Malitel / Orange, Lipton's, etc.) in Wayerma I in Sikasso. He has been in this business for about 3 years. He is much in demand with his clientele because of the quality of his products.

In order to satisfy his ever-growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with whom he is on his first individual loan. With this first loan he intends to buy 10 packs of NBB drinks, 30 cartons of mineral water, 2 cases of deodorant, and 200 Malitel/Orange telephone cards from the local wholesalers and the representatives of the two telecommunications networks. He will resell them wholesale and retail, to a clientele composed of all sorts of people from the town.

With this loan he expects to make a monthly profit of 240,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow his working capital, contribute to family living expenses, and pay the interest on his loan, investing any remainder back into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of various articles for re-sale

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Âgé de 31 ans, Monsieur Mamadou T.  vit avec son épouse et son enfant  dans une grande famille traditionnelle élargie à Sanoubougou II, un des  quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
    Monsieur Mamadou T. après l’obtention du D.E.F. (Diplôme d’Etude Fondamentale du système éducatif Malien correspondant au B.E.P.C.)il abandonne les études pour s’essayer à beaucoup d’activités génératrices de revenus mais sans succès. Alors , il décida d’apprendre le commerce, notamment celui de l’achat et de la vente des téléphones portables et accessoires (façades, batteries, chargeurs, écouteurs, etc.) depuis plus de cinq ans. Il mène cette activité au carrefour du nouveau de Médine où il dispose d’une boutique. Monsieur T. est beaucoup sollicité de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. 
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, il décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso il y a environ une année. Il est à son deuxième prêt individuel après avoir remboursé  sans difficulté le  précédent. 
    Avec ce nouveau prêt, il compte acheter, 30 téléphones portables de marques différentes, 3 cartons de façades, 10 chargeurs, 20 paquets de carte mémoire, 5 grosses montres, 6 cartons de carton de batterie, 4 douzaines d’écouteurs, etc. 
   Il s’approvisionne à Bamako et pour revendre ses articles à une clientèle composée généralement de jeunes et surtout de forains qui viennent aux foires hebdomadaires tous les samedis et Dimanches.
   Il envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 200 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou T., 31, lives with his wife and child in a big extended traditional family in Sanoubougou II, one of the working-class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

After receiving his D.E.F. diploma--which, in the Malian educational system, corresponds to a Middle School leaving certificate, Mr. Mamadou T. left school to try out a number of money-earning activities, but without success. Then, he decided to learn a commercial trade, more specifically buying and selling cell phones and accessories (covers, batteries, chargers, headphones, etc.) which he has been doing for more than 5 years. He does business at a crossroads in Médine where he has a little shop. Mr. T. is much sought after by his clientele due to the quality of his products.

Wishing to satisfy his ever growing clientele, he decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso about one year ago. He is on his second individual loan after having reimbursed the preceding one without difficulty.

With this new loan, he intends to buy 30 cell phones of various brands, 3 boxes of covers, 10 chargers, 20 packets of memory cards, 5 big clocks, 6 cartons of batteries, 4 dozen speakers, etc. He buys his merchandise in Bamako and resells his wares to a clientele composed generally of young people and especially itinerant merchants who come to the weekly fairs every Saturday and Sunday.

With this loan, he expects to make a monthly profit of 200,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to add to his working capital, contribute to covering family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into his business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchasing cell phones, accessories and watches for resale

loans.name: Mariam

texts.fr:
Née le 18 Juillet 1967 à Bamako, Mariam S. est une femme mariée, mère de quatre enfants qui réside avec son époux, sa coépouse et leurs enfants à Sanoubougou I, un des quartiers populaires de la ville de Sikasso (troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
   N’ayant pas eu la chance d’avancer à l’école pour des raisons sociales,  elle s’est initiée à l’activité de  commerce d’achat et de vente des pagnes wax et des tissus brodés il y a plus de dix  ans. Elle est beaucoup  appréciée et sollicitée  de sa clientèle, surtout pour la qualité de ses produits.
   Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire cette clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida d’intégrer l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il à son premier prêt, pour acheter  8 pièces de pagnes UNIWAX, 4 complets de tissus brodés, 5 pièces de pagnes wax REAL et 5 complets de bazin “moins riche” à Bamako et à Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso).                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                          
   Elle dispose d’une place au niveau du marché de leur quartier où elle vend ses marchandises au comptant et à crédit avec une clientèle composée essentiellement des femmes.
   Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 100 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Born on July 18, 1967 in Bamako, Mariam S. is a married woman, the mother of 4 children, who lives with her husband, her co-spouse and their children in Sanoubougou I, one of the working class neighborhoods of the town of Sikasso (third administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Not having had the good fortune to make a go of her schooling for socio-economic reasons, she began buying and selling “pagnes” (lengths of brightly colored African print cloth) and embroidered cloth more than 10 years ago. She is much appreciated and sought after by her clientele, especially because of the quality of her products.

Wishing to better satisfy this ever growing clientele, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso with whom she is on her first loan, which will be used to buy 8 lengths of “pagne” of the UNIWAX brand, 4 outfits of embroidered cloth, 5 lengths of “pagne” of the REAL brand, and 5 outfits of “bazin moins riche” (locally dyed damask) in Bamako and Bobo Dioulasso (Burkina Faso).

She has a place in the neighborhood market where she sells her merchandise, for cash or credit, to a clientele composed essentially of women.

With this loan, she expects to make a monthly profit of 100,000 F CFA which will be used essentially to grow her working capital, contribute to covering family expenses, and pay the interest on the loan, investing any remainder back into her business.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of "pagnes", embroidered cloth, and damask for resale

loans.name: Salimata

texts.fr:
Madame  Salimata T.  a 41 ans et réside avec son époux et leurs enfants  dans une grande famille traditionnelle à Fama, le centre ville de Sikasso ( troisième région administrative de la république du Mali).
   Madame Salimata T. après avoir mené beaucoup d’activités sans succès, s’est finalement initiée à la fabrication des savons traditionnels (savons noirs) Il y a plus de cinq  ans qu’elle a appris cette activité auprès d’une voisine. Elle mène son activité à son domicile  et est  beaucoup sollicitée de sa clientèle pour la qualité de ses produits. Pour satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle décida de rejoindre l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elle est à son 3ème prêt individuel, tous les prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
   Elle compte acheter avec ce prêt, 10 fûts des déchets d’huile de coton (pâtes noires), 5 sacs de soude caustique et 4 chargements de charrette en bois de chauffe. Après la fabrication des savons (auxquels on peut donner plusieurs couleurs marron,  blanche, mais généralement noire d’où son appellation) à base de déchets d’huile de coton et de soude caustique, elle les revend en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée généralement des femmes de sa localité..
   Elle envisage réaliser avec ce prêt un bénéfice mensuel de 120 000 FCFA qui sera utilisé essentiellement pour augmenter son fonds de commerce, contribuer aux dépenses familiales, payer les intérêts de son prêt et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Ms. Salimata T. is 41 years old and resides with her husband and their children in a large traditional family in Fama, the downtown of Sikasso (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). After having run many businesses unsuccessfully, she was introduced in the end to making traditional soaps (black soaps) over five years ago.  She learned this business from one of her neighbors.  She operates in her home and is in high demand by her customers for the quality of her products.  To satisfy her growing customer base, she decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso and is now on her third individual loan.  All the preceding loans have been correctly repaid.  Salimata intends to use this loan to buy 10 drums of waste cotton oil (black pastes), 5 sacks of caustic soda, and 4 cart loads of firewood.  After making the soap (to which several colors may be added: brown, white, but generally black, from which the name comes) out of waste cotton oil and caustic soda, she then sells the soap retail, cash or credit accepted, to customers generally composed of women in her town. With this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 120,000 francs CFA that will be used essentially for: increasing her business capital, helping to cover family expenses, paying the loan interest, and investing the rest in her business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy waste cotton oil, caustic soda, and firewood

loans.name: Mujeres Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
Dieciocho miembros deciden conformar la asociación “Mujeres Emprendedoras”, vieron la necesidad de tener un negocio propio que les permita obtener ingresos para solventar la economía de sus hogares. 
Este es un grupo nuevo que se reunirá en el centro focal Villa Adela, su presidenta es Rosario Vargas.
Distintos son los negocios  de este grupo, por ejemplo venta de abarrotes, elaboración y venta de salchipapas Y hamburguesas, fabricación de calzados, venta de jugos y batidos, entre otros. La asociación Mujeres Emprendedoras necesita comprar mercadería o insumos para iniciar sus negocios, esto les permitirá obtener ingresos para ofrecer mejor calidad de vida a sus familias.
texts.en:
Seeing the necessity of having their own business, which would provide them with income to settle their household expenses, eighteen members decided to form the association “Mujeres Emprendedoras”. This is a new group that will meet in the Villa Adela center. Rosario Vargas is the group’s president.

The group businesses are diverse and include the selling of groceries, making and selling “salchipapas” (fast food made of sausages and potatoes) and hamburgers, shoes manufacturing, selling juices and smoothies, among others.

The “Mujeres Empreendedoras” association needs to buy merchandise and raw materials to start its business. This will provide them with income so that they can offer a better quality of life to their families.

Translated from Spanish by Giovanna Fernandes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise and supplies

loans.name: Ramatou

texts.fr:
Né vers 1976 à Koutiala, environ 33 ans , Madame Ramatou Konaté est mariée et mère  de 2 enfants. Elle vit  dans un foyer polygame dans le quartier Médina Coura  de la préfecture de Koutiala ( Région de Sikasso ). 
Elle est titulaire d’un diplôme de Brevet de Technicien  en comptabilité et animatrice au niveau d’une radio dans  la ville de Koutiala. En plus de son activité radiophonique, Ramatou  mène des activités génératrices de revenus  depuis plus de 7 ans. Elle fait beaucoup plus le commerce d’articles divers, chaussures, habits, bijoux etc.  
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle de plus en plus croissante, elle fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  depuis maintenant 5 ans.   Après  4 prêts  solidaires (prêt de groupe), elle  est à son  8 ème  prêt individuel. Tous les  prêts précédents ont été correctement remboursés.
Ramatou compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter une importante quantité de marchandises d'articles divers à Bamako (la capitale du Mali). Elle effectue ses ventes en ambulante dans les différentes entreprises  et  quartiers de la ville de Koutiala,  à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’hommes, au comptant, en détail et à crédit.  
Elle compte réaliser un  bénéfice mensuel de 90 000 FCFA qu’elle utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts de Soro Yiriwaso, contribuer à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.  
Dans l’avenir elle compte ouvrir une boutique  dans le marché de Koutiala.
texts.en:
Born around 1976 in Koutiala and about 33 years old, Mrs. Ramatou Konaté is married and the mother of 2 children. She lives in a polygamous home in the neighborhood of Médina Coura, in the prefecture of Koutiala (Region of Sikasso). She has a "Brevet de Technicien" diploma in accounting and teaches the subject on a radio station in the city of Koutiala. In addition to her activities on the radio, Ramatou has had another business to create revenues for the past 7 years. She does a lot of business selling a variety of items, shoes, clothes and jewelry etc.

In order to satisfy the needs of her clientele, which is growing more and more, she has worked with the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso for 5 years now. After completing 4 group loans, this is her 8th individual loan. All of her previous loans were fully and properly repaid.

Ramatou will use this loan to buy a large quantity of various items of merchandise in Bamako, the capital of Mali. To sell her merchandise at retail prices, she walks around the different business and neighborhoods in the city of Koutiala, to a clientele of men and women. She sells her merchandise for cash and credit.

She will earn a monthly profit of 90,000 FCFA that she will use to repay the interest of her loan to Soro Yiriwaso, to contribute to improving the conditions of her family's life and invest the remainder in her business. In the future, she hopes to open a store in the market of Koutiala.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a variety of merchandise

loans.name: Edamaria

texts.es:
La señora Edelmira M. P. reside en el municipio de Somotillo de la ciudad de Chinandega donde ha unido sus esfuerzos para lograr un sueño que por mucho tiempo ha tenido como lo es la reconstrucción de su casa de habitación con el propósito de mejorar las condiciones de vida de sus cuatro hijos que requieren del apoyo de su madre.

Ella ha decidido invertir en la compra de los materiales de construcción y para ello ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar el crédito oportuno ya que le urge continuar con la obra de reconstrucción y al final ver logrado su sueño de beneficiar a sus pequeños en su nivel de vida y brindarles un techo digno donde habitar.
texts.en:
Señora Edelmira M. P. resides in the municipality of Somotillo of the city of Chinandega where she has focused all her efforts to achieve a dream that she has had for a long time, namely the reconstruction of her house. The purpose of the loan is to improve the living conditions of her four children that require the support of their mother. She has decided to invest in the purchase of the building materials and for this she has approached Ceprodel to request credit since she is hard-pressed to continue with the work of reconstruction. In the end she would like to see her dream achieved to benefit her small children in their standard of living and to offer them a worthy home to live in.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy construction materials for her home.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Yacouba

texts.fr:
Âgé de  30 ans, Yacouba  T.  vit avec ses épouses et ses trois enfants dans une famille polygame dans un des quartiers populeux de la ville  de Koutiala, Lafiala  ( Région de Sikasso ).  
Pour des raisons familiales,  il n’a pas pu continuer  les études. C’est ainsi qu’il commença les activités  génératrices de revenus, auprès de son feu père, jadis commerçant. Après des années d’apprentissage et  fort de ses expériences, il décide d’évoluer en solo et dans le créneau des pièces détachées pour moto.  Cette activité lui procure assez de revenus et  il reçoit beaucoup de commandes dans le mois.  
Pour la bonne satisfaction de sa clientèle et l’élargissement de son activité,  Monsieur  Yacouba a fait recours à l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso  il y a 1 an. Après  avoir correctement remboursé son premier prêt, il est à son deuxième prêt   individuel.  
Ce prêt servira à acheter, une grande quantité de pièces de rechanges pour moto  « Djakarta ». Il s’approvisionne auprès  des grossistes du grand marché de Koutiala et effectue sa vente dans les villages environnants de Koutiala à une clientèle composée de femmes et hommes au comptant ou à crédit.  
 Yacouba  compte réaliser un  bénéfice de 150.000 FCFA par mois qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement des taux d’intérêts, prendre en charge les besoins de sa famille et investir le reste dans son activité.
texts.en:
Yacouba T., aged 30, lives with his wives and three children in a polygamous family, in one of the most populous neighborhoods in the city of Koutiala, Lafiala, (Region of Sikasso, Mali.) Because of the family, he hasn't be able to continue his studies. This is why he starting working alongside his late father, who was in commerce. After years acquiring valuable experience as an apprentice, Yacouba decided to spin off his own business in spare motorcycle parts. This is a successful activity which brings in lots of income and orders every month.

To expand his activities and satisfy his clientele, Mr. Yacouba took a loan from Soro Yiriwaso one year ago. After fully paying off his first loan, he is now ready for a second loan.

These funds will enable Yacouba to purchase a large quantity of spare parts for the "Djakarta" motorcycles. He purchases from wholesalers at the grand marché in Koutiala, and then sells his wares in the surrounding villages. His clients are both men and women, who pay in cash or on credit.

With this loan, Yacouba hopes to resalise a monthly benefit of 150,000 FCFA, which he'll utilize to reimburse interest expense, pay his family's living expenses, and invest the rest in his business.

Translated from French by Linda Koza, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of motorcycle spare parts

loans.name: Haoua

texts.fr:
Madame  Haoua Traoré  est âgée de 49 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans une famille monogame dans le quartier Darsalam de  Ségou   (4ème  région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas été à l’école pour des raisons sociales, elle commença très tôt à s’intéresser aux activités génératrices de revenus auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage, elle bénéficia d’une solide expérience dans le petit commerce, c’est ainsi qu’elle décide d’évoluer  en solo en menant les activités de commerce de bois de chauffe et  de charbon de bois depuis maintenant 12 ans, chez elle même. Ses ventes sont nombreuses du fait qu’elle est la seule vendeuse du bois de chauffe dans le  quartier, on la  sollicite lors des grands événements (mariages, baptêmes et  funérailles). 
Dans le souci de faire face à la clientèle afin de réaliser plus de bénéfices, elle a fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 30 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires  et 1 prêts individuel  tous bien remboursés, elle est à son 2ème  prêt individuel  qui sera utilisé pour acheter, 1 chargement de bois de chauffe et 30 sacs de charbon de bois dans le village de Sanando. Madame  Haoua Traoré vend au comptant, en détail  et   à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femme. 
Avec ce prêt elle espère réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000FCFA  qui lui permettra de finir sa maison à usage d’habitation et de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille (habillements et nourritures). 
Son ambition est de construire une deuxième maison à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
Ms. Haoua Traoré, age 49, is married and the mother of three.  She lives with her husband and children in a monogamous family in the Darsalam district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Not having gone to school due to societal reasons, she soon started to become interested in earning an income with her mother, who used to sell condiments.  After several years of apprenticeship, she has benefited from solid experience in this small business.  Thus, she decided to progress on her own by running a business selling firewood and charcoal, somethings she has been doing for twelve years now in her home.  She sells a lot because she is the only firewood vendor in her district.  People seek her out when there are major events (marriages, baptisms, and funerals).  Concerned about coping with her customers in order to realize more profit, she turned toward Soro Yiriwaso, with which she has been associated for 30 months.  After three solidarity loans and an individual loan, all repaid, she is now on her second individual loan.  This loan will be used to buy a load of firewood and 20 sacks of charcoal in the village of Sanando. She sells retail to customers composed mostly of women, cash or credit accepted. With this loan, she hopes to realize a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will enable her to finish her house and to provide for her family (clothing and food).  Her ambition is to build a second residential house.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood and charcoal

loans.name: Ernesto

texts.es:
Ernesto M. S. se dedica desde hace varios años a su trabajo de vigilancia llevada a cabo por las noches en una empresa en el municipio de Somotillo en el departamento de Chinandega. El señor Ernesto ha atravesado la necesidad de reconstruir su casa de habitación por lo que decidió brindarle mejores condiciones de vida a sus pequeños hijos iniciando la mejora a su vivienda.

Ha acudido a Ceprodel para solicitar un crédito para la compra de los materiales de construcción para dar lugar al mejoramiento de su hogar y de esta forma contribuir al bienestar habitacional de su familia y en especial de sus pequeños hijos a los que tanto ama.
texts.en:
Ernesto M. S. has been dedicated for several years to his security work, carried out at night in a business in the municipality of Somotillo in the region of Chinandega. Señor Ernesto needs to reconstruct his house in order to offer better living conditions to his small children. He is beginning the improvements to his dwelling. He has approached Ceprodel to request a credit for the purchase of the building materials in order to begin the improvement of his home and in this way to contribute to the housing welfare of his family and especially of his small children that he loves so much.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials for his house.

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: María Auxiliadora

texts.es:
Desde hace 20 años, en el municipio de Somotillo del departamento de Chinandega, por las calles anda la señora María Auxiliadora S. ofreciendo ropa ambulante con el propósito de subsistir y mejorar su condición económica.

Ella es una señora avanzada de edad pero con mucho amor al trabajo como lo es toda mujer nicaragüense. Ella ha solicitado un crédito en Ceprodel para invertirlo en la compra de ropa y de esta manera ofrecerla ambulantemente por las calles de su municipio y así continuar en su negocio.
texts.en:
For 20 years in the municipality of Somotillo of the region of Chinandega, Señora María Auxiliadora S. has walked along the streets offering clothes for sale in order to subsist and to improve her economic condition. She is a lady of advanced age but with a lot of love for her work like every Nicaraguan woman. She has requested a loan from Ceprodel to invest in the purchase of clothes so that she can offer them for sale on the streets of her municipality and thus continue in her business.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing to resell

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: María De La Concepción

texts.es:
La señora María de la Concepción Tórrez actualmente ha iniciado la labor de reconstruir su casa de habitación por las razones de que se ha venido dañando a medida que los años han venido transcurriendo. 

Ella reside en el municipio de Somotillo del departamento de Chinandega donde muy sabiamente ha solicitado un crédito para dar lugar a la compra de los materiales de construcción para continuar con la labor en su obra. Ella anhela invertir directamente en su vivienda y así brindarle mejores condiciones de vida a sus pequeños hijos.
texts.en:
Mrs. María de la Concepción Tórrez recently started rebuilding her home, since it had been damaged over the course of time. She lives in the Somotillo municipality in Chinandega Department, and has very wisely requested this loan to purchase construction materials so that she can continue improving her home. She hopes to invest directly in her house, and thus provide her children with a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials

loans.name: María Teresa

texts.es:
Durante 15 años, la señora María Teresa P. se ha dedicado a la actividad de secretaria en una empresa del municipio de Somotillo en la ciudad de Chinandega. Ella tiene la necesidad de reconstruir su casa de habitación ya que es una dama muy trabajadora y con la responsabilidad de mantener a sus tres hijos en edad escolar.

Ha acudido a Ceprodel con el propósito de solicitar un crédito para utilizarlo en la compra de los materiales de construcción ya que debe de adquirirlos a lo inmediato para dar lugar a la obra y de esta manera beneficiar grandemente a sus pequeños hijos los cuales necesitan mucho de su apoyo incondicional para tener un techo digno donde vivir.
texts.en:
For the past 15 years, Mrs. Maria Teresa P. has worked as a secretary at a company in the Municipality of Somotillo, Chinandega city. She needs to rebuild her house, since she is a very hard-working woman who is responsible for her three school-age children. She has come to Ceprodel to request a loan in order to purchase construction materials. She needs these materials immediately in order to start the project, and she expects it to greatly benefit her young children, who require her unconditional support in order to have a decent roof over their heads.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Urania Del Socorro

texts.es:
La señora Urania del Socorro M. dedica su tiempo a laborar en su municipio de Somotillo con el propósito de mejorar las condiciones de su vivienda las cual ha sido lastimada por los fenómenos naturales a medida que han atravesado los años.

La vivienda ha iniciado a ser reconstruida pero para continuar requiere del apoyo crediticio que solamente Ceprodel le brinda por lo que ha adquirido un crédito para la compra de los materiales de construcción y de esta forma salir adelante buscando la manera de  beneficiar a sus pequeños hijos con un techo digno donde habitar.
texts.en:
Mrs. Urania del Socorro M. works in Somotillo Municipality with the goal of improving her living conditions. Her house has gradually been damaged by natural phenomena over time. She has already started rebuilding her house, but in order to continue she needs the financial support that only Ceprodel can offer her. This is why she has taken out a loan in order to buy construction materials and get ahead in life. She is looking for a way to provide her young children with a decent roof to live under.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Josefa

texts.es: La señora Josefa  Somarraba tiene la edad de 47 años, reside en el barrio  Rene Cisnero en la capital de Managua, casada y con tres hijos que estudian, sus planes es mejorar las condiciones de vida para su familia, su negocio es una pulpería que desde hace quince año logro poner con los ahorros y ayuda de su esposo y con las ganancias de la venta de refrescos y golosinas. Con este préstamo quiere invertir en la compra de granos básicos y eskimo ya que tiene un freezer de venta de eskimo el cual se vende mucho por su rico sabor. Su objetivo es poder crecer en ventas para obtener mejores ganancias. Da las gracias a la institución por el apoyo con el prestamos adquirido ya que podrá fortalecer su negocio y beneficiar a su familia.
texts.en:
Mrs. Josefa Somarraba is 47 years old and lives in the Rene Cisnero neighborhood of the capital city, Managua. She is married, and has three children who are currently in school. She plans to improve her family's living conditions. Josefa runs a small grocery store, which she was able open 15 years ago thanks to her savings, her husband's help, and the money she earned selling drinks and sweets. She will use this loan to buy basic grains and Eskimo brand ice cream for her freezer. She sells a lot of this ice cream, thanks to its delicious flavor. Her goal is to sell more so that she can earn more in profits. She would like to thank the institution, because previous loans have allowed her to strengthen her business and support her family.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy basic grains and Eskimo ice cream

loans.name: Adjovi

texts.fr:
En 2008 cette femme a commencé le commerce de produits d’alimentation générale, sa manière d’accueillir ses clients fait que beaucoup de personne préfère acheter chez elle. Son stock a connu une baisse, pour cela elle sollicite un crédit pour acheter divers produits d’alimentation générale pour se réapprovisionner.
Elle est mariée et mère de 02 enfants.
texts.en:
In 2008, this woman started a grocery business. Many people prefer to buy from her because of the way she accommodates her customers. Her inventory has experience a drop. And so she is requesting a loan to buy various grocery items in order to stock up again. She is married and the mother of two children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy grocery items to sell

loans.name: Angela Del Carmen

texts.es: La señora Ángela del Carmen es una mujer con deseo de superación, su negocio es la venta de ropa que inicio con fondos propios hace cinco años, tiene 47 años de edad, reside en el barrio 380 en la capital de Managua, casada y con un hijo de 11 años de edad, que cursa su primaria. Con este crédito es su séptimo ciclo en Afodenic el cual da las gracias por que ha podido mejorar su vivienda como incrementar sus ventas con esta solicitud va a comprar materiales de construcción para poner cielo razo y poder estar en buenas condiciones con su familia. sus planes es incrementar sus ventas para obtener mejores ingresos y poder dar estudio a sus hijo.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ángela del Carmen is a woman with a strong desire to get ahead in life. She sells clothing, a business she launched with her own money five years ago. She lives in the 380 neighborhood of the capital city of Managua, is married and has an 11-year-old son who is currently in primary school. This is her seventh loan from Afodenic, and she would like to thank the institution because it has helped her improve her home and boost her sales. With the requested loan, she will buy construction materials to install ceiling panels in order to improve her family's living conditions. She plans to improve her sales in order to earn more and educate her son.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy construction materials to install ceiling panels

loans.name: Bertha Leonor

texts.es: La señora Bertha Leonor tiene la edad de 34 años, casada y con un hijo estudiante de la primaria, reside en el barrio Memorial Sandino, su esposo se desempeña como Mecánico Automotriz, su negocio es la venta de productos nutricionales, inicio con la necesidad de apoyar  a su esposo con los gastos ya que todo esta caro y poder cumplir con las metas en terminar de construir su casa ya que es muy pequeña donde habita y quiere hacer un anexo para poder tener comodidad. Da las gracias Afodenic por el apoyo con el préstamo ya que a través de ello ha logrado hacer las mejoras a su vivienda.
texts.en:
Señora Bertha Leonor is 34 years old, married and has a son who is a student in grade school. She resides in the neighborhood of Memorial Sandino. Her husband works as an Automobile Mechanic. Her business is the sale of nutritious products. She begin her business because of the need to support her husband with the expenses, since everything is so expensive. She also wanted to achieve their goal of finishing the building of their house, since the place they live is very small and she wants to add an annex to be able to have more comfort. She gives thanks to Afodenic for the support of the loan since through it she has managed to do the improvements to her dwelling.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy building materials to build an addition to her house

loans.name: Jeffer Omar

texts.es: El joven Jeffer Omar, empezó a trabajar en la venta de ropa, zapatos y productos de cosméticos para obtener ingresos ya que tiene una familia y desea salir adelante, su esposa le tiene una niña de 4 años de edad. Tiene 22 años de edad, reside en la comunidad Ciudad Sandino en la capital de Managua, tiene tres años de administrar este negocio. Este es su primer crédito en Afodenic el cual quiere invertir en la comprar de carteras, zapatos, y ropa para vender variedad a sus clientes. A futuro espera crecer en inventario y tener mejores utilidades y poder ahorrar para poder comprar su propia casa.
texts.en:
The young man Jeffer Omar began working in the sales of clothes, shoes and cosmetic products to earn income since he has a family and wishes to get ahead. His wife has a 4 year old little girl. He is 22 years old, and lives in the community Sandino City in the capital of Managua. He has been managing this business for three years. This is his first loan with Afodenic, and he wants to invest it in the purchase of purses, shoes and clothing in order to sell a variety to his customers. In the future, he hopes to grow his inventory and have greater profits, and to be able to save in order to be able to buy his own home.

Translated from Spanish by Amy McGinty, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy clothes, shoes, and purses

loans.name: Evelin Brandy

texts.es:
La Srta. Evelin B. Salazar M. tiene 19 años, es soltera y vive en casa de sus padres. Viven en una zona netamente lechera no muy alejada de la ciudad.

Es una persona muy responsable y emprendedora ya que tiene su propio ganado desde hace 4 años. Empezo a trabajar desde muy joven, ayudando primeramente a su madre y una ves que tuvo la suficiente experiencia y dinero para invertir en su propio ganado, lo hizo y siguio trabajando para mejorar sus ingresos. 

Ahora requiere de dinero para poder comprar mas alimento para su ganado y quiere comprar una vaca lechera mas. Esto repercutira positivamente a su produccion, incrementando sus ingresos. Quiere poder ahorrar para poder terminar sus estudios en un instituto al que acudia.
texts.en:
Señorita Evelin B. Salazar M. is 19 years old. She is a single woman and lives at the home of her parents. They live in a dairy-farm zone not very far away from the city. She is an enterprising and very responsible person, since she has had her own cattle for 4 years. She began to work at a young age, primarily helping her mother. Once she had sufficient experience and money to invest in her own cattle, she did so and continues working to improve her income. Now she requires money to be able to buy food for her cattle and she wants to buy one more dairy cow. This will have a positive effect on her production, increasing her income. She wants to be able to save so she can finish her studies in an institute that she attends.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food for her dairy cattle and one more cow.

loans.name: Alejandro Jose

texts.es:
El señor Alejandro José C. tiene 33 años de edad, reside en el barrio Linda Vista en la capital de Managua, casado  su esposa le tiene un hijo de 16 años de edad, que estudia, ella se desempeña de administradora. Don Alejandro José es oficial de mantenimiento  desde hace tres años, es inicio como ayudante. Con este crédito es el segundo ciclo en Afodenic el cual comprara pulidora y compresor. Su objetivo es poder tener un equipo completo para poder trabajar por cuenta propia, y poder obtener mejores beneficios. Su meta es poder terminar su carrera ya que estudia ingeniería civil y dar a su familia la mejor comodidad. Da las gracias a la institución por el apoyo con los prestamos ya que lograra sastifacer las necesidades.
.
texts.en:
Mr. Alejandro José C. is 33 years old and lives in the nieghborhood of Linda Vista in the capital Managua. He is married and has a 16 year old son who attends school. His wife is an administrator.
