texts.es:
Dionisia es socia del Bancomunal Jesús de Praga. 
Dionisia es  casada tiene 55 años, tiene cinco hijos que trabajan,
Dionisia  solo se dedicaba a su casa, pero su mamá le pidió que le  ayudara en su tienda por que ya estaba  muy anciana y sufría de asma, de repente su mama murió y cerraron la tienda, allí ella aprendió mucho sobre negocio sus hermanos le regalaron un carrito sanwichero y se puso a vender en la puerta de su casa pollo broster sandwich, salchi-papas.
Dionisia necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, para la compra  mayonesa, papas, pollo. 
Desde que Dionisia esta en Finca aprendió la importancia de ahorrar y lo esta logrando y su economía ha mejorado.
El sueño de Dionisia  es  tener un restaurante
texts.en:
Dionisia is a member of Jesús de Praga community bank. She is 55 years old and has 5 children that are working. Dionisia used to only work at home, but her mother asked her to help with her store because she was old and suffering from asthma. When her mother died suddenly and the store had to be closed, Dionisia learned a lot about business. Her brothers gave her a sandwich cart and she began to sell roast chicken sandwiches and salchi-papas (fast food consisting of hot dogs and french fries) from her doorway. Dionisia needs a loan of 2,000 PEN to buy mayonaise, potatoes, and chicken. Since Dionisia has been with Finca she has learned the importance of saving; she is currently saving and her financial situation has improved. Dionisia's dream is to open a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase mayonaise, potatoes, and chicken.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: Las ganas de progresar de Rosa son una de las prioridades en su familia, por lo cual trabajan cada uno de los miembros por el bienestar de su hogar. Su don es la cocina y también su mejor estrategia de trabajo, ya que en comparación con las diversas vendedoras, busca brindarles a sus clientes platillos de calidad que agraden a su paladar, lo cual hasta la fecha ha resultado. Sin embargo, el móvil de comida donde trabaja se ha ido deteriorando y perjudicando su negocio, ya que es la única forma de trasladarse a las diversas calles de su ciudad, siendo esta, una de las limitaciones que tiene ahora. Su ritmo de trabajo demanda mucho esfuerzo, empieza a las 6 de la tarde hasta la 1 de la madrugada, horario  que es de gran demanda de comida en su localidad. Ahora Rosa espera seguir trabajando, ya que sus anhelos son de conseguir pronto un puesto estable de comida para dejar de salir a las calles y vivir una vida más tranquila. Rosa ya ha trabajado con MFP 30 préstamos, los cuales le permitieron desarrollar su negocio y conformar un buen equipo de trabajo con sus compañeras de grupo, con quienes está muy acostumbrada a trabajar. Con los 2000 soles que viene solicitando reparará su móvil de comida, pues requiere seguir trabajando con normalidad vendiendo sus platillos de comida.
texts.en:
The desire to get ahead is one of the priorities for Rosa’s family. Everyone in her family works in order to support each other’s well-being. Rosa has a talent for cooking and it is also the best way for her to earn a living. Compared to other food vendors, she tries to offer her customers quality dishes that appeal to their tastes. So far, she has been able to meet those expectations. However, the mobile food cart that she uses for her work has been deteriorating and is hindering her business. This is the only way for her to move through the different streets of the city, so this is a major limitation that she faces right now. Her work schedule demands much effort, starting at 6pm and finishing around 1am. During this time, there is a great demand for prepared foods in this location. Rosa hopes to continue working and desires to get a stable job as a cook so that she can quit street vending and live a quiet life.

Rosa has worked with MFP on 30 previous loans. This has helped her develop her business and build a good support team with her fellow communal bank members with whom she is very accustomed to working. She will use her loan of 2000 soles to repair her mobile food cart so that she can work normally and continue selling her prepared dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Repair her mobile food cart

loans.name: Maria

texts.es:
Préstamo anterior: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=92186&_tpos=1&_tpg=1
Maria  es socia del Bancomunal Jesús de Praga
Maria ha empezado a trabajar limpiando casa y también esta dedicándose a despancar ají.
El préstamo le esta ayudando en su negocio de cerrajería que tiene con sus esposo. 
Necesita un crédito de 3000 soles para comprar fierros.
El sueño de Maria es tener otro taller más grande, por que su garaje ya quedo muy pequeño.
texts.en:
Previous loan: http://www.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id=92186&_tpos=1&_tpg=1 Maris is a member of Jesús de Praga community bank. She has begun cleaning homes and also husking ají (Peruvian chilis). The loan is helping her with the locksmith business she has with her husband. She now needs a loan of 3000 soles ($1025) to buy tools. Maria's dream is to have another larger shop because her garage is already too small.

Translated from Spanish by Amani Roland, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy tools

loans.name: Elza

texts.es: Elza tiene 53 años, como madre, sola tuvo que educar a sus 5 hijos, a quienes trató de ofrecer las mejores condiciones de vida. Desde joven trabajó en múltiples actividades, ahora se dedica a la venta de dulces en la puerta de su casa. Sus hijos ya son mayores, entonces ahora sólo requiere lo necesario para sus necesidades personales. Esta actividad le viene respondiendo de manera favorable, ya que su domicilio está ubicado en una de las avenidas más transitadas de su comunidad. Aprovechando esta concurrencia, Elza desea instalar un puesto de comida en la esquina de su casa, donde las personas ya están acostumbradas a visitar, para ello trabajaría durante todo el día, ya que la venta de dulces sólo la realiza por las tardes, cuando los escolares salen de sus centros de estudios; pero con el puesto de comida tendría la posibilidad de incrementar sus ganancias diarias. Es así que sus deseos de progresar la motivan a seguir trabajando como hasta el día de hoy. Lleva 5 años trabajando con MFP, donde ya tiene 9 préstamos y lo que más le gusta es el entusiasmo y compromiso que hay en cada una de sus compañeras por salir adelante y ver el progreso de su banco comunal. Los 1500 soles que solicita le permitirán adquirir los productos e ingredientes necesarios para seguir trabajando en su negocio y para la pronta posibilidad de tener su puesto de comida.
texts.en:
Elza is 53 years old and is a mother who educated her five children and always tried to offer them the best possible living conditions. Since she was very young, she has worked in a variety of activities, and she is now selling sweets from the door of her home. Her children are now adults, so she only needs to earn enough to pay for her personal needs. This business has been going quite well, since her home is located on one if the busiest streets in her community. Elza wants to take advantage of the location by opening a food stand at the corner near her house, where people are already used to stopping by. She currently only sells sweets in the afternoons, since that's when children get out of school, but she plans to start working all day long selling food in order to increase her daily income. Her desire to get ahead in life inspires her to keep working as she has up to this point. She has been working with Microfinanzas Prisma for five years now, and has already taken out 9 previous loans. Her favorite part is the enthusiasm and commitment displayed by her fellow group members to getting ahead and seeing the group make progress. The requested loan of 1,500 soles will allow her to buy the products and ingredients necessary to continue selling sweets, and open up the possibility of starting her own food stand soon.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy ingredients to make sweets

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Carmen Martha

texts.es:
Préstamo anterior: http://partners.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id= 92194&_tpos=7&_tpg=1
Carmen es socia del Bancomunal Jesús D. Praga.
Carmen ha empezado a vender golosinas, fruta  en su casa, también esta vendiendo vinos que esta trayendo del sur D. Chincha. 
Carmen necesita un préstamo D. 2200 soles, para la compra D. herramientas, va comprar una vitrina  mostrador.
El préstamo esta ayudando a surgir en su negocio.
El sueño D. Carmen es que su negocio crezca y  darle educación a su nieto por que su nuera murió.
texts.en:
First Kiva loan: http://partners.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id= 92194&_tpos=7&_tpg=1 Carmen is a member of the Jesús D. Praga Village Bank. She has started selling sweets and fruit from her home, in addition to wines, which she brings up from southern Chincha. Carmen needs a loan of 2200 soles to buy tools and a display case. The loan is helping her get ahead with her business. Her dream is to expand her business and and educate her grandson, since her daughter-in-law died.

Translated from Spanish by Cynthia McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tools and a display case

loans.name: Florencia Elvira

texts.es:
Florencia es socia del Bancomunal Jesús de Praga
Florencia es  conviviente tiene 50 años, tres hijos  mayores que trabajan.
Florencia  se dedicaba a dar desayuno en el distrito de surquillo era ambulante, se le presento la oportunidad de viajar a Argentina a trabajar por una temporada, cuando regreso a Perú ella se fue a vivir a un Pueblo Joven se asocio con varias señoras y pusieron un comedor popular, funciono varios años, pero las socias se retiraron, ella se dedico  a dar menú.    
Desde que Florencia esta en Finca  aprendió a trabajar esforzadamente para cumplir con los pagos que le prestan, y cumplir su sueño.  
Florencia necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles,  la compra de arroz, azúcar, aceite.
El sueño de Florencia es abrir un restaurante.
texts.en:
Florencia is a member of the Jesús de Praga Community Bank. Florencia, 50, is in a common law marriage and has three grown children who work. Florencia was a street vendor selling breakfast in the Surquillo district. She had the chance to travel to Argentina to work for a while. When she returned to Peru, she went to live in a Pueblo Joven (nickname for a shanty town). She got together with other women and they set up a popular eating spot. That worked for several years, but the members retired. She then began sell set menu meals. Since Florencia has been with Finca she has learned to put much effort into her work in order to make her payments on the loans and to fulfill her dream. Florencia needs a loan for 1,000 PEN to buy rice, sugar, and oil. Florencia’s dream is to open a restaurant.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy rice, sugar, and oil

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Préstamo anterior: http://partners.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id= 92198&_tpos=7&_tpg=1
Olga es socia del Bancomunal Jesús de Praga.
Olga se sigue  dedicando a la confección, tiene un taller de confecciones
El préstamo esta ayudando a crecer en su negocio, esta repartiendo mercadería a Grau
Olga necesita un préstamo de 2000 soles, para la compra de tela polar, forros.  
El sueño de Olga sigue siendo el mismo es  tener mas maquinas, mas personal y  comprar su casa.
texts.en:
Previous loan: http://partners.kiva.org/app.php?page=businesses&action=about&id= 92198&_tpos=7&_tpg=1 Olga is a member of the Jesús de Praga Community Bank. Olga makes clothes, and she has a sewing shop. The loan is helping her business grow. She delivers her merchandise to Grau. Olga needs a loan for 2,000 PEN to buy polar fabric and lining. Olga’s dream is to keep doing the same, have more machines, more personnel, and to buy a house.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy polar material and lining

loans.name: Carlos Felipe

texts.es:
Carlos  es socia del Bancomunal Jesús de Praga
Carlos es  soltero no tiene hijos, se dedica atrabajar.
Carlos estaba estudiando matemáticas en la universidad  particular de paga, lamentablemente dejo la universidad  por falta de dinero, se puso a trabajar con una señora  haciendo pasteles y repartiéndolos  a las bodegas y mercados, el invierte en este negocio.
Desde que Carlos esta en Finca  tiene un apoyo económico, apoyo de las socias, aprendido ha  mucho de cómo funcionan los Bancomunales y  a ser responsable con los prestamos.  
Carlos necesita un préstamo de  de 1200 soles,  va comprar harina azúcar, leche, huevos para hacer pasteles. 
El sueño de Carlos es tener su propio negocio de pasteles.
texts.en:
Carlos is a member of the Jesús de Praga Community Bank. Carlos is single, and he does not have children. He devotes himself to his work. Carlos studied mathematics in a private university. Unfortunately, he left the university for lack of money. He started working with a lady making cakes and delivering them to stores and markets. He invests in this business. Since Carlos has been with Finca he has economic support, support from the members, and he has learned a lot about how community banks work and how to be responsible with the loans. Carlos needs a loan for 1,200 PEN. He will buy flour, sugar, milk, and eggs to make cakes. Carlos’ dream is to have his own cake business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy flour, sugar, milk, and eggs to make cakes

loans.name: Pen

texts.en: Pen K., born in 1975, is a married father caring for two teenagers who are attending school.  He currently helps meet family obligations as a fisherman, while his wife sells a variety of vegetables in the market to earn a daily profit. They also cultivate rice, but the entire yield is consumed by the family. Pen is now requesting a loan, 60% of which will be used to expand his wife’s vegetable business and the rest to purchase additional fishing equipment.

loans.use: To grow his wife’s vegetable business and to buy extra fishing equipment.

loans.name: Koy

texts.en: Koy H. is 51-year-old married man and father. He lives with other family members in his own small family home in Siem Reap Province. He owns a piece of land that he inherited from his grandmother. He grows different kinds of crop on his land, such as cabbages, cucumbers, and morning glories, which he will sell to buyers every two or three months when the plants mature. His wife, wH. appears in the photo, has grown these crops with him. The couple is married and has five school-aged children. Because of their farm is outside of a watering system, Koy H. would like a loan to buy a pumping machine for irrigation. He proposes to use the remainder of loan to purchase fertilizer and seed.

loans.use: To buy a pumping machine for irrigation

loans.name: Mao

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Mao, age 22, sells fish that her husband catches. Mr. Nimol Mach has been a fisherman for four years. The couple also grows vegetable to sell in the Prek Anhchanh market. S. is applying for her first loan of $500 to purchase fishing nets and a boat for her husband’s fishing business.

S., and her husband, Mr. Nimol Mach, age 28, live along National Road No. 6, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2006 and have one young son. Besides her son, she also has her mother living with her.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and a boat

loans.name: Pel's Group

texts.en:
This group of borrowers consists of four low-income people who live together in Chong Kneas Commune, in Siem Reap province. Mrs. Pel L., age 35, has been selected to be the leader of group. To earn a living, Pel L. and her husband have been working as fishermen since earL. 2000. They both depend on the fish in and around Tunle Sap River, and they can catch over 10 kilos of fish each day to sell at the local market. Five of their children are going to school and help fishing. RecentL., this famiL.’s productivity has decreased due to frequentL. broken fishing equipment. Therefore, Pel L. has requested a loan to buy more tools and to repair some tools that are broken.

The other borrowers who have jointL. taken this loan are: Pel T., who will be using the loan to purchase additional tools for fishing operations. Pel H., a fish catcher, who is asking for a loan to decorate and repair her house. Pel H., who will use her loan to buy extra nets and traps for fishing.

loans.use: To buy more tools and to repair old tools

loans.name: Soeung

texts.en:
Mrs. C., 39, and her husband, Mr. Sovanra Long, 30, live along the National Road Number 4, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They have been married since 2008 and have no child yet. 

C. and her husband are garment factory workers. The couple wants to repair their house that has worn out in some parts; but they don’t have the money. Hence C. is asking for her first loan of $1,000 to make the repairs.

loans.use: To repair her house

loans.name: Chhum

texts.en:
Mrs. O. Chhum and her husband, Mr. Rean Kroeun, were married in 1971 and have 5 children, of whom one son is a construction worker, and four daughters: two weave silk at home and two attend school. The family lives on an Island of Mekong River, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

O. used to be a silk weaver; but she has transferred her loom to her daughters. She now spins silk to help her daughters in the weaving business. Mr. Rean Kroeun is a farmer. O. is requesting a loan of $1,000 to purchase silk materials for her daughters’ weaving business and to repair her house.
.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for her daughter’s weaving business and repair her house

loans.name: Sang

texts.en:
Mrs. M. Sang, 34 (pictured with her son), lives along National road number 1, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has been married since 2000. She has four sons: one attends school and other three are still young and stay at home.

M. has been growing rice and vegetables for 7 years. Her husband, Mr. Sarith Vit, 29, has been a fisherman for 7 years. He catches fishes from the lake nearby his house. M. is asking for her first loan of $500 to purchase a boat for her husband’s fishing business and for growing vegetables.

loans.use: To purchase a boat for her husband’s fishing business and for growing vegetables

loans.name: Sâl

texts.en: S. is a 27-year-old married father. He owns a medium size phone shop next to his house in the village where he provides phone-repairing service. He also buys used phones at reasonable prices from people in the village and then sells out to gain profit. He started his service early 2008, and he earns ~$4 per day that mainly serves to meet his family’s daily expense. His wife manages household work and plants few vegetables to generate some income. S. wants a loan to buy a computer to provide phone music service to his customers, and buy old mobile phones for sale. He and his wife are pictured above.

loans.use: To buy a computer to provide phone music service

loans.name: Ke

texts.en:
Mrs. Y. Ke, 41, and her husband, Mr. Touch Soeur, 38, were married in 1996 and have two children: one son and one daughter, both of whom are in primary school. The family lives along National Road Number 1, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

Y. was hired by the villagers to spin thread for income. Her husband has been a baker for 20 years. He works at a bakery shop located in Phnom Penh. She is applying for her first loan of $600 to purchase two more spinning devices for her thread-spinning business.

loans.use: To purchase two more spinning devices for her thread-spinning business

loans.name: Chean

texts.en:
Mr. V. Chean, age 30, has been a fisherman for three years. In addition, he works in house construction. His wife sells the fish that he catches in the local market. Some of his fishing materials have broken down, disrupting his business. So he is applying for his first loan of $500 to purchase fishing nets and a boat for his business.

V. and his wife, Mrs. Hoy Hamm, age 24, live along National Road No. 6, about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 2002 and have three children: two sons and one daughter. Besides their children, they also have his mother living with them.

loans.use: To purchase fishing nets and a boat

loans.name: Doem

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Doem, 47, is a widow living in a small village, a suburb of Phnom Penh. She has been working for a company that produces noodles for two years. She doesn’t have her own transportation and always spends a lot of money on motor taxis. So she has requested her first loan of $1,000 to purchase a motorcycle for commuting to work as well as for her family to use. It would be better for her to cut down on some expenses caused by relying on motor taxis.

S. has three sons and one daughter. Three of them have full-time employment in Phnom Penh. They work for a company that produces pure water. Another one is in school.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike to drive to work

loans.name: Pai

texts.en:
Mr. M. Pai, 29, has been a driver for a company for six years. His wife just started selling vegetables in 2009. He is asking for his first loan of $400 to in order to repair the house where he lives.

M. and his wife, Mrs. Savorn Ngin, 26, live along National Road No. 1, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They were married in 2000 and have two children: one son and one daughter. All of their children are in school.

loans.use: For house repair

loans.name: Khan

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Khan, 33, has been a silk weaver for eight years – a skill she learned from her sister. She sells her finished products to a middleman in the village, who then takes them to sell at the market in Phnom Penh. Her husband, Mr. Chamroeun Chea, 36, has been a mason for about seven years.

S. has requested one previous loan from Kiva through MAXIMA. Now she is asking for a second loan of $1100 US to purchase silk materials to continue her silk weaving business.

S. and her husband live in a small village across the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They married in 1995 and have two children: one son and one daughter. Both children are in school and assist their mother with the silk weaving business when they are not in school.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials for a silk weaving business

loans.name: Phun

texts.en:
Mrs. K. Phun, 23, and her husband, Mr. Savun Pork, 33, live in a small village across the Mekong River, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2001 and have three sons: one attends school, and the other two are still young and stay at home.

Since five years, K. has been into silk weaving, a skill she learned from her neighbor. Her husband is also a silk weaver. They sell their finished products to a middle man in the village, who in turn sells in the Phnom Penh market.

K. is requesting her first loan of $400 to purchase silk material for their silk-weaving business.

loans.use: To purchase silk material for their silk-weaving business

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Miss. S. Morn, 25, is single (pictured above with her mother), and lives with her brothers and sister along the National Road Number 1, about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

S. has been working as a tailor for two months. She operates the business at her house. Her mother is 63 years old but is still able to run her own farming business. S. is requesting her first loan of $600 to purchase a sewing machine and help her mother’s farming business.

loans.use: To purchase a sewing machine and help her mother’s farming business.

loans.name: Keo

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Keo, 49, (pictured with her husband) has been married since 1996 and has two children: one son and one daughter, both of whom are in school. The family lives along National Road Number 1, about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh City.

S. has been selling Onsorm for 30 years. Onsorm is a kind of Cambodian cake made of sticky rice sweet or salty filling cooked in steam. S. buys ingredients from local market to produce Onsorm and then sells in her village. Her husband has been a mason for 20 years. 

S. is applying for her first loan of $700 to build additional wall behind her house and buy cow for raising.

loans.use: To build additional wall behind her house and buy cow for raising

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Mrs. S. Chum, 31, and her husband, Mr. S. Pen, 39, were married in 1998 and have three children (shown in the picture). Two of their children attend school. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number five about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

S. stays at home to take of her children, so their main source of income comes from her husband, who has full-time employment in Phnom Penh. She is requesting her first loan of $500 to purchase a motorbike for her husband for commuting to work.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for her husband to commute to work

loans.name: Morn

texts.en:
Mr. B. Morn, age 40, and his wife, Mrs. Yum Chhum, age 37, live along National Road Number 6 about 25 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. They have been married since 1989 and have five children: three sons and two daughters. All of them are in school.

B. is a fisherman and farmer. His wife has been selling groceries for four months. He is applying for his first loan of $1,000 in order to purchase a boat motor for his fishing business and buy more grocery items for his wife’s grocery business.

loans.use: To purchase a boat motor for fishing and grocery items for the grocery store

loans.name: Krey

texts.en:
Mr. C. Krey, 26, is single and lives with his parents along National Road Number 5 about 17 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia. C. has one sister who is a garment factory worker. His parents are farmers.

He has been a construction worker since 2006. The walls of his house break down and it’s difficult for his family to live, especially when the rainy season comes. Therefore, C. is requesting his first loan of $500 in order to buy wooden materials to repair the wall and fill up the land of his house.

loans.use: To buy wooden materials to repair the walls of his house.

loans.name: Ul

texts.en:
Mr. K. Ul, 28, and his wife, Mrs. Puthy Mao, 28, were married in 2004 and have two daughters. Both of them are still young. The family lives in a small village along National Road Number 6, about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, the capital city of Cambodia.

K. has been a house contractor since 2000. It’s a skill he learned from his neighbor. His wife stays at home to take care of their daughters. K. has borrowed money from Kiva through Maxima two times already. Now he is applying for another loan again of $1,000 in order to build a house where he lives.

loans.use: To build a house where he lives.

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao S. is a 23-year-old married woman with no children yet. She plans to bless a kid next year. Presently, she sells a few grocery items in a store in her home for profit purposes and typically makes around $2 of income a day to meet her family’s requirements. Almost all of her inventory she sells to her neighbors who live near her family home. In addition, she also goes to fish with her husband at Tunle Sap Lake. With this business, this family can generate revenue of $3 each day. Since the fishing business is a profitable one for the family, Sao S. is looking for a Kiva loan to purchase extra equipment for fishing activities. She hopes to decorate her old house by using the rest of loan.

loans.use: To purchase extra equipment for fishing activities

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
Violeta O. is a hardworking vendor who lives simply in the village of Santos Quezon, Isabela. She is married to Renato O. who is a farmer. Their major livelihood in the village is agriculture in which rice, vegetables and banana are the main products they usually produce every year. To help her husband earn a daily income, Violeta ventured into vending their own products. She retails in the market and sometimes in their neighborhood. Some products that are not sold in the market are sold to some of her co-villagers at a cheaper price. She enjoys doing the business and tries her best to improve it into progress.  
With the opportunity brought by Kiva lenders, Violeta was encouraged to apply for a PHP12,000 loan that will be used as additional capital for her vending business. This way, she would then able to support those small vegetable farmers in their village by catering their fruit and vegetable products to sell in the market and to sell to some buyers also. She hopes that Kiva lenders will put an eye to her business concerns and ambitions not only for herself but also for her fellow men.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Michael

texts.en:
Michael is a 33-year-old hard working father. He is married to Norla of San Leonardo Aglipay Quirino. He is a “taho’” vendor in their village. According to him, he is proud being a vendor of taho because it is a nutritious kind of food, good for the children. Aside from that, through that “taho”, he is able to support the daily needs of his family. The product is made out of soya beans. According to him, he wants to improve their way of living by patiently maintaining his business and by asking for financial assistance from KIVA amounting to PHP5,000 as additional business capital.



Michael and his wife are blessed with three children, namely: Michael Jerome - 4 years old; Lassie - 3 years old; and the youngest, Michaelo Jersey - 2 years old. His children serve as the inspiration in life to work harder for a better future. He hopes that he will able to generate KIVA’s support so that someday, he will be able to improve their poor living situation in their simple place of San Leonardo.

loans.use: As additional capital

loans.name: Ashur

texts.ru:
MLF “MicroInvest” is one of the leading microfinance organizations, rendering credit services to the population of Tajikistan. Following step of its development, MLF “MicroInvest” sees in transformation into Microloan Deposit-taking Organization. Therefore in October, 2008 MLF “MicroInvest” together with LLC “Frontiers” have founded Limited Liability Company Microloan Deposit-taking Organization “Arvand”
      “Arvand” being assignee of “MicroInvest, continues to carry out its mission which is to improve the standard of living of the population and create new opportunities for social and economic development by providing qualitative financial-technical services to entrepreneurs of Tajikistan
Самадов Ашур 1954 года рождения. Женат, имеет троих детей. Занимается куплей и продажей скота. Жена помогает по хозяйству. Ашур больше года кредитуется в нашей организации. В период кредитование он увеличил поголовье скота и тем самым увеличил прибыль своей семьи. Они откармливают баранов дома, а потом продают на скотном рынке. На запрашиваемый займ Ашур планирует купить дойную корову с теленком и он благодарен нашим кредитором за помощь в осуществлении его планов.
texts.en:
Ashur S. was born in 1954. He is married and has three children. He is involved in buying and selling livestock. His wife helps out with the household. Ashur has been working with our organization for over one year. During this period, he increased the quantity of his livestock and, thus, increased the profit for his family. They raise rams at home and then sell them at a livestock market. Ashur wants to use this loan to purchase a dairy cow with a calf and thanks all of our creditors for the help in accomplishing his goals.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a dairy cow with calf

loans.name: Nilo

texts.en:
43-year-old Nilo S. is a rice grower from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato Mindanao. He has three children. He started farming in 1988 using a three-hectare farm that he owned. According to him, his hopes and plans for the future are to buy farm equipment and send all his children to school. He likes the services of Community Economic Ventures Inc. because they are not just providing loans but training and insurance to people.

He is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from CEVI because he needs to buy sacks of fertilizers and chemicals. He is hoping that he will have a better yield compared to his previous experience.

Now, he enjoys joining in the CEVI cluster meetings and meeting other micro-entrepreneurs who wish to change their lives as well by having a business.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Mercedez

texts.en:
Mercedez B. is a 49-year-old farmer and mother of seven children. She started helping her husband, Elmer B., on the farm in 1977. They are tilling a 1-hectare farm and this is what provides her whole family the food and money they use to sustain their daily finances at home. 

She is asking for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to purchase fertilizer and chemicals. The loan will really help her achieve not just good quality rice and harvest but a bigger income for their family as well.

CEVI helps small business grow. CEVI provides their clients with not just loans but education as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Rose's Group

texts.en: M. Rose is a very hard working and friendly 50-year-old lady and the leader of Tukwatire wamu group in Jinja. She is a business lady involved in knitting and supplying sweaters to schools and individual clients. She has been in the business for two years and at the start, she was given startup capital by a certain Non Government Organization in the form of a loan and it’s from that stage that she picked up on loans. However, this is her second loan with Pearl Microfinance and she hopes to grow her business more in future so that she can own a bigger workshop and even begin training others. She also strives for her children’s continued education for a better future. Rose needs a loan to be able to stock more threads for her business since even her previous loan helped to increase stock, which in turn brought in more profits for her children’s school fees. Rose is a married lady with six children aged 30  to 12 years. Four of then are still in school.

loans.use: To buy more threads for her sweater knitting business.

loans.name: Sedqa Group

texts.en:
Sedqa is the group leader of Sedqa group. There are four members in this group and each of them wishes to take a loan to expand her business.

Sedqa wants to take a loan for her embroidery business.

Fatama wants to take a loan for her husband who has a furniture-making shop.

Salema and Shafeqa want to take a loan for their carpet-weaving businesses.

So they have requested a group loan of 40,000 Afghani. They are all pleased with this process.

loans.use: To expand her embroidery business

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a member of the Makongoro borrower group.  She is 25 years old, married,she  and a mother of 2 children.  Her children are aged 4 and 1 years.

Mariam started her own food business selling food 2 years ago, she works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $112 US).

This Mariam's first loan from BRAC Tazania.  She requests the amount of 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like rice and wheat for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Mariam hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy rice and wheat for resale

loans.name: Norberto

texts.en:
Norberto D., 57-years old, has been farming since 1960. Currently, he is tilling a one and 3/4 hectare rice field which is the bread and butter of his family. He hopes to make his farm productive and that his children will finish their studies.

Hoping for a better harvest, he would like a loan of Php 15,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. He plans to buy fertilizers and chemicals to ensure the healthy growth of his rice plants. The loan will hopefully not just give an abundant harvest but also a bigger family income.

Norberto actively participates in the CEVI cluster meetings. He has also received training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals

loans.name: Gaudioso

texts.en:
Gaudioso L., a 55-year-old rice grower in Sto. Nino, South Cotabato, learned to farm from his father, who is also a farmer. The skills that he acquired have been put to good use, enabling him to meet the demands and needs of his family.

He would like to ask for a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. The loan will really go far both in improving the size of his harvest and meeting the needs of his children.

Gaudioso chose CEVI for their wide array of services, providing not just loans to people but also education to help them grow their businesses more effectively. Now, he actively participates in the CEVI cluster meetings and has learned many things from other micro entrepreneurs who also wish to change their lives.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Zainab

texts.en:
Zainab is a member of the Rafiki borrower group,kihesa,morogoro. She is 37 years old women,she is married and a mother of four. Her children are aged 24, 18, 14, and 9 years.

Zainab started her own business selling food 3 years ago,she works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 50,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $37 US).

This is Zanab's first loan from BRAC Tanzania.  She requests the amount of 150,000 Tsh in order to buy more rice, wheat, and sugar for her business.  With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Zainab hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy rice, wheat, and sugar

loans.name: Consuelo

texts.en:
Consuelo P., a 57-year old rice grower, has three children and a supportive husband who helps her manage their small rice field. She started farming in 1972 with only a 1-hectare farm; since then, she has managed to make her business sufficiently prosperous to be able to provide education and food for her children.

Consuelo would like to ask for a loan worth Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to purchase fertilizers and chemicals. She believes that if she is be able to buy all of the necessities for her farm, she will have a better chance to achieve a bigger harvest and income.

CEVI helps small business grow, providing not only loans but also training and insurance coverage.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Jimmy

texts.en:
Jimmy A. is a 35-year-old farmer from Sto. Nino, South Cotabato in Mindanao. He is still single and what he is planning to do now, he said, is to strive more for a better income to be able to save money for his future family.

It was in 1990 that he started helping in the farm. They only have a two-hectare (5-acre) rice field, and so he really helps especially during land preparation.

Being familiar with growing rice, he understands the importance of keeping the soil fertile and keeping plants protected from insects and pests. That is why, he would like to apply for a loan of Php 15,000 to be used to buy fertilizer and chemicals. 

He said that he is very pleased with the services of CEVI. He receives not just loans but training and insurance coverage as well.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth S. is a 36-year-old resident of Guintubdan, Brgy. Ara-al, La Castellana, Negros Occidental, who is married with two school-age children and earns a living by operating a convenience store.

When Elizabeth started her business, she just sold coffee and snacks to her neighbors. She then expanded it into a "carinderia" - a small eatery that sold cooked food to her neighbors. After she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002 she used her loans to improve her business, expanding her operations to sell groceries and other goods that her neighbors might need - almost like a 7/11 store.

Elizabeth also used the loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon to improve the construction of her store which was originally built from bamboo and other light materials. She slowly reinforced the building using hollow blocks and cement for a more permanent structure. The income from her business enables her to continue fixing and improving her house as well as pay for the education of her two young children.

Now on her 15th loan, Elizabeth is borrowing PHP 19,500 so that she can restock her convenience store and have more working capital to use in her eatery business.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional working capital in her expanding business

loans.name: Jamela Group

texts.en: Jamela is the group leader of the Jamela group. There are 4 members in this group. They want to expand their business and make it larger. Jamela wants to take a loan for her husband who has a general store. Marum wants to take a loan for the business of a bakery. Gul Bibi wants to take a loan for the business of carpet weaving. Farshta wants to take a loan for her brother who has a general store. They are happy that this loan process can support the entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To expand her general store

loans.name: Abdullah Jan

texts.en:
The man who is pictured is Abdullah Jan, the son of F.. He lives in district 8 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is 47 and lives in a family of 7 members. He has got all the responsibilities of his house members and has to pay his children’s school fees and expenses. He has a shop in which he sells wood. He would like to progress his business and to make his business even larger, so he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 Afghani to purchase more wood and attract more clients to his shop in order to have a better income in the future.

He would like to mention that Kiva is an effective process which helps all the entrepreneurs to reach their aims and progress their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase more wood

loans.name: Roberto

texts.en:
Roberto P., a 54-year-old farmer and father of nine children, has been farming since 1976 and owns a one-and-one-half hectare rice field that provides his family with an income to support its needs, including school tuition and groceries. Now, he would like to request a loan worth Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. to purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

CEVI helps Roberto sustain his livelihood, providing him with loans, training, and insurance coverage..

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers and chemicals.

loans.name: Ma. Fe

texts.en: 43-year old, Ma. Fe C. is a farmer of vegetables and also helps her husband to manage a 1.5-hectare (3.75-acre) rice farm. She has six children who are going to school. Aside from their expenses for food and electricity, she also worries about the school fees and books. She would like to ask for a loan of Php 10,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. (CEVI). She wishes to buy the fertilizers and chemicals needed on her farm. She thinks that buying these things is very important in ensuring the healthy growth of the rice so as to have an abundant harvest. CEVI helps her sustain her small livelihood. She receives not just loans but education as well to help her small business grow.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and chemicals

loans.name: Hadala Group

texts.en: Hadala is the group leader of the Hadala group. There are 4 members in this group. Each of them wants to take a loan to progress their business and make it larger. So they are requesting a group loan of 40,000 Afghani. Hadala wants to take a loan for her husband who has a general store. G. Jan wants to take a loan for the business of a bakery. Zara wants to take a loan for the business of tailoring. Bibi Asafa wants to take a loan for her husband who is a taxi driver. They are very thankful to AFS and Kiva lenders who support them.

loans.use: To progress her business

loans.name: Upendo

texts.en:
Upendo is a member of the Furaha borrower group.  She is 26 years old, married, and a mother of two.  Her children are ages 8 and 3.

Upendo started her own business selling clothes 3 years ago; she works 9 hours a day and makes a monthly profit of approximately 300,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $225 US).

This is Upendo's second loan from BRAC Tazania. She requests the amount of 300,000 shillings in order to buy more clothes.  With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Upendo hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Bibi Jan Group

texts.en: Bibi Jan is the leader of the two-member Bibi Jan group, each of whom is requesting a loan to expand their businesses.  Bibi Jan wants to take a loan for her husband who has a fruits and vegetables shop. Del Jan wants to take a loan for her husband who has a clothes-selling shop. They thank you for your support.

loans.use: For expanding business

loans.name: Deograsiana

texts.en:
Deograsiana is a member the of Faraja borrower group.  She is 41 years old, married, and a mother of 2 children.Her children are ages 19 and 13. She also cares for other 1 dependent. 

Deograsiana started her own clothing business selling clothes 5 years ago; she works 8 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tanzanian shillings (about $150 US). This is Deograsiana`s first loan from BRAC Tanzania.  She requests the amount of 200,000 shillings in order to buy more clothes.

With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan Deograsiana hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Mohammad Yousef

texts.en: This is Mohammad Yousef, the son of A. R.. Fifty years old, he lives in District 8 of Kabul Afghanistan with his wife and children. He decided to construct a new house because the house they previously lived in was small and they had trouble living there. He would like to take a loan of 30000 Afghani to buy the essential construction materials for his new house. He wants to thank all Kiva lenders because this kind of program is a tremendous support for the people.

loans.use: Purchasing essential construction materials

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en: Imelda A. of Purok Auturium, Brgy. Ara-al, La Castellana, Negros Occidental, is age 42 and married with three children aged 16, 15 and 6 years old. She already owned a small "Sari-sari" or general store even before she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2001. But with the additional capital she has borrowed from NWTF-Project Dungganon during the past eight years, she has expanded her business and increased her income potential. Now her store offers a wider variety of goods for sale to her neighbors and she also makes and sells "chorizo" or sausage as well as selling charcoal. She was also able to buy a "tricycle" - a motorcycle with a side-car for passengers, which supplements her income. For her 13th loan, she is borrowing PHP 19,000 to continue expanding her business activities. The profit she earns from her business provides for the immediate needs of her family and allows her to save for her children's education. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Zawad

texts.en:
Zawad started her own clothing business selling clothes two years ago. She works four hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzanian shillings. She is a 35-year-old woman, married and the mother of one child. Her child is 10 years old. She also cares for two other dependents. Zawad is a member of the Uvumilivu borrower group in Msamvu Morogoro. 

This is Zawad`s first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more clothes. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zawad hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes

loans.name: Shgofa Group

texts.en:
Shgofa and Nafesa want to take out a loan for a carpet weaving business . Lailaw wants to take out a loan for a shop selling curtains. Sheren wants to take out a loan for her husband, who is a taxi driver. Razui wants to take out a loan for an embroidery business.

Shgofa is the leader of this group. There are five members and each of them wants a loan to expand their business. They have requested a group loan of 50,000 afghani. They admire this process so much!

loans.use: For a carpet weaving business

loans.name: Bun

texts.en:
Bun H. is an older man, 52 years old and married. He makes a living as a fisherman. His wife, Gnik Sun, who works planting different types of crop for sale, appears in the photo. The older couple are blessed with seven children, five of whom are single and the other two are married and have started new homes. Two of their sons are employed: one works as an internal staff at a hotel and the remainder work driving Tuk Tuk taxis; they both have provided their income to support their family’s living expenses.

Bun H.’s son says that he can’t make much money because his Tuk Tuk is not attractive to customers because it is too old and small. Bun H. requested a loan of $600 in order to replace his son's taxi which will permit his son to provide better service.

loans.use: To replace his son's taxi

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en:
Alicia started her own cafe business selling food two years ago. She works 18 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 150,000 Tanzanian shillings. She is a 34-year-old woman, separated from her husband, and the mother of three children. Her children are 12, 7 and 3 years old; she also cares for two other dependents. Alicia is a member of the Twiga borrower group. 

This is Alicia's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 200,000 in order to buy more rice and sugar for her business. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Alicia hopes to save money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat and sugar

loans.name: Mohammad Farid

texts.en:
Mohammad Farid is a shopkeeper who has a general store in which he sells different kinds of things. He is 35, married and the father of four children who are students at school. He is the son of G. A. and lives in Bagrami, Kabul, Afghanistan.

He wants to purchase materials for his shop for which there is a lot of demand in the market. His aim is to attract more clients and to increase his monthly income as well. He has requested an individual loan of 50,000 afghani.

Finally, he would like to express his admiration for the Kiva process.

loans.use: To buy stock for a store

loans.name: Beatha

texts.en:
Beatha started her own cafe business selling food three years ago. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 70,000 Tanzanian shillings. She is a 29-year-old woman, married and the mother of one child, who is 1 year old. Beatha is a member of the Zawadi borrower group. 

This is Beatha's second loan from BRAC  Tanzania. She requested 250,000 in order to buy more commodities for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Beatha hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for a cafe

loans.name: Zakia

texts.en:
Zakia started her own food business selling potatoes and tomatoes two years ago. She is a 20-year-old woman, single and the mother of one child. Her child is 4 years old. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tanzanian shillings. Zakia is a member of the Mafisa borrower group.

This is Zakia's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more tomatoes and potatoes for sale. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Zakia hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more potatoes, rice and tomatoes

loans.name: Ananita

texts.en: Ananita C. is a 54-year-old widow with nine adult children who lives in Hacienda Escolastica, Brgy. Mabini, C. City, Negros Occidental. Ananita owns a general store and farms sugarcane as the source of her livelihood. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has used the money she borrows to finance the operations of her business ventures. Ananita is borrowing PHP 15,000 to again fund the operations of her general store and to add to her working capital in her sugarcane farm. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store and sugarcane farm

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth started her own food business selling bites one year ago. She is a 44-year-old woman, married and the mother of five children. Her children are 26, 21, 20, 15, and 8 years old. She works 12 hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 90,000 Tanzanian shillings. Elizabeth is a member of the Uamsho borrower group. 

This is Elizabeth's first loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 200,000 Tsh in order to buy more commodities like wheat and cooking oil for her business. With the additional profit she gains from the use of this loan, Elizabeth hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more commodities for a food business

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata  Traoré  est âgée de 29  ans, mariée et  mère de 3 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants au  quartier Sido Soninkoura de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle abandonna l’école en classe de 5ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour aider sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage auprès de cette dernière, elle jouit d’une très grande expérience dans le commerce d’articles divers, notamment. la vente du bois de chauffe et du charbon de bois qu’elle mène depuis 4 ans. Étant la seule vendeuse du bois de chauffe dans son quartier, elle est très sollicitée.
Dans le souci de satisfaire sa clientèle qui augmente de jour en jour elle a décidé de  faire  recours à Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant 30 mois. Après 3 prêts solidaires et 1 prêt individuel  tous correctement remboursés, elle est à son 2ème   prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 6 chargements de camion en bois de chauffe. Elle s’approvisionne dans le village  de  Kélékou  auprès des paysans ayant une autorisation  de coupe délivrée par les autorités compétentes.
Madame  Fatoumata  Traoré  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes, parmi ses clients figurent  également quelques hommes qui sont des rôtisseurs.
Ainsi avec ce prêt elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000 FCFA, ce qui lui permettra de rembourser ses dettes, aider son mari à subvenir aux dépenses de la famille et de subvenir à ses propres besoins sans l’aide d’une tierce personne.
Son ambition est de travailler d’avantage afin d’avoir beaucoup et de préparer l’avenir de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Ms. Fatoumata Traoré is 29 years old, married, and the mother of three.  She lives with her husband and children in the Sido Soninkoura district of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). She dropped out of her 5th year of primary schooling (education system in Mali) in order to help her mother, who used to sell condiments.  After several years of apprenticeship with her, Fatoumata enjoys a great deal of experience in the commerce of various goods, especially firewood and charcoal, which she has been selling for four years.  Being the only seller of firewood in her district, she is in high demand.  Concerned about satisfying her customers, who grow in number from day to day, she decided to turn toward Soro Yiriwaso 30 months ago.  After three solidarity loans and an individual loan, all correctly repaid, she is now on her second individual loan.  She intends to use it to buy six truck loads of firewood.  She stocks up in the village of Kélékou from rural suppliers possessing a permit to cut, issued by the competent authorities.  Fatoumata sells to customers composed mostly of women, cash or credit accepted.  Among her customers are also a few men, who are roast cooks.  Thus, with this loan, she envisions realizing a monthly profit of 50,000 francs CFA, which will enable her to repay her debts, to help her husband cover family expenses, and to provide for herself without any third-party assistance.  Her ambition is to work more in order to have a lot and to make a future for her children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy firewood

loans.name: Marry

texts.en:
Marry started her own cafe business selling food three years ago. She is a 37-year-old woman, married and the mother of three children. Her children are 9, 7 and 1 years old. She works four hours a day and earns a monthly profit of 30,000 Tanzanian shillings. Marry is a member of the Zingatia borrower group. 

This is Marry's second loan from BRAC Tanzania. She requested 350,000 in order to buy more commodities like rice and sugar for her business. With the profit she gains from the use of this loan, Marry hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, sugar and wheat

loans.name: Nilda

texts.en:
Nilda R. of Prk. Duensitin, La Castellana, is 60 years old and married with five adult children.

For the past thirty-seven years she has owned and operated a general store that sells a variety of food products and other goods to the local community. Before she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2002, her store was very small, constructed with bamboo and light materials, and it barely provided for her needs. After she joined NWTF-Project Dungganon, she was able to expand her business and the income she earned also helped a lot in helping her afford the education of her children, all of whom were able to finish school.

Now that all of her children are either gainfully employed or have their own sources of income, Nilda invested her profits and loans in other business activities - she bought a motorcycle and a multi-cab van that gives her a wider distribution range for her products.

For her 12th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Nilda is borrowing PHP 25,000 which she to fund the expanding business activities of her general store.


About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her general store

loans.name: Frida

texts.en:
Frida is a member of the Kisiwani borrower group,kihesa,morogoro. She is a 23-year-old single woman. Frida started her own business selling blocks three years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 600,000 Tsh.

This is Frida's first loan from BRAC Tanzania, and she has requested the amount of 200,000 TZS to buy more blocks for sale. With the additional profits she will gain from the use of this loan, Frida hopes to save more money and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more blocks to sell.

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah N. is the single mother of three school-going children. For the last fourteen years she has been cooking food in her house to order and delivering it to specific clients around Naivasha town. Sarah was introduced to KADET through her friend and this is her first loan with the organization. She plans to buy more utensils for the ever-increasing clientele of her catering business, and also to build a bigger permanent structure for her other business of rearing and selling poultry and rabbits. In future, Sarah hopes to build her own restaurant that will not only cater for her active clients but also serve the walk in clients. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy more utensils, and to build a bigger place to keep poultry and rabbits

loans.name: Aminata

texts.fr:
Madame Aminata D. est âgée de 48 ans, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle vit dans une famille monogame avec son époux et  ses enfants au quartier Pélengana Sud de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Ayant abandonné l’école en classe de 9ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien) pour se marier, elle débuta alors le commerce dés l’âge de 10 ans auprès de sa mère qui vendait du lait en ambulant car ses parents peulhs, avaient beaucoup d’animaux. Après plusieurs années d’apprentissage auprès de cette dernière elle décida de mener  une carrière en solo, en optant pour l’achat vente de bois de chauffe depuis maintenant 14 ans. En plus du bois de chauffe, elle vend également du riz et des oignons au marché château.  
C’est dans l’optique de réaliser plus de bénéfice et de renforcer son commerce qu’elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso il y’a de cela 54  mois. Après 5 prêts solidaires et 2  prêts individuels tous correctement remboursés, elle compte  utiliser ce 3ème prêt individuel  pour acheter, 4 chargements de bois de chauffe, 2 sacs de riz et 2 sacs d’oignons. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages  aux alentours de Ségou.
Madame Aminata D. vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes et de quelques hommes (qui sont surtout des boulangers et des rôtisseurs). 
Elle envisage de réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 40 000FCFA, qui lui servira de fonds de roulement et d’aider son mari dans la prise en charge des dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aminata D., 48, is married and the mother of 8 children. She lives in a monogamous family with her husband and children in the Pélengana Sud neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali).

Having left school after the 9th grade of basic school (in the Malian education system) in order to get married, she began at the age of 10 to work, helping her mother who sold milk on foot, since her Peulh parents had lots of animals. After several years spent in apprenticeship with her mother, she decided to go out on her own, opting to buy and sell firewood, which she has now been doing for 14 years. Besides firewood, she also sells rice and onions in the “Château” open-air market.

She came to Soro Yiriwaso 54 months ago hoping to make more profit and expand her business. After 5 solidarity loans and 2 individual loans, all correctly reimbursed, she intends to use this third individual loan to buy 4 loads of firewood, 2 sacks of rice, and 2 sacks of onions. She buys her goods in the villages around Ségou.

Mrs. Aminata D. sells for cash or credit to a clientele composed mainly of women and a few men (who are mostly bakers or meat-roasters). She expects to make a monthly profit of 40,000 F CFA which will be used as working capital and to help her husband support the family.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of firewood, rice, and onions

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more timber to sell

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata  Doucouré est une femme mariée  de 49 ans et mère de 8 enfants qui vit avec son  mari et ses enfants dans une famille traditionnelle avec d’autres ménages dans le quartier Darsalam de Ségou (4ème  région du Mali).
Dès son jeune âge elle s’est intéressée aux activités génératrices de revenus notamment le commerce qu’elle  appris  auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires  et des céréales. Après 10 ans d’apprentissage, elle a pu maîtriser les rouages du petit commerce. Forte de cette expérience,  elle  choisit comme créneau  la vente des produits alimentaires. Elle détient une  boutique aux abords d’un boulevard d’accès très facile du quartier Darsalam. Ses articles sont  soigneusement étalés sur des étagères.
Pour réaliser plus de chiffre d’affaire en augmentant le volume de son activité elle fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est à son 1er  prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser pour acheter 53 cartons de lait en poudre et divers autres produits alimentaires. Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises à  partir de la république islamique de Mauritanie.
Madame Fatoumata  Doucouré vend, en grande partie, au comptant et quelques fois à crédit à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes.
Avec ce prêt, elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50 000FCFA, qui lui permet de faire face aux dépenses familiales (payer la scolarité de ses enfants, compléter le prix du condiment) mais également de rembourser ses dettes.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatoumata Doucouré is a 49 year old married woman and the mother of 8 children; she lives will her husband and their children in a traditional family with other households in the neighborhood of Darsalam de Ségou (4th region of Mali).

At a young age she became interested in businesses which generated income, notably the business that she learned with her mother - selling food condiments and grains. After 10 years of apprenticeship, she mastered the art of small business. With this great experience under her belt, she chose a parallel business - selling food products. She owns a store next to a boulevard which can be easily accessed from the neighborhood of Darsalam. Her merchandise is carefully organized on the shelves of her store.

In order to achieve more sales and increase the volume of her business, she works with Soro Yiriwaso. She is on her first individual loan, which she intends to use to purchase 53 boxes of powdered milk and a variety of other food products. She supplies herself with merchandise from the Islamic Republic of Mauritania. Mrs. Fatoumata Doucouré sells mostly for cash and occasionally for credit, to a clientele composed of men and women.

With this loan, she plans to earn a monthly income of 50,000 FCFA, which will enable her to pay for her family's expenses (school tuition for her children, the full price of the condiments), and to repay her debts.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase powdered milk and a variety of other food products.

loans.name: Aïssata

texts.fr:
Madame  Aïssata M. est âgée de 47 ans, mariée et mère de 8 enfants. Elle vit avec son mari et ses enfants dans une grande famille traditionnelle dans le quartier Alamissani de la ville de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
Elle fréquenta la medersa jusqu’en classe de 9ème année (système éducatif Malien) où elle arrêta pour se marier. En marge de ses études, elle s’intéressa, dès son bas âge, au commerce qu’elle a appris auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires et des calebasses. Avec son mariage,  Aïssata elle, opte pour la vente des habits et des chaussures et jouit aujourd’hui d’une grande réputation dans son quartier.
Dans le but d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour diversifier ses articles de vente, elle  fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 18 mois après avoir bien remboursés 3 prêts solidaires. Elle est à son 1ier prêt individuel qu’elle compte utiliser  pour acheter, 5 pièces de pagnes brodés. Elle s’approvisionne en marchandises au  Burkina Faso et ses articles sont revendus à crédit et au comptant à domicile et en ambulant à une clientèle composée majoritairement de femmes.
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 50.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour payer la scolarité de ses enfants et prendre en charge certaines charges familiales telles que l’achat du savon et l’habillement des enfants.
Son ambition est d’augmenter le volume de son activité.
texts.en:
Mrs. Aïssata M. is 47 years old, married and the mother of 8 children. She lives with her husband and their children in a large, traditional family in the neighborhood of Alamissani, in the city of Ségou (4th Administrative Region of the Republic of Mali).

She attended the madrasah until the 9th grade (in the Malien school system), when she stopped in order to marry. Outside of her studies, at a young age she became interested in the business she learned with her mother, selling food condiments and gourds. With her marriage, Aïssata decided to sell clothes and shoes; today she enjoys a wonderful reputation in her neighborhood.

With the goal of increasing the funds from her business selling various items, she is working with Soro Yiriwaso. She has been working with them for 18 months and has properly reimbursed 3 group loans. This is her first individual loan and she intends to use it to purchase 5 sets of embroidered "pagnes" (printed wax cloths). She supplies herself with merchandise from Burkina Faso. She will sell her merchadise for cash and credit from her home and walking around to a clientele composed mostly of women.

She intends to earn a monthly income of 50,000 FCFA, which she will use to pay for her children's tuition and to take charge of certain family expenses, such as buying soap and clothes for her children. Her ambition is to increase the volume of her business.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase embroidered "pagnes" (colored wax cloths)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more timber to sell

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a member of the Chapakazi borrower group,In kihesa,Morogoro. She is forty years old, married, and a mother of five children aged 25, 23, 19, 19, and 9 years. Anna started her own business selling fish twenty years ago. She works twelve hours a day and gains a monthly profit of approximately 200,000 Tsh.

This is Anna's first loan from BRAC Tanzania, and she has requested the amount of 150,000 TZS to buy more fish to sell. With the additional profits she will gain from the use of this loan, Anna hopes to save more money, pay school fees, get more food for her family, and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more fish  for sale.

loans.name: Scolastica

texts.en:
Scolastica S. is a married woman and a Tanzanian small-business entrepreneur. She runs a beauty salon at Kiwalani Ward in Dar es Salaam. She purchases the business goods from the Kariakoo city business center wholesale shops and from other retail shops. She has been running the business for five years and meets her family’s daily needs from her business income.

Scolastica is requesting a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to capitalize the business by buying more business goods to meet her customers' demands.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to meet her customers' demands

loans.name: Pheap

texts.en:
Mrs. Pheap B. lives in Doem Pour village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living.

In this plantation, she has some problems because her field is infertile and has a lot of insects causing damage to the crop. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticides. She would use the rest of loan to buy gasoline to pump water to support her crop.

Mrs. Pheap B. is 28 years old and the mother of a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Seang Thea, is a hard working man. He is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticides and to buy gasoline to pump water

loans.name: Danaya Group

texts.fr:
Toutes mariées, les quatre femmes du  groupe Danaya ont en moyenne 34 ans, 4 enfants et vivent dans des familles monogames dans le quartier Darsalam de la ville de  Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali).
 Elles se sont connues par des liens socio économiques  et font presque une même activité d’achat et de vente des ustensiles de cuisine en plastique et des bazins teintés. 
Dans le but de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle, elles ont décidé d’intégrer  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur 7ème  prêt solidaire, après avoir bien remboursés tous  les six  prêts précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 5 douzaines de barrique, 3 douzaines de seaux et 40 pièces de pagnes wax. Elles s’approvisionnent en plastiques au Burkina Faso et en pagnes wax au grand marché de Ségou. Elles revendent en détail, au comptant et à crédit, au grand marché de Ségou et en ambulant dans les quartiers pour les pagnes wax à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes. 
Elles comptent réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40.000FCFA  utilisé dans l’achat des fournitures scolaires des enfants, du savon et du complément des frais de condiments. 
Elles ont pour objectif principal d’épargner afin d’avoir un lot à usage d’habitation.
texts.en:
All married, the four women of the group Danaya are an average of 34 years old, with an average of 4 children and living in monogamous family's in the neighborhood of Darsalam, in the city of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali).

They know each other through socio-economic ties and do almost the same business of buying and re-selling plastic kitchen utensils and dyed "bazins" (a type of cloth). With the goal of satisfying the needs of their clientele, they decided to join the micro-finance group Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their seventh group loan and have properly repaid their six previous loans.

This new loan will be used to buy 5 dozen barrels, 3 dozen buckets and 40 sets of wax "pagnes" (colorful wax cloth). They supply themselves with their plastic supplies in Burkina Faso and the wax "pagnes" in the large market of Ségou. They resell at retail prices for cash and for credit, in the large market of Ségou and selling the "pagnes" by walking around the neighborhoods to a clientele composed of men and women.

They will earn an average monthly income of 40,000 FCFA, which they will use to buy school supplies for their children, soap and a complement of fresh condiments. Their main objective is to save money in order to purchase an plot to use for their home.

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase plastic kitchen utensils and wax "pagnes" (wax cloths)

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more hair extensions of various types

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Lucy is a member of the Uamsho borrower group . She is 37 years old, married, and a mother of six children aged 18, 15, 12, 10, 6, and 3 years. She also cares for two other dependents. Lucy started her own cafe selling food three years ago. She works twelve hours a day and earns a monthly profit of approximately 60,000 Tsh.

This is Lucy's first loan from BRAC Tanzania, and she has requested the amount of 200,000 TZS to buy more commodities like sugar, wheat, and rice for her business. With the profit she will gain from the use of this loan, Lucy hopes to save money, pay school fees, get more food for her family, and expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more rice, wheat, and sugar for her business.

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mrs. Mom P. is a farmer in Doem Pour village in Takeo province. She owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice to earn a living.

On her plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field is far from the irrigation system and she does not have enough money to buy a pump in order to support the field. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan for this purpose and she will use the rest of loan to buy rice seed to cultivate rice on the field.

Mrs. Mom P. is 37 years old and the mother of five children, one of whom is employed in a garment factory, three are enrolled in the local school and the youngest one is too young to work or study. Her husband, Mr. Seang Rem, is a fisherman and is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy a pump in order to irrigate her field and to buy rice seed

loans.name: Joseph Kwamah

texts.en: Joseph A. is married to two wives and has nine children. All his children are in school, with his first-born in college and last-born in primary school. Joseph has been repairing cars for the last four years in Naivasha town. Joseph heard about KADET through a friend and decided to join the micro-finance institution. This will be his first loan with KADET and he intends to use it to buy fencing materials to put a perimeter wall around his garage for security purposes. Joseph plans to grow his repair business in future and also to offer employment and training to other people who wish to venture into car mechanics. About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To buy fencing materials to fence off his car repairs garage

loans.name: Paskazia

texts.en:
Paskazia S. is married and is a Tanzanian micro-entrepreneur businesswoman. She runs a tailoring mart school at Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam. She has five sewing machines and six students. They make different types of clothes for both men and women and also schoolchildren’s uniforms. The clothes made are sold and its income is used to expand the business and meet the daily needs of Paskazia’s family.

Paskazia has been running her business for seven years. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to extend the business by buying more sewing machines.

loans.use: To buy more sewing machines

loans.name: Sabali 1  De (Sabali De Chiola) Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe  Sabali  1 sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles traditionnelles avec en moyenne 42 ans, 5 enfants dans le village de Chiola préfecture de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali). 
Dans le but d’avoir des intrants agricoles à leur disposition et de pouvoir recruter des hommes (manœuvres) pour le labour et le sarclage au début de la saison des pluies, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles  sont à leur 1ier  prêt de campagne, après avoir bien remboursé 3 prêts solidaires.
