Ce  prêt  sera utilisé pour acheter, 8 sacs d’engrais, 1.440 kg de semences de mil et d’arachide, recruter de la main d’œuvres pour le labour et le sarclage. Elles se ravitaillent en semences et en engrais à la foire hebdomadaire de Ségou (au grand marché) et de Konodimini. 
Elles espèrent produire sur une superficie de 21 hectares en moyenne 5 tonnes d’arachide, 4 tonnes de mil, 2,4 tonnes d’haricot et des fanes d’haricot destinées à faire des bottes. Une partie de la récolte est auto consommée tandis que l’autre moitié est destinée à la vente. 
Le bénéfice est utilisé pour acheter les condiments hebdomadairement dans les foires et pour  les soins de santé des enfants. 
Elles ont pour objectif d’assurer l’autosuffisance alimentaire.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group Sabali 1 are mostly married in large, traditional families. On average, they are 42 years old and with 5 children. They live in the town of Chiola, in the prefecture of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali).

With the goal of having agricultural fertilizers at their disposal and to be able to recruit men to plow and weed during the beginning of the rainy season, they joined the group Soro Yiriwaso. They are on their first farm loan, having already fully repaid 3 group loans.

This loan will be used to purchase 8 sacks of fertilizer, 1,400 kilograms of seeds for millet and peanuts, recruit agricultural workers for the plowing and the weeding. They resupply themselves with seeds and fertilizers in the weekly markets in Ségou (the big market) and Konodimini.

On an area of 21 hectares, they hope to produce an average of 5 tons of peanuts, 4 tons of millet, 2.4 tons of beans and the tops of the beans (the leaves of the bean plant) will be made into bundles. They will consume part of the harvest and the other half is intended for sale.

The profits will be used to purchase food at the weekly markers and healthcare for their children

Translated from French by Margot Bonner, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase seeds, fertilizer, and pay for the wages of people to plow and weed.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more material such as vitenge and kanga

loans.name: Aderonke

texts.en:
Aderonke is happily married with a kid and she is 44 years old. She lives in Lagos where she sells sachet water (water in plastic bags) and also grinds yam and cassava to elubo (powder form). She has been in this business for the past fifteen years.

Aderonke hopes for the loan of N70,000 to purchase a grinding machine for beans, tomatoes, and peppers and also to buy more sachet water to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase a grinding machine and more sachet water to sell

loans.name: Aderunty

texts.en:
T. is 44 years old and married with two children. She lives in Ogun State. She sells doors and windows and has been in the business for the past fifteen years.

T. is requesting the loan N140,000 to purchase more doors and windows to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more doors and windows to sell

loans.name: Channa

texts.en:
Mrs. Channa K. is a villager in Ta Saum village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land on which she cultivates rice.

On her plantation, she faces an obstacle because she has always hired a laborer with two oxen to plow her field. Instead, she decided to ask for a loan to buy two cows for breeding and to use them to reduce her expense of plowing her field.

Her husband, Mr. Phan Sort, is a traditional-medicine seller. This couple has two children who are too young to work or study. Her husband and a child are shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy two cows for breeding and to reduce the expense of plowing her field

loans.name: Wastara

texts.en:
Wastara A. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and businesswoman. She runs two businesses at Yombo Makangarawe Ward in Dar es Salaam. She runs a pharmacy and a shop that sells tailoring items. She purchases the business goods from the wholesale shops at Kariakoo city business center.

Wastara has been in the business for six years. She started with her pharmacy shop and then opened her shop selling tailoring supplies. She needs a loan of Tshs 1,000,000 to buy more business goods.

Wastara managed to buy a building plot and she has started constructing a house.

loans.use: To buy more business goods to meet her customers' demands

loans.name: Lassana

texts.fr:
Monsieur Lassana D. est un célibataire de 28 ans, sans enfant qui  vit chez son oncle dans une famille traditionnelle élargie  dans le quartier Médine, est un des vieux quartier de la ville  Bougouni (troisième région administrative de la république de Mali).
Né  en  république de Côte d’Ivoire, il fut obligé d’interrompre ses études suites aux événements politiques survenu dans ce pays il y’a près de 7 ans.
Monsieur Lassana D. décida  une fois au pays d’origine, de s’initier au commerce auprès de son oncle qui  possède plusieurs boutiques de quincaillerie. Avec 5 années d’expérience, il maîtrise bien son activité et est très sollicité.
Dans ses recherches de ressources financières complémentaires, il rejoint l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec laquelle, il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Avec ce prêt, il compte  acheter, des appareils électroniques pour sa boutique d’articles divers où on y vend un peu de tout, matériels de sonorisation, quincaillerie,  lubrifiants etc.
 Il s’approvisionne à Bamako(capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes,  et effectue sa vente au comptant, en détail et à crédit  à une clientèle est composée de toute les catégories sociales. 
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Lassana D.  compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 75 000 FCFA qui servira à étoffer son fonds de commerce.
Son ambition est  d’agrandir sa boutique .
texts.en:
Mr. Lassana D., age 28, is unmarried and has no children.  He lives at his uncle's place in a traditional extended family in the Médine district, one of the old districts of the city of Bougouni (3rd administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Born in the Republic of Cote d'Ivoire, Lassana was compelled to interrupt his schooling after political events occurring in this country almost seven years ago.  Once back in his ancestral country, he decided to become familiarized with commerce with the help of his uncle, who owns several hardware stores.  With five years of experience, Lassana has a good command of his business and is in high demand.  In his search for supplemental financial resources, he joined the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is now on his first individual loan.  With this loan, he intends to buy electronics for his general store that sells a bit of everything, sound equipment, hardware, lubricants, etc.  He stocks up in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers, and he sells retail, cash or credit accepted, to customers of all walks of life.  With this loan, Lassana plans on realizing a monthly profit of 75,000 francs CFA that will serve to round out his working capital.  His ambition is to expand his store.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy electronic equipment

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more material such as vitenge and kanga

loans.name: Yann

texts.en:
Mrs. Yann K. lives in An Doung Samreth village in Takeo province. She is a Khmer noodle seller. She is also a farmer who owns a plot of land on which she cultivates rice.

On her plantation, Mrs. Yann K. faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to cultivate rice. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and to hire laborers to work on the field. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family’s living conditions with this loan.

Mrs. Yann K. is 41 years old and is a widow. She has a child who is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and to hire laborers to work on her field

loans.name: Chacha

texts.en:
Chacha M. is a Tanzanian entrepreneur and businessman. He runs a food shop at Kitunda ward in Dar es Salaam selling a variety of food crop products including cereal and leguminous crop products such as wheat flour, maize flour, beans, groundnuts (peanuts), cooking oil and sugar.

Chacha purchases the business goods from the wholesale shops and sometimes direct from the producers. He is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To expand his business by buying more business goods

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
Monsieur Mamadou Traoré est âgé de 39 ans et père d’un enfant. Il vit avec sa femme et son enfant chez ses parents dans une famille traditionnelle élargie dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de la ville de Bougouni (région de Sikasso).
Il abandonna l’école en classe de 7ème année fondamentale (système éducatif Malien), pour suivre à son père chauffeur dans le dessein de devenir un chauffeur. Pendant des années il fît l’apprenti chauffeur jusqu’a avoir son permis de conduire, il y’a  8 ans  de cela..
Après avoir été chauffeur d’un particulier (c’est à dire d’une tierce personne) pendant des années,  il décida d’abandonner ce métier (qui ne lui rapportait  pas financièrement) pour mener l’activité d’achat et de vente de carburants et lubrifiants dans le quartier Massabla Coura. Il a appris cette activité auprès d’un de ses son ami d’enfance. Avec 3 années d’expérience, Monsieur Mamadou Traoré  maîtrise son activité.
Pour le renforcement de ses activités, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte  acheter de l’essence et  de l’huile à moteur en quantité, auprès des grossistes  de Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali.)  Il vend en détail, au comptant et rarement à crédit  à une clientèle composée généralement  de motocyclistes.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Mamadou Traoré compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 32 500 FCFA.
Dans les années à venir il envisage diversifier ses ventes en y associant le collage des pneus.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou Traoré, age 39, is a father with one child.  He lives with his wife and child in his parents' place within a traditional extended family in the Hérémakono Nord district of the city of Bougouni (region of Sikasso).  He dropped out of his 7th year of primary school (educational system of Mali) in order to follow after his father, who is a driver, with the idea of becoming a driver himself.  For year, he was an apprentice driver until he obtained his driver's permit eight years ago.  After being a driver for an individual (that is, a third party) for years, he decided to leave this trade (which wasn't bringing in enough income) in order to run a business buying and selling fuels and lubricants in the Massabla Coura district.  He learned about this work from one of his childhood friends.  With three years of experience, Mamadou is mastering his business. To bolster his business, he decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso and is now on his first individual loan.  He intends to buy gasoline and motor oil in quantity from wholesalers in Bamako (capital of Mali).  Accepting cash but rarely credit, he sells retail to customers who are generally motorcyclists.  With this loan, he plans on realizing a monthly profit of 32,500 francs CFA.  In the years ahead, he envisions diversifying his sales by including tire repair supplies.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For buying motor oil and gasoline

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce R. is a Tanzanian businesswoman entrepreneur. She runs the Beautiful Salon at Yombo Makangarawe ward in Dar es Salaam. Maximum business sales are from Friday to Sunday when workers are on the weekend and preparing themselves for the coming week. She purchases her business goods from Kariakoo wholesale and retail cosmetics shops. She is requesting a loan of Tshs 800,000 to buy more business goods.

loans.use: To buy more business materials

loans.name: Basir Ahmad

texts.en: Basir Ahmad has got a catering shop. He is 36, married with three children. He is the son of D. M. and lives in District 9 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He wants to fulfill the requirements of his shop and expand his business, so he has requested an individual loan of 50,000 afghani. He is confident that with this loan he will increase his business as soon as possible. He would like to thank all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: For a catering business

loans.name: Yaya

texts.fr:
Monsieur Yaya B. est un célibataire de 20 ans, sans enfant qui vit chez sa tante dans le quartier Hérémakono Nord de Bougouni.(région de Sikasso)
N’ayant jamais fréquenté l’école moderne, pendant des années il aidait son père dans les travaux champêtres au village. Afin d’avoir une activité lucrative, il décida de venir à Bougouni ville pour apprendre un métier. C’est ainsi qu’il opte pour la réparation des motos auprès de son cousin. Avec un expérience de 8 ans Monsieur Yaya B. maîtrise bien son activité.
En vu de mieux rentabiliser  de son activité et de fidéliser sa clientèle en les dispensant des centaines de mètres de marche à la recherche des pièces, il décida de collaborer avec Soro Yiriwaso  avec qui il est à son premier prêt individuel.
Il compte utiliser ce prêt pour acheter des pièces détachées pour  motos  à Bamako (capitale de la république du Mali) auprès des grossistes du  grand marché et du Dibibani.
Avec ce prêt, Monsieur Yaya B. compte réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 33 000 FCFA qui lui permettra d’aider sa tante à assurer les dépenses de la famille et investir le reste dans ses activités.
texts.en:
Mr. Yaya B., age 20, is unmarried and has no children.  He lives at his aunt's place in the Hérémakono Nord of Bougouni (region of Sikasso).  Never having had modern schooling, he used to help his father for years with field work in the village.  To have lucrative work, he decided to come to Bougouni City to learn a trade.  And so, he opted for repairing motorbikes with his cousin.  With eight years of experience, Yaya has a good command of his work. For making his business more profitable and earning the loyalty of his customers, by way of saving them from going hundreds of meters in search of spare parts, Yaya decided to collaborate with Soro Yiriwaso, a micro-finance institution, with which he is now on his first individual loan.  He intends to use this loan to buy spare parts for motorbikes in Bamako (capital of Mali) from wholesalers at the grand marketplace and from Dibibani. With this loan, Yaya plans on realizing a monthly profit of 33,000 francs CFA that will allow him to help his aunt with covering family expenses and to invest the rest into his business.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: For buying spare parts

loans.name: Aun

texts.en: Mrs. Aun N. lives in Doem Pour village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to cultivate rice this season. Thus, she decided to ask for a loan to buy rice seed, fertilizer, and pesticides and to hire laborers to work on the field. Her husband, Mr. Noun Rith, is a fisherman. This couple has a child who is too young to work or study. Her husband and child are with her in the picture.

loans.use: To buy seed, fertilizer, pesticides, and to hire laborers to work on the field.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more laboratory equipment

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Victoria sells notebooks and textbooks. She has been in this business for the past 10 years. Victoria is 43 years old and married with 4 children. She hopes for the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more notebooks and textbooks to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more note and text books to sell

loans.name: Afi Edem

texts.fr: Cette femme est une veuve qui a à sa charge ses 02 enfants, elle a abandonné sa profession d’institutrice pour se lancer dans le commerce produits cosmétiques, elle a associé plus tard à ce commerce la vente de chaussures et de sacs. Avec son commerce elle subvient mieux aux charges de sa famille, sa clientèle grandit ce qui l’oblige à agrandir son stock, c’est pour cela qu’elle sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour acheter des produits cosmétiques, 10 chaussures et 5 sacs.
texts.en:
This woman is a widow who has two children in her care.  She left her profession as a primary school teacher in order to get started in the commerce of cosmetics.  She later included with this business the sale of shoes and bags.  With this business, she provides more for her family.  Her customer base is growing, and this compels her to expand her inventory.  This is why she is requesting a loan from WAGES to buy some cosmetic products, ten shoes, and five bags. 

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy cosmetic products, shoes, and bags to sell

loans.name: Titilope

texts.en: Titilope sells clothes, shoes and bags, and has been in this business for the past five years. She has been borrowing from LAPO for the past two years, and her previous loans boosted her business. Titilope is 45 years old and married with three children. She is very happy with LAPO and Kiva lenders for their financial support. She is requesting a loan for N100,000 to purchase more clothes and bags to sell. She thanks you.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes and bags to sell

loans.name: Chum

texts.en: Mr. Chum C. is 25 years old and lives in Sambuor village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a piece of land that he uses to cultivate rice. He is also a construction worker. His wife, Mrs. Khat Nhoen, is a grocer who owns a small grocery store. Since her business is doing well, she wants to expand by purchasing more goods to add to her inventory. Thus, Mr. Chum C. decided to ask for a loan for this purpose. He has a child who is attending the local school. His wife is presented on the right in this photo.

loans.use: Purchasing goods to add to the inventory of his wife's grocery store

loans.name: Osunbiye

texts.en: Osunbiye is 42 years old and married with 5 children. She sells textbooks and notebooks. She has been in this business for the past 18 years. Osunbiye lives in Ogun state. She is requesting for the loan amount of N140, 000 to purchase more textbooks and notebooks to sell. She thanks all kiva lender.

loans.use: To purchase more textbooks and notebooks to sell

loans.name: Rosemary J.

texts.en: RoseM. is a married woman with a small business raising and selling poultry. She sells both broilers and layers at the Yombo Buza ward in Dar es Salaam.  At first, she was only keeping broilers, but as capital increased she decided to keep layers, as well.  She sells six trays of eggs per day.  RoseM. is asking for a loan of TZS 800,000 to buy more chicks and feed for her poultry.

loans.use: To buy more chicks and poultry feed

loans.name: Benkadi De Tieblebougou Group

texts.fr:
Au nombre de dix paysannes  toutes mariées, les membres du groupe BENKADI ont une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans et 6 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans des familles conjugales traditionnelles élargies avec leurs frères, sœurs, enfants et époux  dans le village de TIEBLEBOUGOU qui relève de la commune rurale de KOLA de la préfecture de BOUGOUNI, région de SIKASSO, république du Mali. 
A travers des activités agricoles hivernales ses femmes se sont connues. 
Dans l’intention d’augmenter leur productivité agricole, satisfaire l’autosuffisance alimentaire et prétendre à vendre une partie de la production ressource, elles ont décidé d’adhérer à  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso. Elles sont à leur quatrième prêt agricole et tous les précédents ont été correctement remboursés. 
Avec ce nouveau prêt elles comptent  payer les frais de labour, sarclage et acheter 24 sacs d’engrais dont 8 sacs de complexe céréales et 16 sacs d’urée 18 bidons d’herbicide tout cela pour faire 6 hectares d’arachide et 9 hectares de sorgho. Tous les intrants agricoles de groupe sont achetés sur le marché de BOUGOUNI. La production totale attendue par le groupe est estimée à 5,250 tonnes d’arachide graine et 13 tonnes de sorgho. 
Une partie de cette production est destinée à la consommation familiale et l’autre partie sera stockée et vendue en gros et au comptant aux commerçants de BOUGOUNI. 
Après la vente du stock, le groupe espère obtenir un bénéfice de 320 000 FCFA en fin de campagne qui sera  utilisé pour soutenir les frais scolaire des enfants.
texts.en:
Numbering ten peasant women, all married, the members of the group BENKADI average 42 years of age and 6 children.  All the women live in traditional extended conjugal families with their brothers, sisters, children, and husbands in the village of TIEBLEBOUGOU, which is part of the rural community of KOLA, in the prefecture of BOUGOUNI, region of SIKASSO, Republic of Mali. The women know one another through wintertime farm work.  With the intention of increasing their agricultural productivity, achieving self-sufficiency in food, and claiming a portion of their produce to sell, the group members decided to join the micro-finance institution Soro Yiriwaso.  They are now on their fourth farm loan.  All the preceding ones have been correctly repaid. With this new loan, they plan on covering the cost of labor and weeding and of buying 24 sacks of fertilizer, including 8 sacks of a blend for grains, 16 sacks of urea, and 18 drums of herbicide.  All of this is for 6 hectares of peanuts and 9 hectares of sorghum.  All of the group's farm supplies are purchased at the BOUGOUNI market.  The total production expected by the group is estimated at 5.25 tonnes of peanuts and 13 tonnes of sorghum.  A portion of the production is destined for family consumption.  The other portion will be stored and sold wholesale and in cash to BOUGOUNI merchants.  After the sale, the group hopes to obtain a profit of 320,000 francs CFA at the end of the planting campaign.  This profit will be used to cover the cost of schooling for the children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Farm supplies, cost of labor and weeding

loans.name: Adjoa

texts.fr:
Cette femme exerce dans la vente de produits d’alimentation générale, elle fait ce commerce depuis 2000, son ancienneté dans ce commerce lui a permis d’avoir une grande clientèle. Son stock actuel de produits d’alimentation générale a connu une baisse, elle veut se réapprovisionner et sollicite de WAGES un crédit pour se réapprovisionner avec 4 bidons d’huile, 4 boîtes de conserves, 1 carton de lait  et divers produits d’alimentation générale.
Elle est mariée et mère de 03 enfants
texts.en:
This is a woman who earns an income from selling grocery items.  She has been in this business since 2000.  Her seniority in this commence has enabled her to have many customers.  Her current stock of grocery items has experienced a drop.  She wants to stock up again and is requesting a loan from WAGES for 4 drums of oil, 4 boxes of canned food, 1 box of milk, and various food items.  She is married and the mother of three children.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy food items to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more equipment for her fishing business

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en: Jocelyn T. is 46 years old, single, and lives in Barraks Magallon, in the town of Moises Padilla, Negros Occidental. Jocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1990 and has used the money she borrows as capital for her duck-raising business. Even though she is single, Jocelyn has familial responsibilities, as she is helping in the support of her nephews. So her duck-raising business has been a big help to her family unit. The income that it generates is supporting their daily needs, especially in buying the basic necessities like rice, clothes and paying for the education of her wards. Jocelyn’s new loan of PHP 25,000 will again fund her duck-raising business. It will be used to buy ducklings, to repair the cages and pens, and to buy feeds. Jocelyn is thankful that she has access to loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon because it allows her to continue her business and support her family. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation, Inc. has answered the call of not just a few, but thousands of women. Through the alleviation program, these women have progressed from earning less than a measly $1 a day, to surpassing realities beyond their dreams. They have learned to live a life where they can finally be called honorable. This is Project Dungganon.

loans.use: To use as working capital for her duck-raising business
